Toast: Bread dried and browned before a fire, usually in slices; also, a kind of food prepared by putting slices of toasted bread into milk, gravy, etc.
Testudinata: An order of reptiles which includes the turtles and tortoises. The body is covered by a shell consisting of an upper or dorsal shell, called the carapace, and a lower or ventral shell, called the plastron, each of which consists of several plates.
Tagsore: Adhesion of the tail of a sheep to the wool from excoriation produced by contact with the feces; -- called also tagbelt.
Testudinal: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, a tortoise.
Testudinate: Resembling a tortoise shell in appearance or structure; roofed; arched; vaulted.
Tramming: The act or process of forming trams. See 2d Tram.
Thallium: A rare metallic element of the aluminium group found in some minerals, as certain pyrites, and also in the lead-chamber deposit in the manufacture of sulphuric acid. It is isolated as a heavy, soft, bluish white metal, easily oxidized in moist air, but preserved by keeping under water. Symbol Tl. Atomic weight 203.7.
Tamper: To meddle; to be busy; to try little experiments; as, to tamper with a disease.
Tropeine: Any one of a series of artificial ethereal salts derived from the alkaloidal base tropine.
Tailed: Having a tail; having (such) a tail or (so many) tails; -- chiefly used in composition; as, bobtailed, longtailed, etc.
Tartarus: The infernal regions, described in the Iliad as situated as far below Hades as heaven is above the earth, and by later writers as the place of punishment for the spirits of the wicked. By the later poets, also, the name is often used synonymously with Hades, or the Lower World in general.
Tribalism: The state of existing in tribes; also, tribal feeling; tribal prejudice or exclusiveness; tribal peculiarities or characteristics.
Theurgy: A divine work; a miracle; hence, magic; sorcery.
Tetragon: A plane figure having four sides and angles; a quadrangle, as a square, a rhombus, etc.
Toledo: A sword or sword blade made at Toledo in Spain, which city was famous in the 16th and 17th centuries for the excellence of its weapons.
Telesmatic: Of or pertaining to telesms; magical.
Thrive: To prosper by industry, economy, and good management of property; to increase in goods and estate; as, a farmer thrives by good husbandry.
Titano-: A combining form (also used adjectively) designating certain double compounds of titanium with some other elements; as, titano-cyanide, titano-fluoride, titano-silicate, etc.
Tautophonical: Pertaining to, or characterized by, tautophony; repeating the same sound.
Tiler: A doorkeeper or attendant at a lodge of Freemasons.
Tetrapharmacom: A combination of wax, resin, lard, and pitch, composing an ointment.
Tabulation: The act of forming into a table or tables; as, the tabulation of statistics.
Torchbearer: One whose office it is to carry a torch.
Titling: The hedge sparrow; -- called also titlene. Its nest often chosen by the cuckoo as a place for depositing its own eggs.
Target date: The date set as a goal for completion of some activity.
Trachytoid: Resembling trachyte; -- used to define the structure of certain rocks.
Tallness: The quality or state of being tall; height of stature.
Tachograph: A recording or registering tachometer; also, its autographic record.
Tallowing: The act, or art, of causing animals to produce tallow; also, the property in animals of producing tallow.
Tompon: An inking pad used in lithographic printing.
Tryptone: The peptone formed by pancreatic digestion; -- so called because it is formed through the agency of the ferment trypsin.
tribology: the study of the effects of friction on parts of machinery moving in contact with each other, and of methods, such as lubrication, to counteract negative effects such as wear.
Tartarian: The name of some kinds of cherries, as the Black Tartarian, or the White Tartarian.
Torpescence: The quality or state or being torpescent; torpidness; numbness; stupidity.
Turnip: The edible, fleshy, roundish, or somewhat conical, root of a cruciferous plant (Brassica campestris, var. Napus); also, the plant itself.
Tut: An imperial ensign consisting of a golden globe with a cross on it.
Truancy: The act of playing truant, or the state of being truant; as, addicted to truancy.
Terminalia: A festival celebrated annually by the Romans on February 23 in honor of Terminus, the god of boundaries.
Transferable: Capable of being transferred or conveyed from one place or person to another.
Talking: That talks; able to utter words; as, a talking parrot.
Tearpit: A cavity or pouch beneath the lower eyelid of most deer and antelope; the lachrymal sinus; larmier. It is capable of being opened at pleasure and secretes a waxy substance.
Tunable: Capable of being tuned, or made harmonious; hence, harmonious; musical; tuneful.
Turonian: One of the subdivisions into which the Upper Cretaceous formation of Europe is divided.
Thomsens disease: An affection apparently congenital, consisting in tonic contraction and stiffness of the voluntary muscles occurring after a period of muscular inaction.
Telegraph plant: A tick trefoil (Meibomia gyrans formerly Desmodium gyrans), native of the East Indies; it is a leguminous plant whose lateral leaflets jerk up and down like the arms of a semaphore, and also rotate on their axes.
Tenure: The act or right of holding, as property, especially real estate.
Transposable: That may transposed; as, a transposable phrase.
Twattle: Act of prating; idle talk; twaddle.
Tablature: A painting on a wall or ceiling; a single piece comprehended in one view, and formed according to one design; hence, a picture in general.
Thermidor: The eleventh month of the French republican calendar, -- commencing July 19, and ending August 17. See the Note under Vendémiaire.
Thoracostraca: An extensive division of Crustacea, having a dorsal shield or carapec&unr_; &unr_;&unr_;niting all, or nearly all, of the thoracic somites to the head. It includes the crabs, lobsters, shrimps, and similar species.
Trimorph: A substance which crystallizes in three distinct forms, or which has three distinct physical states; also, any one of these distinct forms. See Trimorphism, 1.
Teuton: One of an ancient German tribe; later, a name applied to any member of the Germanic race in Europe; now used to designate a German, Dutchman, Scandinavian, etc., in distinction from a Celt or one of a Latin race.
Tariff: To make a list of duties on, as goods.
Topful: Full to the top, ore brim; brimfull.
Theme: A subject or topic on which a person writes or speaks; a proposition for discussion or argument; a text.
T\u00eate-\u00e0-t\u00eate: Face to face; privately or confidentially; familiarly.
Thoughtful: Full of thought; employed in meditation; contemplative; as, a man of thoughtful mind.
Tanning: The art or process of converting skins into leather. See Tan, v. t., 1.
Taille: A tally; an account scored on a piece of wood.
Terza rima: A peculiar and complicated system of versification, borrowed by the early Italian poets from the Troubadours.
Transpositional: Of or pertaining to transposition; involving transposition.
Tenth: The next in order after the ninth; one coming after nine others.
Tallwood: Firewood cut into billets of a certain length.
Transmogrification: The act of transmogrifying, or the state of being transmogrified; transformation.
Turkish: Of or pertaining to Turkey or the Turks.
Tile-drain: To drain by means of tiles; to furnish with a tile drain.
Tinny: Pertaining to, abounding with, or resembling, tin.
Ticketing: A periodical sale of ore in the English mining districts; -- so called from the tickets upon which are written the bids of the buyers.
Trill: To utter trills or a trill; to play or sing in tremulous vibrations of sound; to have a trembling sound; to quaver.
Thionine: An artificial red or violet dyestuff consisting of a complex sulphur derivative of certain aromatic diamines, and obtained as a dark crystalline powder; -- called also phenylene violet.
Tailoring: The business or the work of a tailor or a tailoress.
Thialol: A colorless oily liquid, (C2H5)2S2, having a strong garlic odor; -- called also ethyl disulphide. By extension, any one of the series of related compounds.
Troubler: One who troubles or disturbs; one who afflicts or molests; a disturber; as, a troubler of the peace.
Thyroarytenoid: Of or pertaining to both the thyroid and arytenoid cartilages of the larynx.
Tapa: A kind of cloth prepared by the Polynesians from the inner bark of the paper mulberry; -- sometimes called also kapa.
Tipcat: A game in which a small piece of wood pointed at both ends, called a cat, is tipped, or struck with a stick or bat, so as to fly into the air.
Tape: To furnish with tape; to fasten, tie, bind, or the like, with tape;
Ticklish: Sensible to slight touches; easily tickled; as, the sole of the foot is very ticklish; the hardened palm of the hand is not ticklish.
Trefle: A species of time; -- so called from its resemblance in form to a trefoil.
Trowelful: As much as a trowel will hold; enough to fill a trowel.
Tupperware: the collective trade name for a type of plastic food-storage container with a translucent bottom and a close-fitting lid designed to seal the container tightly.  It is in common use in the late 20th century and early 21st century in the U. S.  It comes in a variety of shapes and sizes, suitable for storing a variety of items.  Also used attributively.
Triatomic: Having three atoms; -- said of certain elements or radicals.
Tapis: To cover or work with figures like tapestry.
Tapir: Any one of several species of large odd-toed ungulates belonging to Tapirus, Elasmognathus, and allied genera. They have a long prehensile upper lip, short ears, short and stout legs, a short, thick tail, and short, close hair. They have three toes on the hind feet, and four toes on the fore feet, but the outermost toe is of little use.
Theophilanthropic: Pertaining to theophilanthropy or the theophilanthropists.
Thoroughgoing: Going through, or to the end or bottom; very thorough; complete.
Tape recording: a recording of sound or video on magnetic tape.
Timbrel: A kind of drum, tabor, or tabret, in use from the highest antiquity.
Train: That which draws along; especially, persuasion, artifice, or enticement; allurement.
Terin: A small yellow singing bird, with an ash-colored head; the European siskin. Called also tarin.
Thoracoplasty: A remodeling or reshaping of the thorax; especially, the operation of removing the ribs, so as to obliterate the pleural cavity in cases of empyema.
Tollage: Payment of toll; also, the amount or quantity paid as toll.
thanehood: The character or dignity of a thane; also, thanes, collectively.
Trigonometry: That branch of mathematics which treats of the relations of the sides and angles of triangles, which the methods of deducing from certain given parts other required parts, and also of the general relations which exist between the trigonometrical functions of arcs or angles.
Tanagrine: Of or pertaining to the tanagers.
Taffrail: The upper part of a ship's stern, which is flat like a table on the top, and sometimes ornamented with carved work; the rail around a ship's stern.
Tyrant: To act like a tyrant; to play the tyrant; be to tyrannical.
Trichloride: A chloride having three atoms of chlorine in the molecule.
Teetotalism: The principle or practice of entire abstinence, esp. from intoxicating drinks.
Timberman: A man employed in placing supports of timber in a mine.
Turnkey: A person who has charge of the keys of a prison, for opening and fastening the doors; a warder.
Theorbo: An instrument made like large lute, but having two necks, with two sets of pegs, the lower set holding the strings governed by frets, while to the upper set were attached the long bass strings used as open notes.
Triacid: Capable of neutralizing three molecules of a monobasic acid or the equivalent; having three hydrogen atoms which may be acid radicals; -- said of certain bases; thus, glycerin is a triacid base.
Treatise: A written composition on a particular subject, in which its principles are discussed or explained; a tract.
Tasco: A kind of clay for making melting pots.
Tuberculin: A fluid containing the products formed by the growth of the tubercle bacillus in a suitable culture medium.
Trustworthy: Worthy of trust or confidence; trusty.
Thallus: A solid mass of cellular tissue, consisting of one or more layers, usually in the form of a flat stratum or expansion, but sometimes erect or pendulous, and elongated and branching, and forming the substance of the thallogens.
Taleteller: One who tells tales or stories, especially in a mischievous or officious manner; a talebearer; a telltale; a tattler.
tetrahydrocannabinol: A chemical substance (C21H20O2) which is produced by the hemp plant (Cannabis sativa), and is the physiologically active agent of dried preparations of that plant, called variously marijuana, hashish, ganja, hemp, etc.; also called THC.  It causes the euphoric effect for which the preparations are smoked or chewed.  It is used in medicine in a purified form as an antiemetic (an antinausea agent), especially in conjunction with chemotherapy of cancer.  It occurs primarily as the Δ1-3,4-trans isomer, also called Δ9-THC, with small amounts of the Δ6-3,4-trans isomer detectable at about 1%.  It is a controlled substance, classified as a hallucinogen, and its possession or distribution is illegal in almost all states of the United States.
Traverse: To use the posture or motions of opposition or counteraction, as in fencing.
Tinge: A degree, usually a slight degree, of some color, taste, or something foreign, infused into another substance or mixture, or added to it; tincture; color; dye; hue; shade; taste.
Tintinnabulum: A bell; also, a set or combination of bells or metal plates used as a musical instrument or as a toy.
Tanager: Any one of numerous species of bright-colored singing birds belonging to Tanagra, Piranga, and allied genera. The scarlet tanager (Piranga erythromelas) and the summer redbird (Piranga rubra) are common species of the United States.
Tumor: A morbid swelling, prominence, or growth, on any part of the body; especially, a growth produced by deposition of new tissue; a neoplasm.
Transumptive: Taking from one to another; metaphorical.
Toothlet: A little tooth, or like projection.
Theban: A native or inhabitant of Thebes; also, a wise man.
Trust company: Any corporation formed for the purpose of acting as trustee.  Such companies usually do more or less of a banking business.
Teinland: Land granted by the crown to a thane or lord.
Tzarina: The empress of Russia.  See Czarina.
Tasmanian: Of or pertaining to Tasmania, or Van Diemen's Land.
Trachenchyma: A vegetable tissue consisting of tracheæ.
Tussock: A tuft, as of grass, twigs, hair, or the like; especially, a dense tuft or bunch of grass or sedge.
Trochilics: The science of rotary motion, or of wheel work.
Twelvescore: Twelve times twenty; two hundred and forty.
Trustee stock: High-grade stock in which trust funds may be legally invested.
Tapiser: A maker of tapestry; an upholsterer.
Transept: The transversal part of a church, which crosses at right angles to the greatest length, and between the nave and choir. In the basilicas, this had often no projection at its two ends. In Gothic churches these project these project greatly, and should be called the arms of the transept. It is common, however, to speak of the arms themselves as the transepts.
Trisoctahedron: A solid of the isometric system bounded by twenty-four equal faces, three corresponding to each face of an octahedron.
Teosinte: A large grass (Euchlæna luxurians) closely related to maize. It is native of Mexico and Central America, but is now cultivated for fodder in the Southern United States and in many warm countries. Called also Guatemala grass.
Tottery: Trembling or vaccilating, as if about to fall; unsteady; shaking.
Three: The number greater by a unit than two; three units or objects.
Tend: To move in a certain direction; -- usually with to or towards.
Taurine: A chemical compound occurring in small quantity in the juices of muscle, in the lungs, and elsewhere, but especially in the bile, where it is found as a component part of taurocholic acid, from which it can be prepared by decomposition of the acid. It crystallizes in colorless, regular six-sided prisms, and is especially characterized by containing both nitrogen and sulphur, being chemically amido-isethionic acid, C2H7NSO3.
Tymp: A hollow water-cooled iron casting in the upper part of the archway in which the dam stands.
Touchy: Peevish; irritable; irascible; techy; apt to take fire.
Transmute: To change from one nature, form, or substance, into another; to transform.
Teest: A tinsmith's stake, or small anvil.
Topmast: The second mast, or that which is next above the lower mast, and below the topgallant mast.
Tent: To lodge as a tent; to tabernacle.
Teratology: That branch of biological science which treats of monstrosities, malformations, or deviations from the normal type of structure, either in plants or animals.
Three-cornered: Having three corners, or angles; as, a three-cornered hat.
Turpitude: Inherent baseness or vileness of principle, words, or actions; shameful wickedness; depravity.
Traducer: One who traduces; a slanderer; a calumniator.
Terebene: A polymeric modification of terpene, obtained as a white crystalline camphorlike substance; -- called also camphene. By extension, any one of a group of related substances.
Trapper: One who traps animals; one who makes a business of trapping animals for their furs.
Tamworth: One of a long-established English breed of large pigs. They are red, often spotted with black, with a long snout and erect or forwardly pointed ears, and are valued as bacon producers.
Troubadour: One of a school of poets who flourished from the eleventh to the thirteenth century, principally in Provence, in the south of France, and also in the north of Italy. They invented, and especially cultivated, a kind of lyrical poetry characterized by intricacy of meter and rhyme, and usually of a romantic, amatory strain.
Training wheels: a pair of small wheels attached to the rear of a bicycle to keep the bicycle upright; -- used to assist those, especially small children, learning how to ride a bicycle.
Tungstate: A salt of tungstic acid; a wolframate.
Turko-Iranian: A member of any race of the Turko-Iranian type.
Tracklayer: Any workman engaged in work involved in putting the track in place.
Tithonicity: The state or property of being tithonic; actinism.
T\u00e6niola: One of the radial partitions which separate the internal cavities of certain medusæ.
Thaumatolatry: Worship or undue admiration of wonderful or miraculous things.
Tenant: To hold, occupy, or possess as a tenant.
Twelfth: The quotient of a unit divided by twelve; one of twelve equal parts of one whole.
Tudor: Of or pertaining to a royal line of England, descended from Owen Tudor of Wales, who married the widowed queen of Henry V. The first reigning Tudor was Henry VII.; the last, Elizabeth.
Tractarian: Of or pertaining to the Tractarians, or their principles.
Testosterone: a steroid hormone (C19H28O2) produced mostly in the testes, which is responsible for producing the secondary sexual characteristics of males.
Thyme: Any plant of the labiate genus Thymus. The garden thyme (Thymus vulgaris) is a warm, pungent aromatic, much used to give a relish to seasoning and soups.
Trigraph: Three letters united in pronunciation so as to have but one sound, or to form but one syllable, as -ieu in adieu; a triphthong.
Theopneustic: Given by the inspiration of the Spirit of God.
Three-sided: Having three sides, especially three plane sides; as, a three-sided stem, leaf, petiole, peduncle, scape, or pericarp.
Trichobranchia: The gill of a crustacean in which the branchial filaments are slender and cylindrical, as in the crawfishes.
Toper: One who topes, or drinks frequently or to excess; a drunkard; a sot.
Traditor: A deliverer; -- a name of infamy given to Christians who delivered the Scriptures, or the goods of the church, to their persecutors to save their lives.
Telephonic: Conveying sound to a great distance.
Truculent: Fierce; savage; ferocious; barbarous; as, the truculent inhabitants of Scythia.
Topek: An Eskimo house made of material other than snow, esp. one having walls of turf, driftwood, rock, or skin, and a roof of skins of the walrus or seal.  In Alaska it is often partially underground and covered with timber and turf.  Topeks are also used by Indians of the lower Yukon region.
Torquate: Collared; having a torques, or distinct colored ring around the neck.
Typho\u00eban: Of or pertaining to Typhoeus (t&iuptack_;*fō"ūs), the fabled giant of Greek mythology, having a hundred heads; resembling Typhoeus.
Thymy: Abounding with thyme; fragrant; as, a thymy vale.
Trackway: Any of two or more narrow paths, of steel, smooth stone, or the like, laid in a public roadway otherwise formed of an inferior pavement, as cobblestones, to provide an easy way for wheels.
Tessellated: Formed of little squares, as mosaic work; checkered; as, a tessellated pavement.
Trommel: A revolving buddle or sieve for separating, or sizing, ores.
thaler: A former German silver coin worth about three shillings sterling, or about 73 cents, around 1900.
Text: To write in large characters, as in text hand.
Tranter: One who trants; a peddler; a carrier.
Tin: To cover with tin or tinned iron, or to overlay with tin foil.
Trumpetweed: An herbaceous composite plant (Eupatorium purpureum), often having hollow stems, and bearing purplish flowers in small corymbed heads.
Telestic: Tending or relating to a purpose or an end.
Telethermograph: A record of fluctuations of temperature made automatically at a distant station.
Tremando: Trembling; -- used as a direction to perform a passage with a general shaking of the whole chord.
Trichiuroid: Of, like, or pertaining to, Trichiurus.
Thoroughstitch: So as to go the whole length of any business; fully; completely.
Trifle: To make of no importance; to treat as a trifle.
Twinter: A domestic animal two winters old.
Trillion: According to the French notation, which is used upon the Continent generally and in the United States, the number expressed by a unit with twelve ciphers annexed; a million millions; according to the English notation, the number produced by involving a million to the third power, or the number represented by a unit with eighteen ciphers annexed. See the Note under Numeration.
Titularity: The quality or state of being titular.
Trirhomboidal: Having three rhombic faces or sides.
Teenager: a person whose age is in the teens, i.e. one between the ages of 13 to 19 inclusive.
Tenacity: The quality or state of being tenacious; as, tenacity, or retentiveness, of memory; tenacity, or persistency, of purpose.
Trumpet-shaped: Tubular with one end dilated, as the flower of the trumpet creeper.
Tiebar: A flat bar used as a tie.
Tig: A game among children. See Tag.
Transcendentality: The quality or state of being transcendental.
Trochlear: Shaped like, or resembling, a pulley; pertaining to, or connected with, a trochlea; as, a trochlear articular surface; the trochlear muscle of the eye.
Thysanura: An order of wingless hexapod insects which have setiform caudal appendages, either bent beneath the body to form a spring, or projecting as bristles. It comprises the Cinura, or bristletails, and the Collembola, or springtails. Called also Thysanoura. See Lepisma, and Podura.
Translocation: removal of things from one place to another; substitution of one thing for another.
Tic: A local and habitual convulsive motion of certain muscles; especially, such a motion of some of the muscles of the face; twitching; velication; -- called also spasmodic tic.
Triple-tail: An edible fish (Lobotes Surinamensis) found in the warmer parts of all the oceans, and common on the southern and middle coasts of the United States. When living it is silvery gray, and becomes brown or blackish when dead. Its dorsal and anal fins are long, and extend back on each side of the tail. It has large silvery scales which are used in the manufacture of fancy work. Called also, locally, black perch, grouper, and flasher.
Thionic: Of or pertaining to sulphur; containing or resembling sulphur; specifically, designating certain of the thio compounds; as, the thionic acids.  Cf. Dithionic, Trithionic, Tetrathionic, etc.
Trimaculated: Marked with three spots, or maculæ.
Tyranny: The government or authority of a tyrant; a country governed by an absolute ruler; hence, arbitrary or despotic exercise of power; exercise of power over subjects and others with a rigor not authorized by law or justice, or not requisite for the purposes of government.
Tuy\u00e8re: A nozzle, mouthpiece, or fixture through which the blast is delivered to the interior of a blast furnace, or to the fire of a forge.
Trichiurus: A genus of fishes comprising the hairtails. See Hairtail.
Toilinette: A cloth, the weft of which is of woolen yarn, and the warp of cotton and silk, -- used for waistcoats.
Tautologize: To repeat the same thing in different words.
Theatin: One of an order of Italian monks, established in 1524, expressly to oppose Reformation, and to raise the tone of piety among Roman Catholics. They hold no property, nor do they beg, but depend on what Providence sends. Their chief employment is preaching and giving religious instruction.
thanatopsis: A view of death; a meditation on the subject of death.
Thalamic: Of or pertaining to a thalamus or to thalami.
Tangent wheel: A worm or worm wheel; a tangent screw.
Tantalism: A punishment like that of Tantalus; a teasing or tormenting by the hope or near approach of good which is not attainable; tantalization.
Tanglefish: The sea adder, or great pipefish of Europe.
Tellurium: A rare nonmetallic element, analogous to sulphur and selenium, occasionally found native as a substance of a silver-white metallic luster, but usually combined with metals, as with gold and silver in the mineral sylvanite, with mercury in Coloradoite, etc. Symbol Te. Atomic weight 125.2.
Tingid: Of or pertaining to the genus Tingis.
Tractate: A treatise; a tract; an essay.
Tool-rest: the part that supports a tool-post or a tool.
Tetrarchical: Of or pertaining to a tetrarch or tetrarchy.
Terminational: Of or pertaining to termination; forming a termination.
Toddy: A juice drawn from various kinds of palms in the East Indies; or, a spirituous liquor procured from it by fermentation.
Tuch: A dark-colored kind of marble; touchstone.
Trek: The act of trekking; a drawing or a traveling; a journey; a migration.
Thiophenol: A colorless mobile liquid, C6H5.SH, of an offensive odor, and analogous to phenol; -- called also phenyl sulphydrate.
Transcalent: Pervious to, or permitting the passage of, heat.
Tutorage: The office or occupation of a tutor; tutorship; guardianship.
Tornado: A violent whirling wind; specifically (Meteorol.), a tempest distinguished by a rapid whirling and slow progressive motion, usually accompaned with severe thunder, lightning, and torrents of rain, and commonly of short duration and small breadth; a small cyclone.
Trionyx: A genus of fresh-water or river turtles which have the shell imperfectly developed and covered with a soft leathery skin.  They are noted for their agility and rapacity.  Called also soft tortoise, soft-shell tortoise, and mud turtle.
Tared: Weighed; determined; reduced to equal or standard weight; as, tared filter papers, used in weighing precipitates.
Truss: To bind or pack close; to tie up tightly; to make into a truss.
Territoriality: a pattern of behavior characterized by the marking and defense of a home territory, exhibited by certain male animals.
Thyrotomy: The operation of cutting into the thyroid cartilage.
Transflux: A flowing through, across, or beyond.
Tubulure: A short tubular opening at the top of a retort, or at the top or side of a bottle; a tubulation.
Thermic: Of or pertaining to heat; due to heat; thermal; as, thermic lines.
Theroid: Resembling a beast in nature or habit; marked by animal characteristics; as, theroid idiocy.
Tolu: A fragrant balsam said to have been first brought from Santiago de Tolu, in New Granada. See Balsam of Tolu, under Balsam.
Tolt: A writ by which a cause pending in a court baron was removed into a country court.
Tachometer: An instrument for measuring the velocity, or indicating changes in the velocity, of a moving body or substance.
Tantamount: To be tantamount or equivalent; to amount.
Tipsily: In a tipsy manner; like one tipsy.
Tarsotomy: The operation of cutting or removing the tarsal cartilages.
Tola: A weight of British India. The standard tola is equal to 180 grains.
Titleless: Not having a title or name; without legitimate title.
Testicle: One of the essential male genital glands which secrete the semen.
Tole: To draw, or cause to follow, by displaying something pleasing or desirable; to allure by some bait.
Tamping: The act of one who tamps; specifically, the act of filling up a hole in a rock, or the branch of a mine, for the purpose of blasting the rock or exploding the mine.
Tahitian: Of or pertaining to Tahiti, an island in the Pacific Ocean.
Telega: A rude four-wheeled, springless wagon, used among the Russians.
Toluric: Of, pertaining to, or designating, any one of three isomeric crystalline acids, C9H10ON.CO2H, which are toluyl derivatives of glycocoll.
Traversing: Adjustable laterally; having a lateral motion, or a swinging motion; adapted for giving lateral motion.
Tullibee: A whitefish (Coregonus tullibee) found in the Great Lakes of North America; -- called also mongrel whitefish.
Tanistry: In Ireland, a tenure of family lands by which the proprietor had only a life estate, to which he was admitted by election.
Tulip-eared: Having erect, pointed ears; prick-eared; -- said of certain dogs.
Transfund: To pour from one vessel into another; to transfuse.
Tractation: Treatment or handling of a subject; discussion.
Tome: As many writings as are bound in a volume, forming part of a larger work; a book; -- usually applied to a ponderous volume.
Tinker: To busy one's self in mending old kettles, pans, etc.; to play the tinker; to be occupied with small mechanical works.
Tense: Stretched tightly; strained to stiffness; rigid; not lax; as, a tense fiber.
Thrombin: The enzyme which converts fibrinogen into fibrin.
Terebilenic: Of, pertaining to, or designating, a complex acid, C7H8O4, obtained as a white crystalline substance by a modified oxidation of terebic acid.
Three-handed: Said of games or contests where three persons play against each other, or two against one; as, a three-handed game of cards.
Toilsome: Attended with toil, or fatigue and pain; laborious; wearisome; as, toilsome work.
Thearchy: Government by God; divine sovereignty; theocracy.
Theorica: Public moneys expended at Athens on festivals, sacrifices, and public entertainments (especially theatrical performances), and in gifts to the people; -- also called theoric fund.
Thrombosis: The obstruction of a blood vessel by a clot formed at the site of obstruction; -- distinguished from embolism, which is produced by a clot or foreign body brought from a distance.
Tical: A bean-shaped coin of Siam, worth about sixty cents; also, a weight equal to 236 grains troy.
Triaconter: A vessel with thirty banks of oars, or, as some say, thirty ranks of rowers.
Transdialect: To change or translate from one dialect into another.
Trisyllabic: Of or pertaining to a trisyllable; consisting of three syllables; as, “syllable” is a trisyllabic word.
Teleostomi: An extensive division of fishes including the ordinary fishes (Teleostei) and the ganoids.
Trapezoid: Having the form of a trapezoid; trapezoidal; as, the  trapezoid ligament  which connects the coracoid process and the clavicle.
Trass: A white to gray volcanic tufa, formed of decomposed trachytic cinders; -- sometimes used as a cement. Hence, a coarse sort of plaster or mortar, durable in water, and used to line cisterns and other reservoirs of water.
Thunderworm: A small, footless, burrowing, snakelike lizard (Rhineura Floridana) allied to Amphisbæna, native of Florida; -- so called because it leaves its burrows after a thundershower.
Twelvepence: A shilling sterling, being about twenty-four cents.
Turritelloid: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, the turritellas.
Tress: A braid, knot, or curl, of hair; a ringlet.
Textury: The art or process of weaving; texture.
Tetanization: The production or condition of tetanus.
Turner: A person who practices athletic or gymnastic exercises.
Twit: To vex by bringing to notice, or reminding of, a fault, defect, misfortune, or the like; to revile; to reproach; to upbraid; to taunt; as, he twitted his friend of falsehood.
Tepid: Moderately warm; lukewarm; as, a tepid bath; tepid rays; tepid vapors.
Tourmaline: A mineral occurring usually in three-sided or six-sided prisms terminated by rhombohedral or scalenohedral planes. Black tourmaline (schorl) is the most common variety, but there are also other varieties, as the blue (indicolite), red (rubellite), also green, brown, and white. The red and green varieties when transparent are valued as jewels.
Toothbill: A peculiar fruit-eating ground pigeon (Didunculus strigiostris) native of the Samoan Islands, and noted for its resemblance, in several characteristics, to the extinct dodo. Its beak is stout and strongly hooked, and the mandible has two or three strong teeth toward the end.  Its color is chocolate red. Called also toothbilled pigeon, and manu-mea.
Thomsonite: A zeolitic mineral, occurring generally in masses of a radiated structure. It is a hydrous silicate of aluminia, lime, and soda. Called also mesole, and comptonite.
Tantalization: The act of tantalizing, or state of being tantalized.
Tiara: A form of headdress worn by the ancient Persians. According to Xenophon, the royal tiara was encircled with a diadem, and was high and erect, while those of the people were flexible, or had rims turned over.
Trimethylene: A gaseous hydrocarbon, C3H6, isomeric with propylene and obtained from it indirectly. It is the base of a series of compounds analogous to the aromatic hydrocarbons.
Telemechanic: Designating, or pert. to, any device for operating mechanisms at a distance.
Tournois: A former French money of account worth 20 sous, or a franc. It was thus called in distinction from the Paris livre, which contained 25 sous.
Treasury: A place or building in which stores of wealth are deposited; especially, a place where public revenues are deposited and kept, and where money is disbursed to defray the expenses of government; hence, also, the place of deposit and disbursement of any collected funds.
Trencher: One who trenches; esp., one who cuts or digs ditches.
Tarsia: A kind of mosaic in woodwork, much employed in Italy in the fifteenth century and later, in which scrolls and arabesques, and sometimes architectural scenes, landscapes, fruits, flowers, and the like, were produced by inlaying pieces of wood of different colors and shades into panels usually of walnut wood.
Tile: To cover with tiles; as, to tile a house.
Trifasciated: Having, or surrounded by, three fasciæ, or bands.
Tattersalls: A famous horse market in London, established in 1766 by Richard Tattersall, also used as the headquarters of credit betting on English horse races; hence, a large horse market elsewhere.
Typo: a typographical error; an error in typing, printing, etc.
Tridecatylene: A hydrocarbon, C13H26, of the ethylene series, corresponding to tridecane, and obtained from Burmah petroleum as a light colorless liquid; -- called also tridecylene, and tridecene.
thaumaturgic: Of or pertaining to thaumaturgy; magical; wonderful.
Trochometer: A contrivance for computing the revolutions of a wheel; an odometer.
Ten-pounder: A large oceanic fish (Elops saurus) found in the tropical parts of all the oceans. It is used chiefly for bait.
Tramontana: A dry, cold, violent, northerly wind of the Adriatic.
Type: To represent by a type, model, or symbol beforehand; to prefigure.
Thalamifloral: Bearing the stamens directly on the receptacle; -- said of a subclass of polypetalous dicotyledonous plants in the system of De Candolle.
Tibia: The inner, or preaxial, and usually the larger, of the two bones of the leg or hind limb below the knee.
Tenuirostres: An artificial group of passerine birds having slender bills, as the humming birds.
Trioctile: An aspect of two planets with regard to the earth when they are three octants, or three eighths of a circle, that is, 135 degrees, distant from each other.
Techniphone: A dumb gymnastic apparatus for  training the hands of pianists and organists, as to a legato touch.
Typothet\u00e6: Printers; -- used in the name of an association of the master printers of the United States and Canada, called The United Typothetæ of America.
Transmission: The act of transmitting, or the state of being transmitted; as, the transmission of letters, writings, papers, news, and the like, from one country to another; the transmission of rights, titles, or privileges, from father to son, or from one generation to another.
Tungusic: Of or pertaining to the Tunguses; as, the Tungusic dialects.
Time policy: A policy limited to become void at a specified time; -- often contrasted with voyage policy.
Top-chain: A chain for slinging the lower yards, in time of action, to prevent their falling, if the ropes by which they are hung are shot away.
Tubulipore: Any one of numerous species of Bryozoa belonging to Tubulipora and allied genera, having tubular calcareous calicles.
Toluic: Pertaining to, or designating, one of three metameric acids, CH3.C6H4.CO2H, which are related to toluene and analogous to benzoic acids. They are white crystalline substances, and are called respectively orthotoluic acid, metatoluic acid, and paratoluic acid.
Transaction: The doing or performing of any business; management of any affair; performance.
Taurocol: Glue made from a bull's hide.
Trumplike: Resembling a trumpet, esp. in sound; as, a trumplike voice.
Trawlboat: A boat used in fishing with trawls or trawlnets.
Tradeful: Full of trade; busy in traffic; commercial.
Torvous: Sour of aspect; of a severe countenance; stern; grim.
Trysail: A fore-and-aft sail, bent to a gaff, and hoisted on a lower mast or on a small mast, called the trysail mast, close abaft a lower mast; -- used chiefly as a storm sail. Called also spencer.
Taintworm: A destructive parasitic worm or insect larva.
Tallyman: One who keeps the tally, or marks the sticks.
Tegument: A cover or covering; an integument.
Thetical: Laid down; absolute or positive, as a law.
Trama: The loosely woven substance which lines the chambers within the gleba in certain Gasteromycetes.
Trunk engine: An engine having a trunk piston, as most internal combustion engines.
Tarlatan: A kind of thin, transparent muslin, used for dresses.
Tonsilotome: An instrument for removing the tonsils.
Toran: A gateway, commonly of wood, but sometimes of stone, consisting of two upright pillars carrying one to three transverse lintels. It is often minutely carved with symbolic sculpture, and serves as a monumental approach to a Buddhist temple.
Territorial waters: The waters under the territorial jurisdiction of a state; specif., the  belt (often called the marine belt or territorial sea) of sea subject to such jurisdiction, and subject only to the right of innocent passage by the vessels of other states.
trade-in: an item of property, such as an automobile, that is given in part payment for a new one.
Titanium: An elementary substance found combined in the minerals manaccanite, rutile, sphene, etc., and isolated as an infusible iron-gray amorphous powder, having a metallic luster. It burns when heated in the air. Symbol Ti. Atomic weight 48.1.
Tonsilotomy: The operation of removing the tonsils, or a portion thereof; -- called more commonly tonsillectomy.
Tilde: The accentual mark placed over n, and sometimes over l, in Spanish words [thus, ñ, &ltilde_;], indicating that, in pronunciation, the sound of the following vowel is to be preceded by that of the initial, or consonantal, y.
Thousandth: The quotient of a unit divided by a thousand; one of a thousand equal parts into which a unit is divided.
Trichinosis: The disease produced by the presence of trichinæ in the muscles and intestinal track. It is marked by fever, muscular pains, and symptoms resembling those of typhoid fever, and is frequently fatal.
Testone: A silver coin of Portugal, worth about sixpence sterling, or about eleven cents.
Tellership: The office or employment of a teller.
Tendriled: Furnished with tendrils, or with such or so many, tendrils.
Thoroughness: The quality or state of being thorough; completeness.
Tank top: a sleeveless and collarless shirt with wide shoulder straps and no front opening, often close-fitting and low-cut.
Trematodea: An extensive order of parasitic worms. They are found in the internal cavities of animals belonging to all classes. Many species are found, also, on the gills and skin of fishes. A few species are parasitic on man, and some, of which the fluke is the most important, are injurious parasites of domestic animals. The trematodes usually have a flattened body covered with a chitinous skin, and are furnished with two or more suckers for adhesion. Most of the species are hermaphrodite. Called also Trematoda, and Trematoidea. See Fluke, Tristoma, and Cercaria.
Triatic: A term used in the phrase triatic stay. See under Stay.
Thrilling: Causing a thrill; causing tremulous excitement; deeply moving; as, a thrilling romance.
Taut: Tight; stretched; not slack; -- said esp. of a rope that is tightly strained.
Tupman: A man who breeds, or deals in tups.
Tritovum: An embryonic insect which has twice cast its skin previous to hatching from the egg.
Tinkering: The act or work of a tinker.
Tarpaulin: A piece of canvas covered with tar or a waterproof composition, used for covering the hatches of a ship, hammocks, boats, etc.
Tightly: In a tight manner; closely; nearly.
Truculence: The quality or state of being truculent; savageness of manners; ferociousness.
Talipes: The deformity called clubfoot. See Clubfoot.
Tensible: Capable of being extended or drawn out; ductile; tensible.
Tawny: Of a dull yellowish brown color, like things tanned, or persons who are sunburnt; as, tawny Moor or Spaniard; the tawny lion.
Thermogenic: Relating to heat, or to the production of heat; producing heat; thermogenous; as, the thermogenic tissues.
Tasteless: Having no taste; insipid; flat; as, tasteless fruit.
Taunt: Upbraiding language; bitter or sarcastic reproach; insulting invective.
Tantra: A ceremonial treatise related to Puranic and magic literature; esp., one of the sacred works of the worshipers of Sakti.
Transmarine: Lying or being beyond the sea.
Tetragynian: Belonging to the order Tetragynia; having four styles.
Toothdrawer: One whose business it is to extract teeth with instruments; a dentist.
Tracer: One who, or that which, traces.
Tropism: Modification of the direction of growth, caused by some external influence, such as light; -- sometimes used for motion of an organism toward or away from an external stimulus, more properly called taxis.
Tintinnabulous: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, the tinkling of a bell; having a tinkling sound; tintinnabular.
Tetralogy: A group or series of four dramatic pieces, three tragedies and one satyric, or comic, piece (or sometimes four tragedies), represented consequently on the Attic stage at the Dionysiac festival.
Triverbial: Pertaining to, or designating, certain days allowed to the pretor for hearing causes, when be might speak the three characteristic words of his office, do, dico, addico. They were called dies fasti.
Taxgatherer: One who collects taxes or revenues.
Triableness: Quality or state of being triable.
Tinto: A red Madeira wine, wanting the high aroma of the white sorts, and, when old, resembling tawny port.
Tripe-de-roche: Same as Rock tripe, under Rock.
Tut-mouthed: Having a projecting under jaw; prognathous.
Tauricornous: Having horns like those of a bull.
Tubivalve: A shell or tube formed by an annelid, as a serpula.
Tripodian: An ancient stringed instrument; -- so called because, in form, it resembled the Delphic tripod.
Trifolium: A genus of leguminous herbs with densely spiked flowers and usually trifoliate leaves; trefoil. There are many species, all of which are called clover. See Clover.
Troglodyte: One of any savage race that dwells in caves, instead of constructing dwellings; a cave dweller, or cave man. Most of the primitive races of man were troglodytes.
Transalpine: A native or inhabitant of a country beyond the Alps, that is, out of Italy.
Transitive: Having the power of making a transit, or passage.
Taurocholic: Pertaining to, or designating, a conjugate acid (called taurocholic acid) composed of taurine and cholic acid, present abundantly in human bile and in that of carnivora. It is exceedingly deliquescent, and hence appears generally as a thick, gummy mass, easily soluble in water and alcohol. It has a bitter taste.
Telepolariscope: A polariscope arranged to be attached to a telescope.
Trumpet-tongued: Having a powerful, far-reaching voice or speech.
Turret deck: A narrow superstructure running from stem to stern on the upper deck of a steam cargo vessel having a rounded gunwale and sides curved inward convexly.
Tenon: To cut or fit for insertion into a mortise, as the end of a piece of timber.
Tessera: A small piece of marble, glass, earthenware, or the like, having a square, or nearly square, face, used by the ancients for mosaic, as for making pavements, for ornamenting walls, and like purposes; also, a similar piece of ivory, bone, wood, etc., used as a ticket of admission to theaters, or as a certificate for successful gladiators, and as a token for various other purposes.
Thermogram: The trace or record made by means of a thermograph.
Teaseling: The cutting and gathering of teasels; the use of teasels.
Tracker: One who, or that which, tracks or pursues, as a man or dog that follows game.
Tranquilization: The act of tranquilizing, or the state of being tranquilized.
Thenardite: Anhydrous sodium sulphate, a mineral of a white or brown color and vitreous luster.
Tenor: A state of holding on in a continuous course; manner of continuity; constant mode; general tendency; course; career.
Trochaic: Of or pertaining to trochees; consisting of trochees; as, trochaic measure or verse.
Trispast: A machine with three pulleys which act together for raising great weights.
Tongue-tie: To deprive of speech or the power of speech, or of distinct articulation.
Trophy: A sign or memorial of a victory raised on the field of battle, or, in case of a naval victory, on the nearest land. Sometimes trophies were erected in the chief city of the conquered people.
Traipse: To walk or run about in a slatternly, careless, or thoughtless manner.
Tricot: A fabric of woolen, silk, or cotton knitted, or women to resemble knitted work.
Theomachist: One who fights against the gods; one who resists God of the divine will.
Tres-tine: The third tine above the base of a stag's antler; the royal antler.
Trimester: A term or period of three months.
Thickening: Something put into a liquid or mass to make it thicker.
Tilt-mill: A mill where a tilt hammer is used, or where the process of tilting is carried on.
Tubulibranchiata: A group of gastropod mollusks having a tubular shell. Vermetus is an example.
Tristoma: Any one of numerous species of trematode worms belonging to Tristoma and allied genera having a large posterior sucker and two small anterior ones. They usually have broad, thin, and disklike bodies, and are parasite on the gills and skin of fishes.
Trioxide: An oxide containing three atoms of oxygen; as, sulphur trioxide, SO3; -- formerly called tritoxide.
Tricoccous: Having three cocci, or roundish carpels.
Teutonicism: A mode of speech peculiar to the Teutons; a Teutonic idiom, phrase, or expression; a Teutonic mode or custom; a Germanism.
Turko: One of a body of native Algerian tirailleurs in the French army, dressed as a Turk.
Them: The objective case of they. See They.
Talmudism: The teachings of the Talmud, or adherence to them.
Thee: The objective case of thou. See Thou.
Tilt-yard: A yard or place for tilting.
Thanatopsis: The title of a poem by William Cullen Bryant (1794-1878), meditating on the subject of death.  One of Bryant's best-remembered poems, it was written in 1811 and was discovered and rushed to publication in 1817 (in the North American Review) by Bryant's father, originally without the poet's knowledge.  A revised version was published in 1821.  In this elegy Bryant reflects that death comes to all men, common and great, and that all eventually shall rest together in the "mighty sepulchre" of the earth.
Thea: A genus of plants found in China and Japan; the tea plant.
Thimbleberry: A kind of black raspberry (Rubus occidentalis), common in America.
Tanak: a term used among Jews for the Hebrew Bible; the Old Testament.
Trans-: A prefix, signifying over, beyond, through and through, on the other side, as in transalpine, beyond the Alps; transform, to form through and through, that is, anew, transfigure.
Typesetter: One who, or that which, sets type; a compositor; a machine for setting type.
Toadyism: The practice of meanly fawning on another; base sycophancy; servile adulation.
They: The plural of he, she, or it. They is never used adjectively, but always as a pronoun proper, and sometimes refers to persons without an antecedent expressed.
Thew: Manner; custom; habit; form of behavior; qualities of mind; disposition; specifically, good qualities; virtues.
Talus: A slope; the inclination of the face of a work.
Tropology: A rhetorical mode of speech, including tropes, or changes from the original import of the word.
Trader: One engaged in trade or commerce; one who makes a business of buying and selling or of barter; a merchant; a trafficker; as, a trader to the East Indies; a country trader.
Thrum: To play, as a stringed instrument, in a rude or monotonous manner.
Triable: Fit or possible to be tried; liable to be subjected to trial or test.
Tiredness: The state of being tired, or weary.
Terebratuliform: Having the general form of a terebratula shell.
Trappean: Of or pertaining to trap; being of the nature of trap.
Transparence: The quality or state of being transparent; transparency.
Trotter: One that trots; especially, a horse trained to be driven in trotting matches.
Tax certificate: The certificate issued to the purchaser of land at a tax sale certifying to the sale and the payment of the consideration thereof, and entitling the purchaser upon certain conditions and at a certain time thereafter to a deed or instrument of conveyance (called a tax deed) of the land, to be executed by the proper officer.
Thomism: The doctrine of Thomas Aquinas, esp. with respect to predestination and grace.
T connection: The connection of two coils diagrammatically as a letter T, chiefly used as a connection for passing transformers. When the three free ends are connected to a source of three-phase current, two-phase current may be derived from the secondary circuits. The reverse arrangement may be used to transform from two-phase.
Tenderness: The quality or state of being tender (in any sense of the adjective).
Triblet: A goldsmith's tool used in making rings.
Teagle: A hoisting apparatus; an elevator; a crane; a lift.
Thomist: A follower of Thomas Aquinas. See Scotist.
Tomb: To place in a tomb; to bury; to inter; to entomb.
Trackmaster: One who has charge of the track; -- called also roadmaster.
Tanier: An aroid plant (Caladium sagittæfolium), the leaves of which are boiled and eaten in the West Indies.
Transprint: To transfer to the wrong place in printing; to print out of place.
Trophi: The mouth parts of an insect, collectively, including the labrum, labium, maxillæ, mandibles, and lingua, with their appendages.
Trilocular: Having three cells or cavities; as, a trilocular capsule; a trilocular heart.
Tumbleweed: Any plant which habitually breaks away from its roots in the autumn, and is driven by the wind, as a light, rolling mass, over the fields and prairies; such as witch grass, wild indigo, Amarantus albus, etc.
Tuille: In plate armor, a suspended plate in from of the thigh. See Illust. of Tasses.
Tironian: Of or pertaining to Tiro, or a system of shorthand said to have been introduced by him into ancient Rome.
Tube railway: an electrically powered railroad with tracks running through a tunnel underground; a subway.
Transfixion: The act of transfixing, or the state of being transfixed, or pierced.
Thick-skulled: Having a thick skull; hence, dull; heavy; stupid; slow to learn.
Transcendence: The quality or state of being transcendent; superior excellence; supereminence.
Triskelion: A figure composed of three branches, usually curved, radiating from a center, as the figure composed of three human legs, with bent knees, which has long been used as a badge or symbol of Sicily and of the Isle of Man.
Telegraphist: One skilled in telegraphy; a telegrapher.
Thirteen: The number greater by one than twelve; the sum of ten and three; thirteen units or objects.
Terebinthic: Of or pertaining to turpentine; resembling turpentine; terbinthine; as, terbinthic qualities.
Threepence: A small silver coin of three times the value of a penny.
Trigamy: The act of marrying, or the state of being married, three times; also, the offense of having three husbands or three wives at the same time.
Tiling: A surface covered with tiles, or composed of tiles.
Tutti-frutti: A confection of different kinds of preserved fruits.
Tamability: The quality or state of being tamable; tamableness.
Turn-buckle: A loop or sleeve with a screw thread at one end and a swivel at the other, -- used for tightening a rod, stay, etc.
Tanystomata: A division of dipterous insects in which the proboscis is large and contains lancelike mandibles and maxillæ. The horseflies and robber flies are examples.
Tunnel stern: A design of motor-boat stern, for  use in shallow waters, in which the propeller is housed in a tunnel and does not extend below the greatest draft.
Tremella: A genus of gelatinous fungi found in moist grounds.
Turrilite: Any fossil ammonite of the genus Turrilites. The shell forms an open spiral with the later whorls separate.
Tapper: The lesser spotted woodpecker (Dendrocopus minor); -- called also tapperer, tabberer, little wood pie, barred woodpecker, wood tapper, hickwall, and pump borer.
Troppo: Too much; as, allegro ma non troppo, brisk but not too much so.
Tappet: A lever or projection moved by some other piece, as a cam, or intended to tap or touch something else, with a view to produce change or regulate motion.
Toadflax: An herb (Linaria vulgaris) of the Figwort family, having narrow leaves and showy orange and yellow flowers; -- called also butter and eggs, flaxweed, and ramsted.
Triple-crowned: Having three crowns; wearing the triple crown, as the pope.
Tetradic: Of or pertaining to a tetrad; possessing or having the characteristics of a tetrad; as, a carbon is a tetradic element.
Trigness: The quality or state of being trig; smartness; neatness.
Tillage: The operation, practice, or art of tilling or preparing land for seed, and keeping the ground in a proper state for the growth of crops.
Telestereoscope: A stereoscope adapted to view distant natural objects or landscapes; a telescopic stereoscope.
Taker: One who takes or receives; one who catches or apprehends.
Toe drop: A morbid condition of the foot in which the toe is depressed and the heel elevated.
Torril: A worthless woman; also, a worthless horse.
Tenacious: Holding fast, or inclined to hold fast; inclined to retain what is in possession; as, men tenacious of their just rights.
Theodicy: A vindication of the justice of God in ordaining or permitting natural and moral evil.
Tenebrosity: The quality or state of being tenebrous; tenebrousness.
Thermometric: Of or pertaining to a thermometer; as, the thermometrical scale or tube.
Tubby: Resembling a tub; specifically sounding dull and without resonance, like a tub; wanting elasticity or freedom of sound; as, a tubby violin.
Toshred: To cut into shreds or pieces.
Tarrier: A kind of dig; a terrier.
Trivalve: Anything having three valves, especially a shell.
Translator: One who translates; esp., one who renders into another language; one who expresses the sense of words in one language by equivalent words in another.
Traitress: A woman who betrays her country or any trust; a traitoress.
Trier: One who tries; one who makes experiments; one who examines anything by a test or standard.
Torpedo body: An automobile body which is built so that the side surfaces are flush.
Tinned: Covered, or plated, with tin; as, a tinned roof; tinned iron.
Tautological: Involving tautology; having the same signification; as, tautological expression.
Triangularly: In a triangular manner; in the form of a triangle.
Taconic: Designating, or pertaining to, the series of rocks forming the Taconic mountains in Western New England. They were once supposed to be older than the Cambrian, but later proved to belong to the Lower Silurian and Cambrian.
Tralineate: To deviate; to stray; to wander.
Toothbrush: A brush for cleaning the teeth.
Tikor: A starch or arrow-root made from the tubes of an East Indian zinziberaceous plant (Curcuma angustifolia); also, the plant itself.
Tentwort: A kind of small fern, the wall rue. See under Wall.
Thievery: The practice of stealing; theft; thievishness.
Tempting: Adapted to entice or allure; attractive; alluring; seductive; enticing; as, tempting pleasures.
Tungstic: Of or pertaining to tungsten; derived from, or resembling, tungsten; wolframic; as, tungstic oxide.
Thio-: A combining form (also used adjectively) denoting the presence of sulphur. See Sulpho-.
Tracheobronchial: Pertaining both to the tracheal and bronchial tubes, or to their junction; -- said of the syrinx of certain birds.
Traiteur: The keeper of an eating house, or restaurant; a restaurateur.
Tryster: One who makes an appointment, or tryst; one who meets with another.
Two-throw: Capable of being thrown or cranked in two directions, usually opposite to one another; as, a two-throw crank; a two-throw switch.
Teaseler: One who uses teasels for raising a nap on cloth.
Talook: A large estate; esp., one constituting a revenue district or dependency the native proprietor of which is responsible for the collection and payment of the public revenue due from it.
Tarsorrhaphy: An operation to diminish the size of the opening between eyelids when enlarged by surrounding cicatrices.
Trigesimo-secundo: A book composed of sheets so folded that each one makes thirty-two leaves; hence, indicating, more or less definitely, a size of book; -- usually written 32mo, or 32°, and called thirty-twomo.
Teleost: One of the Teleosti. Also used adjectively.
Thornless: Destitute of, or free from, thorns.
Trimembral: Having, or consisting of, three members.
Taxpayer: One who is assessed and pays a tax.
Tetrahedron: A solid figure inclosed or bounded by four triangles.
Thraldom: The condition of a thrall; slavery; bondage; state of servitude.
Textile: That which is, or may be, woven; a fabric made by weaving.
Trammeled: Having blazes, or white marks, on the fore and hind foot of one side, as if marked by trammels; -- said of a horse.
Tadpole: The young aquatic larva of any amphibian. In this stage it breathes by means of external or internal gills, is at first destitute of legs, and has a finlike tail. Called also polliwig, polliwog, porwiggle, or purwiggy.
Temporomalar: Of or pertaining to both the temple and the region of the malar bone; as, the temporomalar nerve.
Treasuress: A woman who is a treasurer.
Throstling: A disease of bovine cattle, consisting of a swelling under the throat, which, unless checked, causes strangulation.
Tabellion: A secretary or notary under the Roman empire; also, a similar officer in France during the old monarchy.
Tetrandria: A Linnæan class of plants having four stamens.
Tension: The act of stretching or straining; the state of being stretched or strained to stiffness; the state of being bent strained; as, the tension of the muscles, tension of the larynx.
Turban-shell: A sea urchin when deprived of its spines; -- popularly so called from a fancied resemblance to a turban.
Thermopile: An instrument of extreme sensibility, used to determine slight differences and degrees of heat. It is composed of alternate bars of antimony and bismuth, or any two metals having different capacities for the conduction of heat, connected with an astatic galvanometer, which is very sensibly affected by the electric current induced in the system of bars when exposed even to the feeblest degrees of heat.
Toon: The reddish brown wood of an East Indian tree (Cedrela Toona) closely resembling the Spanish cedar; also. the tree itself.
Thermodynamic: Relating to thermodynamics; caused or operated by force due to the application of heat.
Tool: To travel in a vehicle; to ride or drive.
Tergiversate: To shift; to practice evasion; to use subterfuges; to shuffle.
Thatch: To cover with, or with a roof of, straw, reeds, or some similar substance; as, to thatch a roof, a stable, or a stack of grain.
Toot: To cause to sound, as a horn, the note being modified at the beginning and end as if by pronouncing the letter t; to blow; to sound.
Trickish: Given to tricks; artful in making bargains; given to deception and cheating; knavish.
Tarantism: A nervous affection producing melancholy, stupor, and an uncontrollable desire to dance. It was supposed to be produced by the bite of the tarantula, and considered to be incapable of cure except by protracted dancing to appropriate music.
Tarsale: One of the bones or cartilages of the tarsus; esp., one of the series articulating with the metatarsals.
Terrier: One of a breed of small dogs, which includes several distinct subbreeds, some of which, such as the Skye terrier and Yorkshire terrier, have long hair and drooping ears, while others, at the English and the black-and-tan terriers, have short, close, smooth hair and upright ears.
Tasse: A piece of armor for the thighs, forming an appendage to the ancient corselet.
Trocha: A line of fortifications, usually rough, constructed to prevent the passage of an enemy across a region.
Taiping: Pertaining to or designating a dynasty with which one Hung-Siu-Chuen, a half-religious, half-political enthusiast, attempted to supplant the Manchu dynasty by the Taiping rebellion, incited by him in 1850 and suppressed by General Gordon about 1864.
Testudineous: Resembling the shell of a tortoise.
Tody: Any one of several species of small insectivorous West Indian birds of the genus Todus. They are allied to the kingfishers.
Thwack: A heavy blow with something flat or heavy; a thump.
Tunnel: To make a tunnel; as, to tunnel under a river.
Tribal: Of or pertaining to a tribe or tribes; as, a tribal scepter.
Terricol\u00e6: A division of annelids including the common earthworms and allied species.
Tree: To drive to a tree; to cause to ascend a tree; as, a dog trees a squirrel.
Turtlehead: An American perennial herb (Chelone glabra) having white flowers shaped like the head of a turtle. Called also snakehead, shell flower, and balmony.
Tref: Ceremonially unclean, according to the Jewish law; -- opposed to kosher.
Trey: Three, at cards, dice, or dominoes; a card, die, or domino of three spots or pips.
Tabetic: Of or pertaining to tabes; of the nature of tabes; affected with tabes; tabid.
Toxicant: A poisonous agent or drug, as opium; an intoxicant.
Tret: An allowance to purchasers, for waste or refuse matter, of four pounds on every 104 pounds of suttle weight, or weight after the tare deducted.
Toothwort: A plant whose roots are fancied to resemble teeth, as certain plants of the genus Lathræa, and various species of Dentaria. See Coralwort.
Toweling: Cloth for towels, especially such as is woven in long pieces to be cut at will, as distinguished from that woven in towel lengths with borders, etc.
Trigrammatic: Containing three letters or characters, or three sets of letters or characters.
Tschego: A West African anthropoid ape allied to the gorilla and chimpanzee, and by some considered only a variety of the chimpanzee. It is noted for building large, umbrella-shaped nests in trees. Called also tscheigo, tschiego, nschego, nscheigo.
Theophanic: Of or pertaining to a theopany; appearing to man, as a god.
Tittup: The act of tittuping; lively, gay, or restless behavior or gait; a prance or caper.
Toltec: One of a race which formerly occupied Mexico.
Trestlework: A viaduct, pier, scaffold, or the like, resting on trestles connected together.
Tracheary: Tracheal; breathing by means of tracheæ.
Tartarous: Resembling, or characteristic of, a Tartar; ill-natured; irritable.
Tableware: Ware, or articles collectively, for use during meals, including, for example, dishes, plates, bowls, knives, forks, and spoons.
Tachina: Any one of numerous species of Diptera belonging to Tachina and allied genera.  Their larvæ are external parasites of other insects.
Torpent: Having no motion or activity; incapable of motion; benumbed; torpid.
Turnsole: A plant of the genus Heliotropium; heliotrope; -- so named because its flowers are supposed to turn toward the sun.
Tenuity: The quality or state of being tenuous; thinness, applied to a broad substance; slenderness, applied to anything that is long; as, the tenuity of a leaf; the tenuity of a hair.
Tennysonian: Of or pertaining to Alfred (Lord) Tennyson, the English poet (1809-92); resembling, or having some of the characteristics of, his poetry, as simplicity, pictorial quality, sensuousness, etc.
Termagant: Tumultuous; turbulent; boisterous; furious; quarrelsome; scolding.
tough: A person who is tough{7}; a ruffian; a thug; as, a cluster of neighborhood toughs hanging out on the corner.
Trona: A native double salt, consisting of a combination of neutral and acid sodium carbonate, Na2CO3.2HNaCO3.2H2O, occurring as a white crystalline fibrous deposit from certain soda brine springs and lakes; -- called also urao, and by the ancients nitrum.
Torilto: A species of Turnix (Turnix sylvatica) native of Spain and Northen Africa.
Theophilosophic: Combining theism and philosophy, or pertaining to the combination of theism and philosophy.
Tetragrammaton: The mystic number four, which was often symbolized to represent the Deity, whose name was expressed by four letters among some ancient nations; as, the Hebrew JeHoVaH, Greek qeo`s, Latin deus, etc.
Tupian: Designating, or pertaining to, a linguistic stock of South American Indians comprising the most important Brazilian tribes.  Agriculture, pottery, and stone working were practiced by them at the time of the conquest.  The Tupi and the Guarani were originally the most powerful of the stock, which is hence also called Tupi-Guaranian.
Tormenter: One who, or that which, torments; a tormentor.
Triglyph: An ornament in the frieze of the Doric order, repeated at equal intervals. Each triglyph consists of a rectangular tablet, slightly projecting, and divided nearly to the top by two parallel and perpendicular gutters, or channels, called glyphs, into three parts, or spaces, called femora. A half channel, or glyph, is also cut upon each of the perpendicular edges of the tablet. See Illust. of Entablature.
Tewed: Fatigued; worn with labor or hardship.
Two-sided: Having two sides only; hence, double-faced; hypocritical.
Telegraph: To convey or announce by telegraph.
Tewel: A pipe, funnel, or chimney, as for smoke.
Temporizer: One who temporizes; one who yields to the time, or complies with the prevailing opinions, fashions, or occasions; a trimmer.
Thimbleful: As much as a thimble will hold; a very small quantity.
Thunderstrike: To strike, blast, or injure by, or as by, lightning.
Tined: Furnished with tines; as, a three-tined fork.
Tramrail: An overhead rail forming a track on which a trolley runs to convey a load, as in a shop.
Tenpins: A game resembling ninepins, but played with ten pins. See Ninepins.
Tinea: A name applied to various skin diseases, but especially to ringworm. See Ringworm, and Sycosis.
Tenno: Lit., King of Heaven; -- a title of the emperor of Japan as the head of the Shinto religion.
Toxotes: A genus of fishes comprising the archer fishes. See Archer fish.
Tandem engine: A steam engine having two or more steam cylinders in line, with a common piston rod.
Titivate: To dress or smarten up; to spruce.
Triviality: The quality or state of being trivial; trivialness.
Treckschuyt: A covered boat for goods and passengers, used on the Dutch and Flemish canals.
Tartro-: A combining form (also used adjectively) used in chemistry to denote the presence of tartar or of some of its compounds or derivatives.
Twinling: A young or little twin, especially a twin lamb.
Taction: The act of touching; touch; contact; tangency.
Thoria: A rare white earthy substance, consisting of the oxide of thorium; -- formerly called also thorina.
Tomato: The fruit of a plant of the Nightshade family (Lycopersicum esculentun); also, the plant itself. The fruit, which is called also love apple, is usually of a rounded, flattened form, but often irregular in shape. It is of a bright red or yellow color, and is eaten either cooked or uncooked.
Talented: Furnished with talents; possessing skill or talent; mentally gifted.
Transfretation: The act of passing over a strait or narrow sea.
Tarheel state: North Carolina; -- used as a nickname.
Trainband: A band or company of an organized military force instituted by James I. and dissolved by Charles II.; -- afterwards applied to the London militia.
Tearless: Shedding no tears; free from tears; unfeeling.
Tinkling: A tinkle, or succession of tinkles.
Trade-mark: A peculiar distinguishing mark or device affixed by a manufacturer or a merchant to his goods, the exclusive right of using which is recognized by law.
Twister: One who twists; specifically, the person whose occupation is to twist or join the threads of one warp to those of another, in weaving.
Turn-sick: A disease with which sheep are sometimes affected; gid; sturdy. See Gid.
Trivalence: The quality or state of being trivalent.
Tilia: A genus of trees, the lindens, the type of the family Tiliaceæ, distinguished by the winglike bract coalescent with the peduncle, and by the indehiscent fruit having one or two seeds. There are about twenty species, natives of temperate regions.  Many species are planted as ornamental shade trees, and the tough fibrous inner bark is a valuable article of commerce. Also, a plant of this genus.
Tragacanth: A kind of gum procured from a spiny leguminous shrub (Astragalus gummifer) of Western Asia, and other species of Astragalus. It comes in hard whitish or yellowish flakes or filaments, and is nearly insoluble in water, but slowly swells into a mucilaginous mass, which is used as a substitute for gum arabic in medicine and the arts. Called also gum tragacanth.
Taperness: The quality or state of being taper; tapering form; taper.
Terebrate: To perforate; to bore; to pierce.
Troglodytes: A genus of apes including the chimpanzee.
Thankworthy: Deserving thanks; worthy of gratitude; mreitorious.
Tragi-comi-pastoral: Partaking of the nature of, or combining, tragedy, comedy, and pastoral poetry.
Trant: To traffic in an itinerary manner; to peddle.
Toggle switch: an electrical switch operated by pushing a lever through a small angle of deflection.  The lever has a spring which returns it to its original position after the pressure applied by the operator is released.
Tetrapetalous: Containing four distinct petals, or flower leaves; as, a tetrapetalous corolla.
Torchlight: The light of a torch, or of torches.  Also adjectively; as, a torchlight procession.
Tephramancy: Divination by the ashes of the altar on which a victim had been consumed in sacrifice.
Turritella: Any spiral marine gastropod belonging to Turritella and allied genera. These mollusks have an elongated, turreted shell, composed of many whorls. They have a rounded aperture, and a horny multispiral operculum.
Triadic: Having the characteristics of a triad; as, boron is triadic.
Tournery: Work turned on a lathe; turnery.
Treadwheel: A wheel turned by persons or animals, by treading, climbing, or pushing with the feet, upon its periphery or face. See Treadmill.
Taborite: One of certain Bohemian reformers who suffered persecution in the fifteenth century; -- so called from Tabor, a hill or fortress where they encamped during a part of their struggles.
Tautog: An edible labroid fish (Haitula onitis, or Tautoga onitis) of the Atlantic coast of the United States. When adult it is nearly black, more or less irregularly barred, with greenish gray. Called also blackfish, oyster fish, salt-water chub, and moll.
Trichinoscope: An apparatus for the detection of trichinæ in the flesh of animals, as of swine.
Terrestrify: To convert or reduce into a condition like that of the earth; to make earthy.
Tetrodon: Any one of numerous species of plectognath fishes belonging to Tetrodon and allied genera. Each jaw is furnished with two large, thick, beaklike, bony teeth.
Tolylene: A hydrocarbon radical, C6H4.(CH2)2, regarded as characteristic of certain toluene derivatives.
Tumblerful: As much as a tumbler will hold; enough to fill a tumbler.
Tamarind: A leguminous tree (Tamarindus Indica) cultivated both the Indies, and the other tropical countries, for the sake of its shade, and for its fruit. The trunk of the tree is lofty and large, with wide-spreading branches; the flowers are in racemes at the ends of the branches. The leaves are small and finely pinnated.
Tremulous: Shaking; shivering; quivering; as, a tremulous limb; a tremulous motion of the hand or the lips; the tremulous leaf of the poplar.
Trefoil: Any plant of the genus Trifolium, which includes the white clover, red clover, etc.; -- less properly, applied also to the nonesuch, or black medic. See Clover, and Medic.
Translavation: A laving or lading from one vessel to another.
Thymate: A compound of thymol analogous to a salt; as, sodium thymate.
Twistical: Crooked; tortuous; hence, perverse; unfair; dishonest.
Thrall-like: Resembling a thrall, or his condition, feelings, or the like; slavish.
Telescope bag: An adjustable traveling bag consisting of two cases, the larger slipping over the other.
Tossing: The act of throwing upward; a rising and falling suddenly; a rolling and tumbling.
Trinket: To give trinkets; hence, to court favor; to intrigue.
Thomsonianism: An empirical system which assumes that the human body is composed of four elements, earth, air, fire, and water, and that vegetable medicines alone should be used; -- from the founder, Dr. Samuel Thomson, of Massachusetts.
Tribunal: In villages of the Philippine Islands, a kind of townhall. At the  tribunal the head men of the village met to transact business, prisoners were confined, and troops and travelers were often quartered.
Tyronism: The state of being a tyro, or beginner.
Thermocautery: Cautery by the application of heat.
Turban: A headdress worn by men in the Levant and by many Muslims of the male sex, consisting of a cap, and a sash, scarf, or shawl, usually of cotton or linen, wound about the cap, and sometimes hanging down the neck.
Tollhouse: A house occupied by a receiver of tolls.
Tourniquet: An instrument for arresting hemorrhage. It consists essentially of a pad or compress upon which pressure is made by a band which is tightened by a screw or other means.
Tortoise: Any one of numerous species of reptiles of the order Testudinata.
Twentieth: The next in order after the nineteenth; one coming after nineteen others.
Topping: The act of one who tops; the act of cutting off the top.
Tentful: As much, or as many, as a tent will hold.
Technography: Description of the arts and  crafts of tribes and peoples.
Topsoiling: The act or art of taking off the top soil of land before an excavation or embankment is begun.
Top fermentation: An alcoholic fermentation during which the yeast cells are carried to the top of the fermenting liquid. It proceeds with some violence and requires a temperature of 14-30° C. (58-86° F.). It is used in the production of ale, porter, etc., and of wines high in alcohol, and in distilling.
Tenn\u00e9: A tincture, rarely employed, which is considered as an orange color or bright brown. It is represented by diagonal lines from sinister to dexter, crossed by vertical lines.
Toucan: Any one of numerous species of fruit-eating birds of tropical America belonging to Ramphastos, Pteroglossus, and allied genera of the family Ramphastidæ.  They have a very large, but light and thin, beak, often nearly as long as the body itself.  Most of the species are brilliantly colored with red, yellow, white, and black in striking contrast.
Thunderhead: A rounded mass of cloud, with shining white edges; a cumulus, -- often appearing before a thunderstorm.
Telescopic sight: A sight consisting of a small telescope, as on a compass or rifle.
Triumph: To obtain a victory over; to prevail over; to conquer. Also, to cause to triumph.
Tribunate: The state or office of a tribune; tribuneship.
Triumphing: Having or celebrating a triumph; victorious; triumphant.
Tracheid: A wood cell with spiral or other markings and closed throughout, as in pine wood.
Turbinite: A petrified shell resembling a member of the genus Turbo.
Taper: To make or cause to taper.
Toothleted: Having a toothlet or toothlets; as, a toothleted leaf.
Turkey: Any large American gallinaceous bird belonging to the genus Meleagris, especially the North American wild turkey (Meleagris gallopavo), and the domestic turkey, which was probably derived from the Mexican wild turkey, but had been domesticated by the Indians long before the discovery of America.
Tympano-: A combining form used in anatomy to indicate connection with, or relation to, the tympanum; as in tympanohyal, tympano-Eustachian.
Thunderbird: An Australian insectivorous singing bird (Pachycephala gutturalis). The male is conspicuously marked with black and yellow, and has a black crescent on the breast. Called also white-throated thickhead, orange-breasted thrust, black-crowned thrush, guttural thrush, and black-breasted flycatcher.
Tump: To form a mass of earth or a hillock about; as, to tump teasel.
Totalness: The quality or state of being total; entireness; totality.
Tableman: A man at draughts; a piece used in playing games at tables. See Table, n., 10.
Terebrant: Boring, or adapted for boring; -- said of certain Hymenoptera, as the sawflies.
Truce: A suspension of arms by agreement of the commanders of opposing forces; a temporary cessation of hostilities, for negotiation or other purpose; an armistice.
Trapes: To go about in an idle or slatternly fashion; to trape; to traipse.
Torrens system: A system of registration of titles to land (as distinct from registration of deeds) introduced into South Australia by the Real Property (or Torrens) Act (act 15 of 1857-58), drafted by Sir Robert Torrens (1814-84). Its essential feature is the guaranty by the government of properly registered titles. The system has been generally adopted in Australia and British Columbia, and in its original or a modified form in some other countries, including some States of the United States. Hence Torrens title, etc.
Temperamental: Of or pertaining to temperament; constitutional.
Tartarine: Potassium carbonate, obtained by the incineration of tartar.
