Terrel: A spherical magnet so placed that its poles, equator, etc., correspond to those of the earth.
Timeserving: An obsequious compliance with the spirit of the times, or the humors of those in power, which implies a surrender of one's independence, and sometimes of one's integrity.
Tinner: One who works in a tin mine.
Trigamous: Having three sorts of flowers in the same head, -- male, female, and hermaphrodite, or perfect, flowers.
Topographer: One who is skilled in the science of topography; one who describes a particular place, town, city, or tract of land.
Toque: A kind of cap worn in the 16th century, and copied in modern fashions; -- called also toquet.
Tussive: Pertaining to a cough; caused by coughing.
Transmutationist: One who believes in the transmutation of metals or of species.
Twilly: A machine for cleansing or loosening wool by the action of a revolving cylinder covered with long iron spikes or teeth; a willy or willying machine; -- called also twilly devil, and devil. See Devil, n., 6, and Willy.
Tinkerly: After the manner of a tinker.
Tribune: An officer or magistrate chosen by the people, to protect them from the oppression of the patricians, or nobles, and to defend their liberties against any attempts that might be made upon them by the senate and consuls.
Tanite: A firm composition of emery and a certain kind of cement, used for making grinding wheels, slabs, etc.
Tarriance: The act or time of tarrying; delay; lateness.
Theropoda: An order of carnivorous dinosaurs in which the feet are less birdlike, and hence more like those of an ordinary quadruped, than in the Ornithopoda. It includes the rapacious genera Megalosaurus, Creosaurus, and their allies.
Terret: One of the rings on the top of the saddle of a harness, through which the reins pass.
Table: To live at the table of another; to board; to eat.
Transelement: To change or transpose the elements of; to transubstantiate.
Tavernman: The keeper of a tavern; also, a tippler.
Truncation: The act of truncating, lopping, or cutting off.
Tractrix: A curve such that the part of the tangent between the point of tangency and a given straight line is constant; -- so called because it was conceived as described by the motion of one end of a tangent line as the other end was drawn along the given line.
Totear: To tear or rend in pieces.
Turfy: Abounding with turf; made of, or covered with, turf.
Thank: To express gratitude to (anyone) for a favor; to make acknowledgments to (anyone) for kindness bestowed; -- used also ironically for blame.
Tribrach: A poetic foot of three short syllables, as, m&ebreve_;l&ibreve_;ŭs.
Thunder: To emit with noise and terror; to utter vehemently; to publish, as a threat or denunciation.
Transitoriness: The quality or state of being transitory; speedy passage or departure.
Tilefish: A large, edible, deep-water food fish (Lopholatilus chamæleonticeps) more or less thickly covered with large, round, yellow spots.
Thane: A dignitary under the Anglo-Saxons and Danes in England.  Of these there were two orders, the king's thanes, who attended the kings in their courts and held lands immediately of them, and the ordinary thanes, who were lords of manors and who had particular jurisdiction within their limits.  After the Conquest, this title was disused, and baron took its place.
Tylopoda: A tribe of ungulates comprising the camels.
Textual: Of, pertaining to, or contained in, the text; as, textual criticism; a textual reading.
Trimyarian: A lamellibranch which has three muscular scars on each valve.
Tip: A light touch or blow; a tap.
Thermotonus: A condition of tonicity with respect to temperature.
Tarpan: A wild horse found in the region of the Caspian Sea.
Thermo-: A combining form from Gr. qe`rmh heat, qermo`s hot, warm; as in thermochemistry, thermodynamic.
Trusty: Admitting of being safely trusted; justly deserving confidence; fit to be confided in; trustworthy; reliable.
Tenantless: Having no tenants; unoccupied; as, a tenantless mansion.
Tweag: A pinching condition; perplexity; trouble; distress.
Turacoverdin: A green pigment found in the feathers of the turacou. See Turacin.
Taxine: A poisonous alkaloid of bitter taste extracted from the leaves and seeds of the European yew (Taxus baccata).  Called also taxia.  The usual preparation is a mixture of compounds.  Taxine A has the chemical formula: C35H47NO10.
Tenter: To hang or stretch on, or as on, tenters.
Tinet: Brushwood and thorns for making and repairing hedges.
Trident: Having three teeth or prongs; tridentate.
Tilting: The act of one who tilts; a tilt.
Trichome: A hair on the surface of leaf or stem, or any modification of a hair, as a minute scale, or star, or gland. The sporangia of ferns are believed to be of the nature of trichomes.
Tubularida: An extensive division of Hydroidea; the tubularians; -- called also Athecata, Gymnoblastea, and Tubulariæ.
Traction wheel: A locomotive driving wheel which acts by friction adhesion to a smooth track.
Thionol: A red or violet dyestuff having a greenish metallic luster. It is produced artificially, by the chemical dehydration of thionine, as a brown amorphous powder.
Trituberculy: A theory of the development of mammalian molar teeth. The primitive stage is that of simple cones, as in reptiles. The simple cone then developed a smaller cone in front and another behind. Next, a cingulum was developed, and the three cones became arranged in a triangle, the two smaller cusps having moved to the outer side in upper and to the inner in lower molars. This primitive triangle is called the trigon or trigonid and this stage the tritubercular or trigonodont. The trigon being a cutting apparatus, an extension of the posterior part of the crown was developed in lower molars for crushing, and a smaller corresponding part appeared in upper molars. Another large cone then arose, usually from the cingulum. In more complex forms, smaller intermediate cusps appeared.
Teocalli: Literally, God's house; a temple, usually of pyramidal form, such as were built by the aborigines of Mexico, Yucatan, etc.
Two-ply: Consisting of two thicknesses, as cloth; double.
Tumid: Swelled, enlarged, or distended; as, a tumid leg; tumid flesh.
Theomancy: A kind of divination drawn from the responses of oracles among heathen nations.
Te Deum: An ancient and celebrated Christian hymn, of uncertain authorship, but often ascribed to St. Ambrose; -- so called from the first words “Te Deum laudamus.” It forms part of the daily matins of the Roman Catholic breviary, and is sung on all occasions of thanksgiving. In its English form, commencing with words, “We praise thee, O God,” it forms a part of the regular morning service of the Church of England and the Protestant Episcopal Church in America.
Tea-saucer: A small saucer in which a teacup is set.
Touchdown: The act of touching the football down behind the opponents' goal; also the score (6 points) resulting from such a play.
Trade name: The name by which an article is called among traders, etc.; as, tin spirits is a common trade name in the dyeing industry for various solutions of tin salts.
Trinitarian: One who believes in the doctrine of the Trinity.
Theobromine: An alkaloidal ureide, C7H8N4O2, homologous with and resembling caffeine, produced artificially, and also extracted from cacao and chocolate (from Theobroma Cacao) as a bitter white crystalline substance; -- called also dimethyl xanthine.
Taking: The act of gaining possession; a seizing; seizure; apprehension.
Thumper: One who, or that which, thumps.
Twixt: An abbreviation of Betwixt, used in poetry, or in colloquial language.
Tazza: An ornamental cup or vase with a large, flat, shallow bowl, resting on a pedestal and often having handles.
Tot: To mark with the word “tot”; as, a totted debt. See Tot, n.
Temporomaxillary: Of or pertaining to both the temple or the temporal bone and the maxilla.
Triplication: The act of tripling, or making threefold, or adding three together.
Touch-needle: A small bar of gold and silver, either pure, or alloyed in some known proportion with copper, for trying the purity of articles of gold or silver by comparison of the streaks made by the article and the bar on a touchstone.
Tipping: A distinct articulation given in playing quick notes on the flute, by striking the tongue against the roof of the mouth; double-tonguing.
Tetrylene: Butylene; -- so called from the four carbon atoms in the molecule.
Thecal: Of or pertaining to a theca; as, a thecal abscess.
Troublesome: Giving trouble or anxiety; vexatious; burdensome; wearisome.
Trump: To trick, or impose on; to deceive.
Try cock: A cock for withdrawing a small quantity of liquid, as for testing.
Trackless: Having no track; marked by no footsteps; untrodden; as, a trackless desert.
Tallage: To lay an impost upon; to cause to pay tallage.
Tyburn ticket: A certificate given to one who prosecutes a felon to conviction, exempting him from certain parish and ward offices.
Tom o Bedlam: Formerly, a wandering mendicant discharged as incurable from Bethlehem Hospital, England; hence, a wandering mendicant, either mad or feigning to be so; a madman; a bedlamite.
Tempestivily: The quality, or state, of being tempestive; seasonableness.
Thinker: One who thinks; especially and chiefly, one who thinks in a particular manner; as, a close thinker; a deep thinker; a coherent thinker.
Textuary: One who is well versed in the Scriptures; a textman.
Tucuma: A Brazilian palm (Astrocaryum Tucuma) which furnishes an edible fruit.
Turlupin: One of the precursors of the Reformation; -- a nickname corresponding to Lollard, etc.
Triglyceride: A glyceride formed by the replacement of three hydrogen atoms in glycerin by acid radicals.
Trichinous: Of or pertaining to trichinæ or trichinosis; affected with, or containing, trichinæ; as, trichinous meat.
Tint: To give a slight coloring to; to tinge.
Truncheoneer: A person armed with a truncheon.
Tootle: To toot gently, repeatedly, or continuously, on a wind instrument, as a flute; also, to make a similar noise by any means.
Tom: A familiar contraction of Thomas, a proper name of a man.
Trachelorrhaphy: The operation of sewing up a laceration of the neck of the uterus.
Tarente: A harmless lizard of the Gecko family (Platydactylus Mauritianicus) found in Southern Europe and adjacent countries, especially among old walls and ruins.
Ting: The apartment in a Chinese temple where the idol is kept.
Tine: A tooth, or spike, as of a fork; a prong, as of an antler.
Tranquillity: The quality or state of being tranquil; calmness; composure.
Top-hamper: The upper rigging, spars, etc., of a ship.
Titillate: To tickle; as, to titillate the nose with a feather.
Tink: A sharp, quick sound; a tinkle.
tutorial: A class{6} or short series of classes in which one or more instructors provide intensive instruction on some subject to a small group.  Such short courses of instruction may be held at an institution of learning, or in any other place where a small group may desire a brief but thorough introduction to a topic.
Telestereograph: An instrument for telegraphically reproducing a photograph.
Tycoon: The title by which the shogun, or former commander in chief of the Japanese army, was known to foreigners.
Thioxene: Any one of three possible metameric substances, which are dimethyl derivatives of thiophene, like the xylenes from benzene.
Thong: A strap of leather; especially, one used for fastening anything.
Tout-ensemble: All together; hence, in costume, the fine arts, etc., the general effect of a work as a whole, without regard to the execution of the separate perts.
Toppiece: A small wig for the top of the head; a toupee.
Thunderclap: A sharp burst of thunder; a sudden report of a discharge of atmospheric electricity.
Trading: Carrying on trade or commerce; engaged in trade; as, a trading company.
Tradition: To transmit by way of tradition; to hand down.
Tormentful: Full of torment; causing, or accompanied by, torment; excruciating.
Trinoctial: Lasting during three nights; comprising three nights.
Totipalmi: A division of swimming birds including those that have totipalmate feet.
Tagtail: A worm which has its tail conspicuously colored.
Tay-Sachs Disease: A rare hereditary disease affecting lipid metabolism in humans, due to a deficiency of hexosaminidase.  It occurs in infants and children, and causes death before the onset of adulthood.  It occurs most commonly of people of Jewish origin from easter Europe.  It is characterized by accumulation of lipids in nervous tissue, causes a red spot on the retina, and eventual blindness and paralysis before death.
Thuyin: A substance extracted from trees of the genus Thuja, or Thuya, and probably identical with quercitrin.
Tangentially: In the direction of a tangent.
Teraphim: Images connected with the magical rites used by those Israelites who added corrupt practices to the patriarchal religion. Teraphim were consulted by the Israelites for oracular answers.
Trachelipoda: An extensive artificial group of gastropods comprising all those which have a spiral shell and the foot attached to the base of the neck.
Truckler: One who truckles, or yields servilely to the will of another.
Thing: In Scandinavian countries, a legislative or judicial assembly; -- used, esp. in composition, in titles of such bodies. See Legislature, Norway.
Thine: A form of the possessive case of the pronoun thou, now superseded in common discourse by your, the possessive of you, but maintaining a place in solemn discourse, in poetry, and in the usual language of the Friends, or Quakers.
Tocororo: A cuban trogon (Priotelus temnurus) having a serrated bill and a tail concave at the end.
Telpherage: The conveyance of vehicles or loads by means of electricity.
Thousand legs: A millepid, or galleyworm; -- called also thousand-legged worm.
Thwart: To move or go in an oblique or crosswise manner.
Trial balance: The testing of a ledger to discover whether the debits and credits balance, by finding whether the sum of the personal credits increased by the difference between the debit and credit sums in the merchandise and other impersonal accounts equals the sum of personal debits. The equality would not show that the items were all correctly posted.
Thalline: An artificial alkaloid of the quinoline series, obtained as a white crystalline substance, C10H13NO, whose salts are valuable as antipyretics; -- so called from the green color produced in its solution by certain oxidizing agents.
Triarian: Occupying the third post or rank.
Thirteenth: The quotient of a unit divided by thirteen; one of thirteen equal parts into which anything is divided.
Terminate: To be limited in space by a point, line, or surface; to stop short; to end; to cease; as, the torrid zone terminates at the tropics.
Triplite: A mineral of a dark brown color, generally with a fibrous, massive structure. It is a fluophosphate of iron and manganese.
Trevet: A stool or other thing supported by three legs; a trivet.
Telechirograph: An instrument for  telegraphically transmitting and receiving handwritten messages, as photographically by a beam of light from a mirror.
Triandria: A Linnæan class of plants having three distinct and equal stamens.
Tubal: Of or pertaining to a tube; specifically, of or pertaining to one of the Fallopian tubes; as, tubal pregnancy.
Thorp: A group of houses in the country; a small village; a hamlet; a dorp; -- now chiefly occurring in names of places and persons; as, Althorp, Mablethorpe.
Tubicol\u00e6: A division of annelids including those which construct, and habitually live in, tubes. The head or anterior segments usually bear gills and cirri. Called also Sedentaria, and Capitibranchiata. See Serpula, and Sabella.
Themselves: The plural of himself, herself, and itself. See Himself, Herself, Itself.
Thwartingly: In a thwarting or obstructing manner; so as to thwart.
Tattoo: An indelible mark or figure made by puncturing the skin and introducing some pigment into the punctures; -- a mode of ornamentation practiced by various barbarous races, both in ancient and modern times, and also by some among civilized nations, especially by sailors.
Tahaleb: A fox (Vulpes Niloticus) of Northern Africa.
Tolletane: Of or pertaining to Toledo in Spain; made in Toledo.
Translunary: Being or lying beyond the moon; hence, ethereal; -- opposed to sublunary.
Tonometry: The act of measuring with a tonometer;
Tectibranchiata: An order, or suborder, of gastropod Mollusca in which the gills are usually situated on one side of the back, and protected by a fold of the mantle.  When there is a shell, it is usually thin and delicate and often rudimentary. The aplysias and the bubble shells are examples.
Timeliness: The quality or state of being timely; seasonableness; opportuneness.
Tetrathionic: Of, pertaining to, or designating, a thionic derivative, H2S4O6, of sulphuric acid, obtained as a colorless, odorless liquid.
Tarrock: The young of the kittiwake gull before the first molt.
Tubicolous: Inhabiting a tube; as, tubicolous worms.
Terrific: Causing terror; adapted to excite great fear or dread; terrible; as, a terrific form; a terrific sight.
Tympanitic: Of, pertaining to, or affected with, tympanites.
Thermoregulator: A device for the automatic regulation of temperature; a thermostat.
Tidology: A discourse or treatise upon the tides; that part of science which treats of tides.
Tricorporal: Represented with three bodies conjoined to one head, as a lion.
Traducianism: The doctrine that human souls are produced by the act of generation; -- opposed to creationism, and infusionism.
Tu-whit: Words imitative of the notes of the owl.
Transgressional: Of pertaining to transgression; involving a transgression.
Timbered: Furnished with timber; -- often compounded; as, a well-timbered house; a low-timbered house.
Tutsan: A plant of the genus Hypericum (Hypericum Androsœmum), from which a healing ointment is prepared in Spain; -- called also parkleaves.
Tray: A small trough or wooden vessel, sometimes scooped out of a block of wood, for various domestic uses, as in making bread, chopping meat, etc.
Traditionalist: An advocate of, or believer in, traditionalism; a traditionist.
Tape recorder: an electroinic device for recording and playing back sounds on magnetic tape; it often has an integrated microphone, amplifier, and speaker, and in such cases requires no additional equipment other than the magnetic tape for recording or playback.
Traditionalism: A system of faith founded on tradition; esp., the doctrine that all religious faith is to be based solely upon what is delivered from competent authority, exclusive of rational processes.
Testicular: Of or pertaining to the testicle.
Tomium: The cutting edge of the bill of a bird.
Topi: An antelope (Damaliscus corrigum jimela) having a glossy purplish brown coat. It is related to the blesbok and is native of East Africa. Also, any of various related varieties of other districts south of the Sahara.
Thermojunction: A junction of two dissimilar conductors used to produce a thermoelectric current, as in one form of pyrometer; a thermocouple.
Tumescent: Slightly tumid; swollen, as certain moss capsules.
Tope: To drink hard or frequently; to drink strong or spiritous liquors to excess.
Two-port: Having two ports; specif.: Designating a type of two-cycle internal-combustion engine in which the admission of the mixture to the crank case is through a suction valve.
Thyro-: A combining form used in anatomy to indicate connection with, or relation to, the thyroid body or the thyroid cartilage; as, thyrohyal.
Trustiness: The quality or state of being trusty.
Tetrasyllable: A word consisting of four syllables; a quadrisyllable.
Transcolate: To cause to pass through a sieve or colander; to strain, as through a sieve.
Twelve: The number next following eleven; the sum of ten and two, or of twice six; twelve units or objects; a dozen.
Thermoelectrometer: An instrument for measuring the strength of an electric current in the heat which it produces, or for determining the heat developed by such a current.
Trousering: Cloth or material for making trousers.
Theology: The science of God or of religion; the science which treats of the existence, character, and attributes of God, his laws and government, the doctrines we are to believe, and the duties we are to practice; divinity; (as more commonly understood) “the knowledge derivable from the Scriptures, the systematic exhibition of revealed truth, the science of Christian faith and life.”
Torchwort: The common mullein, the stalks of which, dipped in suet, anciently served for torches. Called also torch, and hig-taper.
Triserial: Arranged in three vertical or spiral rows.
Terebinthinate: Impregnating with the qualities of turpentine; terbinthine.
Talmudic: Of or pertaining to the Talmud; contained in the Talmud; as, Talmudic Greek; Talmudical phrases.
Trashiness: The quality or state of being trashy.
Tirailleur: Formerly, a member of an independent body of marksmen in the French army. They were used sometimes in front of the army to annoy the enemy, sometimes in the rear to check his pursuit. The term is now applied to all troops acting as skirmishers.
Tone: To utter with an affected tone.
Tong: In China, an association, secret society, or organization of any kind; in the United States, usually, a secret association of Chinese such as that of the highbinders; in the U. S. the tongs have been frequently associated with criminal activity and gang warfare.
Tuber: A fleshy, rounded stem or root, usually containing starchy matter, as the potato or arrowroot; a thickened root-stock. See Illust. of Tuberous.
Torch: A light or luminary formed of some combustible substance, as of resinous wood; a large candle or flambeau, or a lamp giving a large, flaring flame.
Trample: The act of treading under foot; also, the sound produced by trampling.
Taxiarch: An Athenian military officer commanding a certain division of an army.
Thwartness: The quality or state of being thwart; obliquity; perverseness.
Term insurance: Insurance for a specified term providing for no payment to the insured except upon losses during the term, and becoming void upon its expiration.
Twibil: A kind of mattock, or ax; esp., a tool like a pickax, but having, instead of the points, flat terminations, one of which is parallel to the handle, the other perpendicular to it.
Tel-el-Amarna: A station on the Nile in Egypt, midway between Thebes and Memphis, forming the site of the ancient city of Akhetaton, capital of Amenophis IV. (Akhenaton, or Amenhotep IV., of the 18th dynasty, king 1353-1336 B. C.), whose archive chamber was discovered there during extensive excavations in 1887-1888.  A collection of about 300 clay tablets (called the Tel-el-Amarna tablets, or the Amarna tablets) was found here, forming the diplomatic correspondence (Tel-el-Amarna letters) of Amenophis IV. and his father, Amenophis III., with the kings of Asiatic countries (such as Babylonia, Assyria, and Palestine), written in cuneiform characters.  It is an important source of our knowledge of Asia from about 1400 to 1370 b. c..  The name of the site is also spelled Tell-el-Amarna, Tell el Amarna, and Tel Amarna.
Towboat: A vessel constructed for being towed, as a canal boat.
Taguan: A large flying squirrel (Pteromys petuarista). Its body becomes two feet long, with a large bushy tail nearly as long.
Talismanic: Of or pertaining to a talisman; having the properties of a talisman, or preservative against evils by occult influence; magical.
Tremendous: Fitted to excite fear or terror; such as may astonish or terrify by its magnitude, force, or violence; terrible; dreadful; as, a tremendous wind; a tremendous shower; a tremendous shock or fall.
Tattler: One who tattles; an idle talker; one who tells tales.
Tales: Persons added to a jury, commonly from those in or about the courthouse, to make up any deficiency in the number of jurors regularly summoned, being like, or such as, the latter.
Trisect: To cut or divide into three parts.
T\u00e6nioglossa: An extensive division of gastropod mollusks in which the odontophore is long and narrow, and usually bears seven rows of teeth.  It includes a large number of families both marine and fresh-water.
Tetrapody: A set of four feet; a measure or distance of four feet.
Trigonometric: Of or pertaining to trigonometry; performed by the rules of trigonometry.
Torpedo stern: A broad stern without overhang, flattened on the bottom, used in some torpedo and fast power boats. It prevents settling in the water at high speed.
Twinkler: One who, or that which, twinkles, or winks; a winker; an eye.
Thimbleweed: Any plant of the composite genus Rudbeckia, coarse herbs somewhat resembling the sunflower; -- so called from their conical receptacles.
Trapball: An old game of ball played with a trap. See 4th Trap, 4.
Turfing: The act or process of providing or covering with turf.
Taled: A kind of quadrangular piece of cloth put on by the Jews when repeating prayers in the synagogues.
Transparency: The quality or condition of being transparent; transparence.
Turacin: A red or crimson pigment obtained from certain feathers of several species of turacou; whence the name. It contains nearly six per cent of copper.
Triphylite: A mineral of a grayish-green or bluish color, consisting of the phosphates of iron, manganese, and lithia.
Trace: To walk; to go; to travel.
Tabernacular: Of or pertaining to a tabernacle, especially the Jewish tabernacle.
Troglodytic: Of or pertaining to a troglodyte, or dweller in caves.
Thermoscope: An instrument for indicating changes of temperature without indicating the degree of heat by which it is affected; especially, an instrument contrived by Count Rumford which, as modified by Professor Leslie, was afterward called the differential thermometer.
Threnode: A threne, or threnody; a dirge; a funeral song.
Trepidation: An involuntary trembling, sometimes an effect of paralysis, but usually caused by terror or fear; quaking; quivering.
Threnody: A song of lamentation; a threnode.
Therapeutist: One versed in therapeutics, or the discovery and application of remedies.
Tract: To trace out; to track; also, to draw out; to protact.
Terebinthine: Of or pertaining to turpentine; consisting of turpentine, or partaking of its qualities.
Township: The district or territory of a town.
Titularly: In a titular manner; nominally; by title only.
T\u00e6nia: A genus of intestinal worms which includes the common tapeworms of man. See Tapeworm.
T\u00e6niasis: Ill health due to tænia, or tapeworms.
Testamentation: The act or power of giving by testament, or will.
Thereunto: Unto that or this; thereto; besides.
Tawery: A place where skins are tawed.
Tribuneship: The office or power of a tribune.
Tubercled: Having tubercles; affected with, tubercles; tuberculate; as, a tubercled lung or stalk.
Trilinear: Of, pertaining to, or included by, three lines; as, trilinear coördinates.
Trias: The formation situated between the Permian and Lias, and so named by the Germans, because consisting of three series of strata, which are called in German the Bunter sandstein, Muschelkalk, and Keuper.
Thimblerigger: One who cheats by thimblerigging, or tricks of legerdemain.
Trial: The act of trying or testing in any manner.
Two-handed: Having two hands; -- often used as an epithet equivalent to large, stout, strong, or powerful.
Typhon: According to Hesiod, the son of Typhoeus, and father of the winds, but later identified with him.
Triad: A union of three; three objects treated as one; a ternary; a trinity; as, a triad of deities.
Tape deck: an electroinic device for recording and playing back sounds on magnetic tape; usually it needs to be connected to an amplifier system for playback.
Tollable: Subject to the payment of toll; as, tollable goods.
Tryptic: Relating to trypsin or to its action; produced by trypsin; as, trypsin digestion.
Torpedoist: One skilled in the theory or use of torpedoes; also, one who favors the use of torpedoes.
Thespian: Of or pertaining to Thespis; hence, relating to the drama; dramatic; as, the Thespian art.
Theorematic: Of or pertaining to a theorem or theorems; comprised in a theorem; consisting of theorems.
Transmeation: The act of transmeating; a passing through or beyond.
Tentory: The awning or covering of a tent.
Trimorphic: Of, pertaining to, or characterized by, trimorphism; -- contrasted with monomorphic, dimorphic, and polymorphic.
True-hearted: Of a faithful heart; honest; sincere; not faithless or deceitful; as, a truhearted friend.
Trica: An apothecium in certain lichens, having a spherical surface marked with spiral or concentric ridges and furrows.
Tridentine: Of or pertaining to Trent, or the general church council held in that city.
Trochoidal: Of or pertaining to a trochoid; having the properties of a trochoid.
Tomrig: A rude, wild, wanton girl; a hoiden; a tomboy.
Tonite: An explosive compound; a preparation of gun cotton.
Transformative: Having power, or a tendency, to transform.
Teutonic: The language of the ancient Germans; the Teutonic languages, collectively.
Tilt hammer: A tilted hammer; a heavy hammer, used in iron works, which is lifted or tilted by projections or wipers on a revolving shaft; a trip hammer.
Throat: To utter in the throat; to mutter; as, to throat threats.
Treillage: Latticework for supporting vines, etc.; an espalier; a trellis.
Tabulata: An artificial group of stony corals including those which have transverse septa in the calicles. The genera Pocillopora and Favosites are examples.
Torrid: Parched; dried with heat; as, a torrid plain or desert.
Tabulate: To form into a table or tables; to reduce to tables or synopses.
Turkey-trot: An eccentric ragtime dance, danced with the feet well apart and with a characteristic rise on the ball of the foot, followed by a drop upon the heel. The original form, owing to the positions assumed by the dancers, is offensively suggestive.  Similar dances are the bunny hug and grizzly bear, so called in allusion to the movements and the positions assumed by the partners in dancing.
Tackling: Furniture of the masts and yards of a vessel, as cordage, sails, etc.
Turbidness: The quality or state of being turbid; muddiness; foulness.
Tessellata: A division of Crinoidea including numerous fossil species in which the body is covered with tessellated plates.
To-: An obsolete intensive prefix used in the formation of compound verbs; as in to-beat, to-break, to-hew, to-rend, to-tear. See these words in the Vocabulary. See the Note on All to, or All-to, under All, adv.
Trangram: Something intricately contrived; a contrived; a puzzle.
Thyself: An emphasized form of the personal pronoun of the second person; -- used as a subject commonly with thou; as, thou thyself shalt go; that is, thou shalt go, and no other. It is sometimes used, especially in the predicate, without thou, and in the nominative as well as in the objective case.
Transcontinental: Extending or going across a continent; as, a transcontinental railroad or journey.
Thimble: A kind of cap or cover, or sometimes a broad ring, for the end of the finger, used in sewing to protect the finger when pushing the needle through the material. It is usually made of metal, and has upon the outer surface numerous small pits to catch the head of the needle.
Toxicologist: One versed in toxicology; the writer of a treatise on poisons.
Tellurize: To impregnate with, or to subject to the action of, tellurium; -- chiefly used adjectively in the past participle; as, tellurized ores.
Tubful: As much as a tub will hold; enough to fill a tub.
Tie-rod: A rod used as a tie. See Tie.
Trisulc: Something having three forks or prongs, as a trident.
Twelfthtide: The twelfth day after Christmas; Epiphany; -- called also Twelfth-day.
telemarketing: the use of the telephone as an interactive medium for promotion; calling potential customers by telephone for the purpose of selling something; -- applied especially to calls made to persons who have not previously contacted the seller.
Therewhile: At that time; at the same time.
Trillo: A trill or shake. See Trill.
Tautologous: Repeating the same thing in different words; tautological.
Tourist: One who makes a tour, or performs a journey, especially for pleasure.
Travesty: To translate, imitate, or represent, so as to render ridiculous or ludicrous.
Tychonic: Of or pertaining to Tycho Brahe, or his system of astronomy.
Transition zone: The zone lying between the Boreal and Sonoran zones of North America. It includes an eastern or humid subdivision and a western arid one of corresponding temperature comprising the northern Great Plains and the lower slopes of the mountains of the western United States and Mexico. Called also Neutral zone.
Truly: In a true manner; according to truth; in agreement with fact; as, to state things truly; the facts are truly represented.
Tirrit: A word from the vocabulary of Mrs. Quickly, the hostess in Shakespeare's Henry IV., probably meaning terror.
Topiarian: Of or pertaining to the ornamental cutting and trimming of trees, hedges, etc.; practicing ornamental gardening.
Toggery: Clothes; garments; dress; as, fishing toggery.
Turk: A member of any of numerous Tartar tribes of Central Asia, etc.; esp., one of the dominant race in Turkey.
Tool steel: Hard steel, usually crucible steel, capable of being tempered so as to be suitable for tools.
Trull: A drab; a strumpet; a harlot; a trollop.
Transnature: To transfer or transform the nature of.
Transcribe: To write over again, or in the same words; to copy; as, to transcribe Livy or Tacitus; to transcribe a letter.
Tronage: A toll or duty paid for weighing wool; also, the act of weighing wool.
Terbium: A rare metallic element, found in certain minerals, as gadolinite and samarskite, with other rare earths such as ytterbium. Symbol Tb. Atomic number 65. Atomic weight 158.925.
Trunnion: A cylindrical projection on each side of a piece, whether gun, mortar, or howitzer, serving to support it on the cheeks of the carriage. See Illust. of Cannon.
Telluride: A compound of tellurium with a more positive element or radical; -- formerly called telluret.
Theobromic: Of, pertaining to, or designating, an acid extracted from cacao butter (from the Theobroma Cacao), peanut oil (from Arachis hypogæa), etc., as a white waxy crystalline substance.
Tidal wave: an unusually high wave from the sea, sometimes reaching far inland and causing great destruction, and usually caused by some event, such as an earthquake, far from the shore.  In Japan, such a wave is called a tsunami.
Tolerant: Inclined to tolerate; favoring toleration; forbearing; indulgent.
Twenty: The number next following nineteen; the sum of twelve and eight, or twice ten; twenty units or objects; a score.
Tupelo: A North American tree (Nyssa multiflora) of the Dogwood family, having brilliant, glossy foliage and acid red berries.  The wood is crossgrained and very difficult to split. Called also black gum, sour gum, and pepperidge.
Thrower: One who throws. Specifically: (a) One who throws or twists silk; a throwster. (b) One who shapes vessels on a throwing engine.
Teaspoonful: As much as teaspoon will hold; enough to fill a teaspoon.  In cooking, it is usually estimated as 4.9 milliliters, which is 1/6 of a fluid ounce, or 1/3 of a tablespoonful.  In cooking recipes it may be abbreviated as t.
Tousle: To put into disorder; to tumble; to touse.
Trammeler: One who uses a trammel net.
Tricipital: Having three heads, or three origins; as, a tricipital muscle.
Tractor: That which draws, or is used for drawing.
Tetracolon: A stanza or division in lyric poetry, consisting of four verses or lines.
Tau: The common American toadfish; -- so called from a marking resembling the Greek letter tau (τ).
Top-heavy: Having the top or upper part too heavy for the lower part.
Taw: A large marble to be played with; also, a game at marbles.
Tap: To pierce so as to let out, or draw off, a fluid; as, to tap a cask, a tree, a tumor,  a keg of beer, etc.
Thermostat: A device which automatically regulates temperature, or provides a signal used by another device to regulate temperature.  The temperature-sensitive signal may be electronic, as that produced by a thermocouple.  The signal may also be caused mechanically, as by the unequal expansion of different metals, liquids, or gases by heat, which can then cause the opening or closing of the damper of a stove, or the like, as the heat becomes greater or less than is desired.
Tar: To smear with tar, or as with tar; as, to tar ropes; to tar cloth.
Tatty: A mat or screen of fibers, as of the kuskus grass, hung at a door or window and kept wet to moisten and cool the air as it enters.
Tax: To subject to the payment of a tax or taxes; to impose a tax upon; to lay a burden upon; especially, to exact money from for the support of government.
Tailpiece: A piece at the end; an appendage.
Test-market: to market (a product) in a limited area for a period of time to determine the probable demand.
Thymol: A phenol derivative of cymene, C10H13.OH, isomeric with carvacrol, found in oil of thyme, and extracted as a white crystalline substance of a pleasant aromatic odor and strong antiseptic properties; -- called also hydroxy cymene.
Two-speed: Adapted for producing or for receiving either of two speeds; -- said of a power-transmitting device.
Tag: A child's play in which one runs after and touches another, and then runs away to avoid being touched.
Tab: The flap or latchet of a shoe fastened with a string or a buckle.
Tac: A kind of customary payment by a tenant; -- a word used in old records.
Temporo-: A combining form used in anatomy to indicate connection with, or relation to, the temple, or temporal bone; as, temporofacial.
Trou-de-loup: A pit in the form of an inverted cone or pyramid, constructed as an obstacle to the approach of an enemy, and having a pointed stake in the middle. The pits are called also trapholes.
Tai: A member of one of the tribes of the Tai stock.
Tablet: A small table or flat surface.
Top-timbers: The highest timbers on the side of a vessel, being those above the futtocks.
Tableau: A striking and vivid representation; a picture.
Trajectory: The curve which a body describes in space, as a planet or comet in its orbit, or stone thrown upward obliquely in the air.
Transpiration: The act or process of transpiring or excreting in the form of vapor; exhalation, as through the skin or other membranes of the body; as, pulmonary transpiration, or the excretion of aqueous vapor from the lungs. Perspiration is a form of transpiration.
Thinness: The quality or state of being thin (in any of the senses of the word).
Telary: Of or pertaining to a web; hence, spinning webs; retiary.
Trinucleus: A genus of Lower Silurian trilobites in which the glabella and cheeks form three rounded elevations on the head.
Terutero: The South American lapwing (Vanellus Cayennensis). Its wings are furnished with short spurs. Called also Cayenne lapwing.
Trikosane: A hydrocarbon, C23H48, of the methane series, resembling paraffin; -- so called because it has twenty-three atoms of carbon in the molecule.
Treeful: The quantity or number which fills a tree.
Tactful: Full of tact; characterized by a discerning sense of what is right, proper, or judicious.
Tub: To make use of a bathing tub; to lie or be in a bath; to bathe.
Tiglic: Of, pertaining to, or designating, an acid, C4H7CO2H (called also methyl crotonic acid), homologous with crotonic acid, and obtained from croton oil (from Croton Tiglium) as a white crystalline substance.
Tetrol: A hypothetical hydrocarbon, C4H4, analogous to benzene; -- so called from the four carbon atoms in the molecule.
Trional: A compound similar to sulphonal, used as a hypnotic in medicine.
Telotrocha: An annelid larva having telotrochal bands of cilia.
Third rail: The third rail used in the third-rail system.
Tollman: One who receives or collects toll; a toll gatherer.
Tractility: The quality of being tractile; ductility.
Trochite: A wheel-like joint of the stem of a fossil crinoid.
Tart: A species of small open pie, or piece of pastry, containing jelly or conserve; a sort of fruit pie.
Thigmotaxis: The property possessed by living protoplasm of contracting, and thus moving, when touched by a solid or fluid substance.
Temptationless: Having no temptation or motive; as, a temptationless sin.
Thoracica: A division of cirripeds including those which have six thoracic segments, usually bearing six pairs of cirri. The common barnacles are examples.
Tarantass: A low four-wheeled carriage used in Russia. The carriage box rests on two long, springy poles which run from the fore to the hind axletree. When snow falls, the wheels are taken off, and the body is mounted on a sledge.
Thoroughpin: A disease of the hock (sometimes of the knee) of a horse, caused by inflammation of the synovial membrane and a consequent excessive secretion of the synovial fluid; -- probably so called because there is usually an oval swelling on each side of the leg, appearing somewhat as if a pin had been thrust through.
Transferability: The quality or state of being transferable.
Triangularity: The quality or state of being triangular.
Trifid: Cleft to the middle, or slightly beyond the middle, into three parts; three-cleft.
Taxon: a taxonomic group, or the name of a taxonomic grouping.
Timer: A timekeeper; especially, a watch by which small intervals of time can be measured; a kind of stop watch. It is used for timing the speed of horses, machinery, etc.
Tentorium: A fold of the dura mater which separates the cerebellum from the cerebrum and often incloses a process or plate of the skull called the bony tentorium.
Transfigure: To change the outward form or appearance of; to metamorphose; to transform.
Triturium: A vessel for separating liquids of different densities.
Transcur: To run or rove to and fro.
Twaddler: One who prates in a weak and silly manner, like one whose faculties are decayed.
Testaceology: The science of testaceous mollusks; conchology.
Tilbury: A kind of gig or two-wheeled carriage, without a top or cover.
Tectonic: Of or pertaining to building or construction; architectural.
Tridymite: Pure silica, like quartz, but crystallizing in hexagonal tables. It is found in trachyte and similar rocks.
Three-decker: A vessel of war carrying guns on three decks.
Targum: A translation or paraphrase of some portion of the Old Testament Scriptures in the Chaldee or Aramaic language or dialect.
Trenchant: Fitted to trench or cut; gutting; sharp.
Teething: The process of the first growth of teeth, or the phenomena attending their issue through the gums; dentition.
Trunkfish: Any one of several species of plectognath fishes, belonging to the genus Ostracion, or the family Ostraciontidæ, having an angular body covered with a rigid integument consisting of bony scales. Some of the species are called also coffer fish, and boxfish.
Tipster: One who makes a practice of giving or selling tips, or private hints or information, esp. for use in gambling upon the probable outcome of events, as horse races.
Thomsenolite: A fluoride of aluminium, calcium, and sodium occurring with the cryolite of Greenland.
Topically: In a topical manner; with application to, or limitation of, a particular place or topic.
Technology: Industrial science; the science of systematic knowledge of the industrial arts, especially of the more important manufactures, as spinning, weaving, metallurgy, etc.
Turnverein: A company or association of gymnasts and athletes.
Talmud: The body of the Jewish civil and canonical law not comprised in the Pentateuch.
Telltale: One who officiously communicates information of the private concerns of others; one who tells that which prudence should suppress.
Thessalian: Of or pertaining to Thessaly in Greece.
Technique: The method or manner of performance in any art; -- also called technic.
Twelvepenny: Sold for a shilling; worth or costing a shilling.
Transanimate: To animate with a soul conveyed from another body.
Tremie: An apparatus for depositing and consolidating concrete under water, essentially a tube of wood or sheet metal with a hooperlike top. It is usually handled by a crane.
Therefore: For that or this reason, referring to something previously stated; for that.
Thump: To give a thump or thumps; to strike or fall with a heavy blow; to pound.
Tambourine: A South American wild dove (Tympanistria tympanistria), mostly white, with black-tiped wings and tail. Its resonant note is said to be ventriloquous.
Tanate: An Asiatic wild dog (Canis procyonoides), native of Japan and adjacent countries. It has a short, bushy tail. Called also raccoon dog.
Twirl: The act of twirling; a rapid circular motion; a whirl or whirling; quick rotation.
Trigamist: One who has been married three times; also, one who has three husbands or three wives at the same time.
Tonic: A tonic element or letter; a vowel or a diphthong.
Thrush: An affection of the mouth, fauces, etc., common in newly born children, characterized by minute ulcers called aphthæ. See Aphthæ.
Triternate: Three times ternate; -- applied to a leaf whose petiole separates into three branches, each of which divides into three parts which each bear three leafiets.
Tumble-down: Ready to fall; dilapidated; ruinous; as, a tumble-down house.
Toad: Any one of numerous species of batrachians belonging to the genus Bufo and allied genera, especially those of the family Bufonidæ. Toads are generally terrestrial in their habits except during the breeding season, when they seek the water. Most of the species burrow beneath the earth in the daytime and come forth to feed on insects at night. Most toads have a rough, warty skin in which are glands that secrete an acrid fluid.
Tri\u0153cia: The third order of the Linnæan class Polygamia.
Tiger: A very large and powerful carnivore (Felis tigris) native of Southern Asia and the East Indies. Its back and sides are tawny or rufous yellow, transversely striped with black, the tail is ringed with black, the throat and belly are nearly white. When full grown, it equals or exceeds the lion in size and strength. Called also royal tiger, and Bengal tiger.
Trundlehead: One of the disks forming the ends of a lantern wheel or pinion.
Telotype: An electric telegraph which prints the messages in letters and not in signs.
Techno: a form of music primarily created by computer sound synthizers rather than by musicians playing instruments.
Tammy: A kind of woolen, or woolen and cotton, cloth, often highly glazed, -- used for curtains, sieves, strainers, etc.
Thuggee: The practice of secret or stealthy murder by Thugs.
Thrust: A violent push or driving, as with a pointed weapon moved in the direction of its length, or with the hand or foot, or with any instrument; a stab; -- a word much used as a term of fencing.
Toxiphobia: An insane or greatly exaggerated dread of poisons.
Ternion: The number three; three things together; a ternary.
Tachygraphy: The art or practice of rapid writing; shorthand writing; stenography.
Typesetting: The act or art of setting type.
Telehydrobarometer: An instrument for indicating the level of water in a distant tank or reservior.
Trucking: The business of conveying goods on trucks.
Twigsome: Full of, or abounding in, twigs; twiggy.
Transposal: The act of transposing, or the state of being transposed; transposition.
Transmissible: Capable of being transmitted from one to another; capable of being passed through any body or substance.
These: The plural of this. See This.
Timbre: The crest on a coat of arms.
Testacy: The state or circumstance of being testate, or of leaving a valid will, or testament, at death.
Tampion: A wooden stopper, or plug, as for a cannon or other piece of ordnance, when not in use.
Twelvemonth: A year which consists of twelve calendar months.
Tamperer: One who tampers; one who deals unfairly.
Time: To keep or beat time; to proceed or move in time.
Trapezohedron: A solid bounded by twenty-four equal and similar trapeziums; a tetragonal trisoctahedron. See the Note under Trisoctahedron.
Triformity: The state of being triform, or of having a threefold shape.
Thriftiness: The quality or state of being thrifty; thrift.
Triturate: To rub, grind, bruise, or thrash.
Tulipwood: The beautiful rose-colored striped wood of a Brazilian tree (Physocalymna floribunda), much used by cabinetmakers for inlaying.
Tarnisher: One who, or that which, tarnishes.
Tileseed: Any plant of the genus Geissois, having seeds overlapping like tiles on a roof.
Transfix: To pierce through, as with a pointed weapon; to impale; as, to transfix one with a dart.
Trichiasis: A disease of the eye, in which the eyelashes, being turned in upon the eyeball, produce constant irritation by the motion of the lids.
Trypsinogen: The antecedent of trypsin, a substance which is contained in the cells of the pancreas and gives rise to the trypsin.
Touch-box: A box containing lighted tinder, formerly carried by soldiers who used matchlocks, to kindle the match.
Typify: To represent by an image, form, model, or resemblance.
Transplendency: Quality or state of being transplendent.
Telluric: Of or pertaining to the earth; proceeding from the earth.
Tampoon: The stopper of a barrel; a bung.
Transfuse: To pour, as liquid, out of one vessel into another; to transfer by pouring.
Thermantidote: A device for circulating and cooling the air, consisting essentially of a kind of roasting fan fitted in a window and incased in wet tatties.
Trackage: The act of tracking, or towing, as a boat; towage.
Trustee: To commit (property) to the care of a trustee; as, to trustee an estate.
Three-piled: Having the quality of three-pile; best; most costly.
Tetrachord: A scale series of four sounds, of which the extremes, or first and last, constituted a fourth. These extremes were immutable; the two middle sounds were changeable.
Tabloid: Compressed or condensed, as into a tabloid; administrated in or as in tabloids, or small condensed bits; as, a tabloid form of imparting information.
Tellurhydric: Of, pertaining to, or designating, hydrogen telluride, which is regarded as an acid, especially when in solution.
Toggle: To change the value of (a program variable) by activating a toggle switch; as, to toggle the view from character to graphic mode; to toggle the keyboard input from insert to overtype mode.
Tentative: An essay; a trial; an experiment.
Transposition: The act of transposing, or the state of being transposed.
Three-port: Having three ports; specif.: Designating a type of two-cycle internal-combustion engine in which the mixture enters the crank case through a port uncovered by the piston near the end of its stroke.
Timesaving: Saving time; as, a timesaving expedient.
Thermoelectricity: Electricity developed in the action of heat. See the Note under Electricity.
Thible: A slice; a skimmer; a spatula; a pudding stick.
Tough-pitch: The exact state or quality of texture and consistency of well reduced and refined copper.
Tush: A long, pointed tooth; a tusk; -- applied especially to certain teeth of horses.
Triform: Having a triple form or character.
Trounce: To punish or beat severely; to whip smartly; to flog; to castigate.
Tarantula: Any one of several species of large spiders, popularly supposed to be very venomous, especially the European species (Tarantula apuliæ). The tarantulas of Texas and adjacent countries are large species of Mygale.
Tricentenary: Including, or relating to, the interval of three hundred years; tercentenary.
Twelfth-night: The evening of Epiphany, or the twelfth day after Christmas, observed as a festival by various churches.
To-name: A name added, for the sake of distinction, to one's surname, or used instead of it.
Transmutation: The act of transmuting, or the state of being transmuted; as, the transmutation of metals.
Tutelar: Having the guardianship or charge of protecting a person or a thing; guardian; protecting; as, tutelary goddesses.
Tristigmatic: Having, or consisting of, three stigmas.
Thoroughbred: Bred from the best blood through a long line; pure-blooded; -- said of stock, as horses. Hence, having the characteristics of such breeding; mettlesome; courageous; of elegant form, or the like.
Tenaille: An outwork in the main ditch, in front of the curtain, between two bastions. See Illust. of Ravelin.
Theocrasy: A mixture of the worship of different gods, as of Jehovah and idols.
Tipsy: Being under the influence of strong drink; rendered weak or foolish by liquor, but not absolutely or completely drunk; fuddled; intoxicated.
Thermoan\u00e6sthesia: Loss of power to distinguish heat or cold by touch.
Toluidine: Any one of three metameric amido derivatives of toluene analogous to aniline, and called respectively orthtoluidine, metatoluidine, and paratoluidine; especially, the commonest one, or paratoluidine, which is obtained as a white crystalline substance.
Transported: Conveyed from one place to another; figuratively, carried away with passion or pleasure; entranced.
Trichord: An instrument, as a lyre or harp, having three strings.
Terma: The terminal lamina, or thin ventral part, of the anterior wall of the third ventricle of the brain.
Tripinnate: Having bipinnate leaflets arranged on each side of a rhachis.
Tephrite: An igneous rock consisting essentially of plagioclase and either leucite or nephelite, or both.
Tampoe: The edible fruit of an East Indian tree (Baccaurea Malayana) of the Spurge family. It somewhat resembles an apple.
Terpin: A white crystalline substance regarded as a hydrate of oil of turpentine.
Thermoelectric: Pertaining to thermoelectricity; as, thermoelectric currents.
Tank: A large basin or cistern; an artificial receptacle for liquids.
Traps: Small or portable articles for dress, furniture, or use; goods; luggage; things.
technocrat: a technical specialist exercising governmental or managerial authority.
Tang: To make a ringing sound; to ring.
Tipcart: A cart so constructed that the body can be easily tipped, in order to dump the load.
Titlark: Any one of numerous small spring birds belonging to Anthus, Corydalla, and allied genera, which resemble the true larks in color and in having a very long hind claw; especially, the European meadow pipit (Anthus pratensis).
Typhomalarial: Pertaining to typhoid fever and malaria; as, typhomalarial fever, a form of fever having symptoms both of malarial and typhoid fever.
Toscatter: To scatter in pieces; to divide.
Thurification: The act of fuming with incense, or the act of burning incense.
Tonality: The principle of key in music; the character which a composition has by virtue of the key in which it is written, or through the family relationship of all its tones and chords to the keynote, or tonic, of the whole.
Trim: Fitly adjusted; being in good order., or made ready for service or use; firm; compact; snug; neat; fair; as, the ship is trim, or trim built; everything about the man is trim; a person is trim when his body is well shaped and firm; his dress is trim when it fits closely to his body, and appears tight and snug; a man or a soldier is trim when he stands erect.
Trick: To deceive by cunning or artifice; to impose on; to defraud; to cheat; as, to trick another in the sale of a horse.
Trio: Three, considered collectively; three in company or acting together; a set of three; three united.
Trouv\u00e8re: One of a school of poets who flourished in Northern France from the eleventh to the fourteenth century.
Turn: The act of turning; movement or motion about, or as if about, a center or axis; revolution; as, the turn of a wheel.
Toss: A throwing upward, or with a jerk; the act of tossing; as, the toss of a ball.
Trig: A stone, block of wood, or anything else, placed under a wheel or barrel to prevent motion; a scotch; a skid.
Typhoid: Of or pertaining to typhus; resembling typhus; of a low grade like typhus; as, typhoid symptoms.
T cell: A type of white blood cell that circulates in the blood and lymph, and provides cell-mediated immunity for the organism, protecting against infecting cells or the body's own malignant cells; also called T lymphocyte.  There are several types of T cells.  They develop, as do B cells, from progenitor cells in the bone marrow, but are distinguished from B-cells (B-lymphocytes) by their site of differentiation; T-cells mature in the thymus and B-cells in the bone marrow (in birds in the Bursa of Fabricius).  They also have different antigen receptors from those of B-cells. T-cells differentiate into cells that can directly kill infecting cells (cell-mediated immunity, cytotoxity) or activate other cells of the immune system (helper T cells), whereas B-cells differentiate on activation into antibody-secreting plasma cells.   Helper T cells interact with B-cells by secreting lymphokines that stimulate the B cell which have detected a foreign antigen to enter the cell cycle and develop, by repeated mitosis, into a clone of cells with identical receptors, and then to secrete antibodies to that specific antigen.
Talisman: A magical figure cut or engraved under certain superstitious observances of the configuration of the heavens, to which wonderful effects are ascribed; the seal, figure, character, or image, of a heavenly sign, constellation, or planet, engraved on a sympathetic stone, or on a metal corresponding to the star, in order to receive its influence.
Thiotolene: A colorless oily liquid, C4H3S.CH3, analogous to, and resembling, toluene; -- called also methyl thiophene.
Tetrahedral: Having, or composed of, four sides.
Tephroite: A silicate of manganese of an ash-gray color.
Towser: A familiar name for a dog.
Tose: To tease, or comb, as wool.
Target language: the language into which a text is to be translated; -- correlative of source language.
Tappoon: A piece of wood or sheet metal fitted into a ditch to dam up the water so as to overflow a field.
Theatrical: Of or pertaining to a theater, or to the scenic representations; resembling the manner of dramatic performers; histrionic; hence, artificial; as, theatrical performances; theatrical gestures.
Thebaic: Of or pertaining to Thebes in Egypt; specifically, designating a version of the Bible preserved by the Copts, and esteemed of great value by biblical scholars. This version is also called the Sahidic version.
Traditional: Of or pertaining to tradition; derived from tradition; communicated from ancestors to descendants by word only; transmitted from age to age without writing; as, traditional opinions; traditional customs; traditional expositions of the Scriptures.
Thebaid: A Latin epic poem by Statius about Thebes in Bœotia.
Turf: To cover with turf or sod; as, to turf a bank, or the border of a terrace.
Tinman: A manufacturer of tin vessels; a dealer in tinware.
Trinity: The union of three persons (the Father, the Son, and the Holy Ghost) in one Godhead, so that all the three are one God as to substance, but three persons as to individuality.
Triquetrous: Three sided, the sides being plane or concave; having three salient angles or edges; trigonal.
Theriodontia: An extinct order of reptiles found in the Permian and Triassic formations in South Africa. In some respects they resembled carnivorous mammals. Called also Theromorpha.
Tarweed: A name given to several resinous-glandular composite plants of California, esp. to the species of Grindelia, Hemizonia, and Madia.
Thinly: In a thin manner; in a loose, scattered manner; scantily; not thickly; as, ground thinly planted with trees; a country thinly inhabited.
Tapeti: A small South American hare (Lepus Braziliensis).
thank: A expression of gratitude; an acknowledgment expressive of a sense of favor or kindness received; obligation, claim, or desert, or gratitude; -- now generally used in the plural.
Trois point: The third point from the outer edge on each player's home table.
Trifoliate: Having three leaves or leaflets, as clover. See Illust. of Shamrock.
Thesaurus: A treasury or storehouse; hence, a repository, especially of knowledge; -- often applied to a comprehensive work, like a dictionary or cyclopedia.
Trunk piston: In a single-acting engine, an elongated hollow piston, open at the end, in which the end of the connecting rod is pivoted. The piston rod, crosshead and stuffing box are thus dispensed with.
Tripartient: Dividing into three parts; -- said of a number which exactly divides another into three parts.
Transmigrate: To pass from one country or jurisdiction to another for the purpose of residence, as men or families; to migrate.
Teaming: The act or occupation of driving a team, or of hauling or carrying, as logs, goods, or the like, with a team.
Translucent: Transmitting rays of light without permitting objects to be distinctly seen; partially transparent.
Throne: To be in, or sit upon, a throne; to be placed as if upon a throne.
Throng: Thronged; crowded; also, much occupied; busy.
Tamboura: A stringed musical instrument resembling a lute but lacking frets, with a small round body and a long neck, used to produce an accompaniment for singing; -- called also tambur, tambour, and tampur.
Tactics: The science and art of disposing military and naval forces in order for battle, and performing military and naval evolutions. It is divided into grand tactics, or the tactics of battles, and elementary tactics, or the tactics of instruction.
Tonguefish: A flounder (Symphurus plagiusa) native of the southern coast of the United States.
Trestletree: One of two strong bars of timber, fixed horizontally on the opposite sides of the masthead, to support the crosstrees and the frame of the top; -- generally used in the plural.
Tractive: Serving to draw; pulling; attracting; as, tractive power.
Three-leafed: Producing three leaves; as, three-leaved nightshade.
Tachyglossa: A division of monotremes which comprises the spiny ant-eaters of Australia and New Guinea. See Illust. under Echidna.
Totipalmate: Having all four toes united by a web; -- said of certain sea birds, as the pelican and the gannet. See Illust. under Aves.
Tralatition: A change, as in the use of words; a metaphor.
Tortilla: An unleavened cake, as of maize flour, baked on a heated iron or stone.
Tormenting: Causing torment; as, a tormenting dream.
Tubulated: Made in the form of a small tube; provided with a tube, or elongated opening.
Tuneful: Harmonious; melodious; musical; as, tuneful notes.
Triumvir: One of tree men united in public office or authority.
Trecento: The fourteenth century, when applied to Italian art, literature, etc. It marks the period of Dante, Petrarch, and boccaccio in literature, and of Giotto in painting.
Topiary: Of or pertaining to ornamental gardening; produced by cutting, trimming, etc.; topiarian.
Trapezohedral: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, a trapezohedron.
Timid: Wanting courage to meet danger; easily frightened; timorous; not bold; fearful; shy.
Tortuous: Bent in different directions; wreathed; twisted; winding; as, a tortuous train; a tortuous leaf or corolla.
thymus: Of, pertaining to, or designating, the thymus gland.
Teacupful: As much as a teacup can hold; enough to fill a teacup.
Tam-tam: A kind of drum used in the East Indies and other Oriental countries; -- called also tom-tom.
Transfuge: One who flees from one side to another; hence, a deserter; a turncoat; an apostate.
Toe hold: A hold in which the agressor bends back his opponent's foot.
Tonometer: An instrument for determining the rate of vibrations in tones.
Thessalonian: Of or pertaining to Thessalonica, a city of Macedonia.
Tomentose: Covered with matted woolly hairs; as, a tomentose leaf; a tomentose leaf; a tomentose membrane.
Therapeut\u00e6: A name given to certain ascetics said to have anciently dwelt in the neighborhood of Alexandria. They are described in a work attributed to Philo, the genuineness and credibility of which are now much discredited.
Tangle: Any large blackish seaweed, especially the Laminaria saccharina. See Kelp.
Tasimer: An instrument for detecting or measuring minute extensions or movements of solid bodies. It consists essentially of a small rod, disk, or button of carbon, forming part of an electrical circuit, the resistance of which, being varied by the changes of pressure produced by the movements of the object to be measured, causes variations in the strength of the current, which variations are indicated by a sensitive galvanometer. It is also used for measuring minute changes of temperature.
Tolerability: The quality or state of being tolerable.
Tauriform: Having the form of a bull.
Trichinize: To render trichinous; to affect with trichinæ; -- chiefly used in the past participle; as, trichinized pork.
Thermophore: An apparatus for conveying heat, as a case containing material which retains its heat for a considerable period.
Taciturnity: Habitual silence, or reserve in speaking.
Tetraphyllous: Having four leaves; consisting of four distinct leaves or leaflets.
Trophosome: The nutritive zooids of a hydroid, collectively, as distinguished from the gonosome, or reproductive zooids.
Transcription: The act or process of transcribing, or copying; as, corruptions creep into books by repeated transcriptions.
Thimbleeye: The chub mackerel. See under Chub.
Touter: One who seeks customers, as for an inn, a public conveyance, shops, and the like: hence, an obtrusive candidate for office.
Translucence: The quality or state of being translucent; clearness; partial transparency.
Tritiated: containing tritium; -- of chemical compounds; as, tritiated thymine.
Teated: Having protuberances resembling the teat of an animal.
Tectibranch: One of the Tectibranchiata. Also used adjectively.
Ticklenburg: A coarse, mixed linen fabric made to be sold in the West Indies.
Tim-whiskey: A kind of carriage. See Whiskey.
Turfman: A turfite; a votary of the turf, or race course.
Tamable: Capable of being tamed, subdued, or reclaimed from wildness or savage ferociousness.
Triadelphous: Having stamens joined by filaments into three bundles. See Illust. under Adelphous.
Tachydidaxy: A short or rapid method of instructing.
Throb: A beat, or strong pulsation, as of the heart and arteries; a violent beating; a papitation:
Taurylic: Pertaining to, or designating, an acid found of a urine of neat cattle, and probably identical with cresol.
Tripartite: Divided into three parts; triparted; as, a tripartite leaf.
Trolley: A form of truck which can be tilted, for carrying railroad materials, or the like.
Tilley: The seeds of a small tree (Croton Pavana) common in the Malay Archipelago. These seeds furnish croton oil, like those of Croton Tiglium.
Treasonable: Pertaining to treason; consisting of treason; involving the crime of treason, or partaking of its guilt.
Throw: The act of hurling or flinging; a driving or propelling from the hand or an engine; a cast.
Thready: Like thread or filaments; slender; as, the thready roots of a shrub.
Tinger: One who, or that which, tinges.
Terminus: Literally, a boundary; a border; a limit.
Theater: An edifice in which dramatic performances or spectacles are exhibited for the amusement of spectators; anciently uncovered, except the stage, but in modern times roofed.
Tanyard: An inclosure where the tanning of leather is carried on; a tannery.
Temptable: Capable of being tempted; liable to be tempted.
Tenemental: Of or pertaining to a tenement; capable of being held by tenants.
Tullian: Belonging to, or in the style of, Tully (Marcus Tullius Cicero).
Torsion galvanometer: A galvanometer in which current is measured by torsion.
Trochoid: Admitting of rotation on an axis; -- sometimes applied to a pivot joint like that between the atlas and axis in the vertebral column.
Transportation: The act of transporting, or the state of being transported; carriage from one place to another; removal; conveyance.
Tetrahexahedron: A solid in the isometric system, bounded by twenty-four equal triangular faces, four corresponding to each face of the cube.
Tatting: A kind of lace made from common sewing thread, with a peculiar stitch.
Truncus: The thorax of an insect. See Trunk, n., 5.
Trigone: A smooth triangular area on the inner surface of the bladder, limited by the apertures of the ureters and urethra.
Titan crane: A massive crane with an overhanging counterbalanced arm carrying a traveler and lifting crab, the whole supported by a carriage mounted on track rails.  It is used esp. for setting heavy masonry blocks for piers, breakwaters, etc.
Tumble: Act of tumbling, or rolling over; a fall.
Tigers-foot: A name given to some species of morning-glory (Ipomœa) having the leaves lobed in pedate fashion.
Tournament: A mock fight, or warlike game, formerly in great favor, in which a number of combatants were engaged, as an exhibition of their address and bravery; hence, figuratively, a real battle.
Titaniferous: Containing or affording titanium; as, titaniferous magnetite.
Toreumatology: The art or the description of scupture such as bas-relief in metal; toreumatography.
Tee-to-tum: A workingmen's resort conducted under religious influences as a counteractant to the drinking saloon.
Tobine: A stout twilled silk used for dresses.
Tearful: Abounding with tears; weeping; shedding tears; as, tearful eyes.
Thwarter: A disease in sheep, indicated by shaking, trembling, or convulsive motions.
Tribromophenol: A colorless crystalline substance (C6H3OBr3) prepared by the reaction of carbolic acid with bromine.  The predominant isomer is 2,4,6-tribromophenol; -- called also bromol.
Triple: To make threefold, or thrice as much or as many; to treble; as, to triple the tax on coffee.
Terebratula: A genus of brachiopods which includes many living and some fossil species. The larger valve has a perforated beak, through which projects a short peduncle for attachment. Called also lamp shell.
Tombstone: A stone erected over a grave, to preserve the memory of the deceased.
Tenantable: Fit to be rented; in a condition suitable for a tenant.
Twibilled: Armed or provided with a twibil or twibils.
Therm: one of several units of heat, especially one equivalent to 1000 large calories, or 100,000 British thermal units.
Tensor: A muscle that stretches a part, or renders it tense.
Trolley car: A motor car powered by electricity drawn from a trolley, and thus constrained to follow the trolley lines.
Tasting: The act of perceiving or tasting by the organs of taste; the faculty or sense by which we perceive or distinguish savors.
Therf: Not fermented; unleavened; -- said of bread, loaves, etc.
Thammuz: A deity among the ancient Syrians, in honor of whom the Hebrew idolatresses held an annual lamentation. This deity has been conjectured to be the same with the Phœnician Adon, or Adonis.
Towrope: A rope used in towing vessels.
Topsoil: The upper layer of soil; surface soil.
Trunk steamer: A freight steamer having a high hatch coaming extending almost continuously fore and aft, but not of whaleback form at the sides.
Terzetto: A composition in three voice parts; a vocal (rarely an instrumental) trio.
Targeted: Furnished, armed, or protected, with a target.
Tuition: Superintending care over a young person; the particular watch and care of a tutor or guardian over his pupil or ward; guardianship.
Transplace: To remove across some space; to put in an opposite or another place.
Tempean: Of or pertaining to Temple, a valley in Thessaly, celebrated by Greek poets on account of its beautiful scenery; resembling Temple; hence, beautiful; delightful; charming.
Thorough-lighted: Provided with thorough lights or windows at opposite sides, as a room or building.
Taglioni: A kind of outer coat, or overcoat; -- said to be so named after a celebrated Italian family of professional dancers.
Thirstiness: The state of being thirsty; thirst.
Tickseed: A seed or fruit resembling in shape an insect, as that of certain plants.
Tablecloth: A cloth for covering a table, especially one with which a table is covered before the dishes, etc., are set on for meals.
Trisaccharide: A complex sugar, as raffinose, yielding by hydrolysis three simple sugar molecules.
thaw: The melting of ice, snow, or other congealed matter; the resolution of ice, or the like, into the state of a fluid; liquefaction by heat of anything congealed by frost; also, a warmth of weather sufficient to melt that which is congealed.
Tympanum: The ear drum, or middle ear. Sometimes applied incorrectly to the tympanic membrane. See Ear.
Tomcat: A male cat, especially when full grown or of large size.
Tessellation: The act of tessellating; also, the mosaic work so formed.
Thanage: The district in which a thane anciently had jurisdiction; thanedom.
Trachearia: A division of Arachnida including those that breathe only by means of tracheæ. It includes the mites, ticks, false scorpions, and harvestmen.
Tectology: A division of morphology created by Haeckel; the science of organic individuality constituting the purely structural portion of morphology, in which the organism is regarded as composed of organic individuals of different orders, each organ being considered an individual. See Promorphology, and Morphon.
Ton mile: A unit of measurement of the freight transportation performed by a railroad during a given period, usually a year, the total of which consists of the sum of the products obtained by multiplying the aggregate weight of each shipment in tons during the given period by the number of miles for which it is carried.
Thill: One of the two long pieces of wood, extending before a vehicle, between which a horse is hitched; a shaft.
Trap shooting: Shooting at pigeons liberated, or glass balls or clay pigeons sprung into the air, from a trap.
Thinner: One who thins, or makes thinner.
Titrate: To analyse, or determine the strength of, by means of standard solutions.  Cf. Standardized solution, under Solution.
Tough: Having the quality of flexibility without brittleness; yielding to force without breaking; capable of resisting great strain; as, the ligaments of animals are remarkably tough.
Thither: Being on the farther side from the person speaking; farther; -- a correlative of hither; as, on the thither side of the water.
Torso: The human body, as distinguished from the head and limbs; in sculpture, the trunk of a statue, mutilated of head and limbs; as, the torso of Hercules.
Tuna: Any one of several species of large oceanic fishes belonging to the mackerel family Scombridae, especially the bluefin tuna (Thunnus thynnus, formerly Orcynus thynnus or Albacora thynnus), called also the common tunny or great tunny, a native of the Mediterranean Sea and of temperate parts of the Atlantic Ocean.  It sometimes weighs a thousand pounds or more, and is caught commercially in large quantity for use as food; -- also called, especially in Britain, tunny.  It is also one of the favorite fishes used by the Japanese in preparing sushi.  On the American coast, especially in New England, it is sometimes called the horse mackerel.  Another well-known species is the yellowfin tuna (Thunnus albacares) of warm seas. the See Illust. of Horse mackerel, under Horse.
Transumpt: A copy or exemplification of a record; a transcript.
Topical: Of or pertaining to a place; limited; logical application; as, a topical remedy; a topical claim or privilege.
Tug: A pull with the utmost effort, as in the athletic contest called tug of war; a supreme effort.
Tenderloin: A strip of tender flesh on either side of the vertebral column under the short ribs, in the hind quarter of beef and pork. It consists of the psoas muscles.
True-blue: A person of inflexible integrity or fidelity.
Trappous: Of or performance to trap; resembling trap, or partaking of its form or qualities; trappy.
Timepleaser: One who complies with prevailing opinions, whatever they may be; a timeserver.
Tune: To form one sound to another; to form accordant musical sounds.
Trough-shell: Any bivalve shell of the genus Mactra. See Mactra.
Tlinkit: The Indians of a seafaring group of tribes of southern Alaska comprising the Koluschan stock. Previous to deterioration from contact with the whites they were the foremost traders of the northwest. They built substantial houses of cedar adorned with  totem poles, and were expert stone carvers and copper workers. Slavery, the potlatch, and the use of immense labrets were characteristic. Many now work in the salmon industry.
Titillation: The act of tickling, or the state of being tickled; a tickling sensation.
Transmew: To transmute; to transform; to metamorphose.
Typical: Of the nature of a type; representing something by a form, model, or resemblance; emblematic; prefigurative.
Tacamahac: A bitter balsamic resin obtained from tropical American trees of the genus Elaphrium (Elaphrium tomentosum and Elaphrium Tacamahaca), and also from East Indian trees of the genus Calophyllum; also, the resinous exhudation of the balsam poplar.
Therapeutics: That part of medical science which treats of the discovery and application of remedies for diseases.
Tule: A large bulrush (Scirpus lacustris, and Scirpus Tatora) growing abundantly on overflowed land in California and elsewhere.
Trampler: One who tramples; one who treads down; as, a trampler on nature's law.
Tithingman: The chief man of a tithing; a headborough; one elected to preside over the tithing.
Turbinaceous: Of or pertaining to peat, or turf; of the nature of peat, or turf; peaty; turfy.
Triduan: Lasting three lays; also, happening every third day.
Tame: To reduce from a wild to a domestic state; to make gentle and familiar; to reclaim; to domesticate; as, to tame a wild beast.
Troupe: A company or troop, especially the company pf performers in a play or an opera.
Thermometer: An instrument for measuring temperature, founded on the principle that changes of temperature in bodies are accompanied by proportional changes in their volumes or dimensions.
Teetotum: A child's toy, somewhat resembling a top, and twirled by the fingers.
Tamp: In blasting, to plug up with clay, earth, dry sand, sod, or other material, as a hole bored in a rock, in order to prevent the force of the explosion from being misdirected.
ticker tape parade: A parade to honor a person or persons, held in New York City, during which people in the tall buildings of Manhattan throw large quantities of paper, confetti, paper ribbons, or the like onto the parading group.  The name comes form the ticker tape originally thrown onto the parade when it passed stockbrokers' offices in lower Manhattan, before stock tickers became obsolete; in subsequent years other types of waste paper were used to serve the honorary function, as well as paper tape distributed specifically for the purpose of being thrown in such a parade.
Thoracotomy: The operation of opening the pleural cavity by incision.
Teeter-tail: The spotted sandpiper. See the Note under Sandpiper.
Tylarus: One of the pads on the under surface of the toes of birds.
Truttaceous: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, a trout; as, fish of the truttaceous kind.
Time signature: A sign at the beginning of a composition or movement, placed after the key signature, to indicate its time or meter. Also called rhythmical signature. It is in the form of a fraction, of which the denominator indicates the kind of note taken as time unit for the beat, and the numerator, the number of these to the measure.
To-brest: To burst or break in pieces.
Tannage: A tanning; the act, operation, or result of tanning.
Teleological: Of or pertaining to teleology, or the doctrine of design.
Touch-paper: Paper steeped in saltpeter, which burns slowly, and is used as a match for firing gunpowder, and the like.
Trusteeship: The office or duty of a trustee.
Teapoy: An ornamental stand, usually with three legs, having caddies for holding tea.
Thryfallow: To plow for the third time in summer; to trifallow.
