Tunicin: Animal cellulose; a substance present in the mantle, or tunic, of the Tunicates, which resembles, or is identical with, the cellulose of the vegetable kingdom.
Telepathy: The sympathetic affection of one mind by the thoughts, feelings, or emotions of another at a distance, without communication through the ordinary channels of sensation.
Trecentist: A member of the trecento, or an imitator of its characteristics.
Turbulence: The quality or state of being turbulent; a disturbed state; tumult; disorder; agitation.
Tollgate: A gate where toll is taken.
Teapot: A vessel with a spout, in which tea is made, and from which it is poured into teacups.
Tres-tyne: In the antler of a stag, the third tyne above the base. This tyne appears in the third year. In those deer in which the brow tyne does not divide, the tres-tyne is the second tyne above the base. See Illust. under Rucervine, and under Rusine.
Throatwort: A plant (Campanula Trachelium) formerly considered a remedy for sore throats because of its throat-shaped corolla.
Tuberculous: Pertaining to, or affected with, a tuberculosis.
Tangram: A Chinese toy made by cutting a square of thin wood, or other suitable material, into seven pieces, as shown in the cut, these pieces being capable of combination in various ways, so as to form a great number of different figures. It is now often used in primary schools as a means of instruction.
Thule: The name given by ancient geographers to the northernmost part of the habitable world. According to some, this land was Norway, according to others, Iceland, or more probably Mainland, the largest of the Shetland islands; hence, the Latin phrase ultima Thule, farthest Thule.
Thorn: To prick, as with a thorn.
Theopathy: Capacity for religious affections or worship.
Trophonian: Of or pertaining to Trophonius, his architecture, or his cave and oracle.
Texas Leaguer: A short fly that falls too far out to be handled by an infielder and too close in to be caught by an outfielder; -- called also Texas league single.
Tankard: A large drinking vessel, especially one with a cover.
Tetrarchy: The district under a Roman tetrarch; the office or jurisdiction of a tetrarch; a tetrarchate.
Tercentenary: Including, or relating to, an interval of three hundred years.
Ternary: A ternion; the number three; three things taken together; a triad.
Targeteer: One who is armed with a target or shield.
Turbary: A right of digging turf on another man's land; also, the ground where turf is dug.
Tripudiary: Of or pertaining to dancing; performed by dancing.
Tarsectomy: The operation of excising one or more of the bones of the tarsus.
Trainer: One who trains; an instructor; especially, one who trains or prepares men, horses, etc., for exercises requiring physical agility and strength.
Trust: To have trust; to be credulous; to be won to confidence; to confide.
Tympanitis: Inflammation of the lining membrane of the middle ear.
Turningness: The quality of turning; instability; tergiversation.
Torque: A collar or neck chain, usually twisted, especially as worn by ancient barbaric nations, as the Gauls, Germans, and Britons.
Tamias: A genus of ground squirrels, including the chipmunk.
Tubeworm: Any annelid which constructs a tube; one of the Tubicolæ.
Telemeter: An instrument used for measuring the distance of an object from an observer; as, a telescope with a micrometer for measuring the apparent diameter of an object whose real dimensions are known.
Tensile: Of or pertaining to extension; as, tensile strength.
Titanous: Designating certain compounds of titanium in which that element has a lower valence as contrasted with titanic compounds.
Tubulation: The act of shaping or making a tube, or of providing with a tube; also, a tube or tubulure; as, the tubulation of a retort.
Trilemma: A syllogism with three conditional propositions, the major premises of which are disjunctively affirmed in the minor. See Dilemma.
Toret: A ring for fastening a hawk's leash to the jesses; also, a ring affixed to the collar of a dog, etc.
Tachygraphic: Of or pertaining to tachygraphy; written in shorthand.
Tarragon: A plant of the genus Artemisa (Artemisa dracunculus), much used in France for flavoring vinegar.
Toleration: The act of tolerating; the allowance of that which is not wholly approved.
Trite: Worn out; common; used until so common as to have lost novelty and interest; hackneyed; stale; as, a trite remark; a trite subject.
Thorough: A furrow between two ridges, to drain off the surface water.
Trigeminous: Born three together; being one of three born at the same birth; also, threefold.
Test: The external hard or firm covering of many invertebrate animals.
Tracing: The act of one who traces; especially, the act of copying by marking on thin paper, or other transparent substance, the lines of a pattern placed beneath; also, the copy thus producted.
Trichromatic: Having or existing in three different phases of color; having three distinct color varieties; -- said of certain birds and insects.
Togated: Dressed in a toga or gown; wearing a gown; gowned.
Triptych: Anything in three parts or leaves.
Treadle: The part of a foot lathe, or other machine, which is pressed or moved by the foot.
Tsetse: A venomous two-winged African fly (Glossina morsitans) whose bite is very poisonous, and even fatal, to horses and cattle, but harmless to men. It renders extensive districts in which it abounds uninhabitable during certain seasons of the year.
Turnwrest: Designating a cumbersome style of plow used in England, esp. in Kent.
Timidity: The quality or state of being timid; timorousness; timidness.
Tripestone: A variety of anhydrite composed of contorted plates fancied to resemble pieces of tripe.
Tartareous: Consisting of tartar; of the nature of tartar.
Tanist: In Ireland, a lord or proprietor of a tract of land or of a castle, elected by a family, under the system of tanistry.
Typification: The act of typifying, or representing by a figure.
Topflight: unexcelled; of the highest grade; of greatest skill; exhibiting excellence; a topflight performance.
Topsy-turvy: In an inverted posture; with the top or head downward; upside down; as, to turn a carriage topsy-turvy.
Twinkle: A closing or opening, or a quick motion, of the eye; a wink or sparkle of the eye.
Tonguing: Modification of tone for a rapid staccato effect by the performer's tongue, in playing a wind instrument, as a flute. In single tonguing only one kind of stroke is used, the tongue articulating a rapid “t;” in double tonguing, two strokes, as for “t” and “k,” are alternated; in triple tonguing, “t, k, t,” etc.
Telling: Operating with great effect; effective; as, a telling speech.
Translation: The act of translating, removing, or transferring; removal; also, the state of being translated or removed; as, the translation of Enoch; the translation of a bishop.
Tonnihood: The female of the bullfinch; -- called also tonyhoop.
Tellina: A genus of marine bivalve mollusks having thin, delicate, and often handsomely colored shells.
Telephonically: By telephonic means or processes; by the use of the telephone.
Telfordize: To furnish (a road) with a telford pavement.
Tertium quid: A third somewhat; something mediating, or regarded as being, between two diverse or incompatible substances, natures, or positions.
Thallene: A hydrocarbon obtained from coal-tar residues, and remarkable for its intense yellowish green fluorescence.
Trapezium: A plane figure bounded by four right lines, of which no two are parallel.
Triple-headed: Having three heads; three-headed; as, the triple-headed dog Cerberus.
Tridimensional: Having three dimensions; extended in three different directions.
Tiger-eye: A siliceous stone of a yellow color and chatoyant luster, obtained in South Africa and much used for ornament. It is an altered form of the mineral crocidolite. See Crocidolite.
Trunk: To lop off; to curtail; to truncate; to maim.
Technician: a person trained or skilled in the technical details of a particular art or science, especially one skilled at operating, maintaining, or repairing equipment, in contrast to the theory or informational content of a craft; -- formerly also called a technicist.
Tagalog: Any member of a certain tribe which is one of the leading and most civilized of those native of the Philippine Islands.
telekinesis: the ability to move objects by means of thought alone, without physical means; -- an ability claimed by certain persons, such as mediums.
Tasset: A defense for the front of the thigh, consisting of one or more iron plates hanging from the belt on the lower edge of the corselet.
Tricuspid: Having three cusps, or points; tricuspidate; as, a tricuspid molar.
Trice: A very short time; an instant; a moment; -- now used only in the phrase in a trice.
Triton: A fabled sea demigod, the son of Neptune and Amphitrite, and the trumpeter of Neptune.  He is represented by poets and painters as having the upper part of his body like that of a man, and the lower part like that of a fish. He often has a trumpet made of a shell.
Transplanter: One who transplants; also, a machine for transplanting trees.
Trifarious: Facing three ways; arranged in three vertical ranks, as the leaves of veratrum.
Tricrotism: That condition of the arterial pulse in which there is a triple beat. The pulse curve obtained in the sphygmographic tracing characteristic of tricrotism shows two secondary crests in addition to the primary.
Tautochrone: A curved line, such that a heavy body, descending along it by the action of gravity, will always arrive at the lowest point in the same time, wherever in the curve it may begin to fall; as, an inverted cycloid with its base horizontal is a tautochrone.
Triarchy: Government by three persons; a triumvirate; also, a country under three rulers.
Tormentor: One who, or that which, torments; one who inflicts penal anguish or tortures.
Tarsius: A genus of nocturnal lemurine mammals having very large eyes and ears, a long tail, and very long proximal tarsal bones; -- called also malmag, spectral lemur, podji, and tarsier.
Toccata: An old form of piece for the organ or harpsichord, somewhat in the free and brilliant style of the prelude, fantasia, or capriccio.
Tuesday: The third day of the week, following Monday and preceding Wednesday.
Tappit hen: A hen having a tuft of feathers on her head.
Tabard: A sort of tunic or mantle formerly worn for protection from the weather. When worn over the armor it was commonly emblazoned with the arms of the wearer, and from this the name was given to the garment adopted for heralds.
Toughen: To grow or make tough, or tougher.
Twitter: The act of twittering; a small, tremulous, intermitted noise, as that made by a swallow.
Tendency: Direction or course toward any place, object, effect, or result; drift; causal or efficient influence to bring about an effect or result.
Tactile: Of or pertaining to the organs, or the sense, of touch; perceiving, or perceptible, by the touch; capable of being touched; as, tactile corpuscles; tactile sensations.
tribo-: a combining form relating to friction.
Tribometer: An instrument to ascertain the degree of friction in rubbing surfaces.
Turcoman: A member of a tribe of Turanians inhabiting a region east of the Caspian Sea.
Thickness: The quality or state of being thick (in any of the senses of the adjective).
Tergiferous: Carrying or bearing upon the back.
Timbering: The act of furnishing with timber; also, timbers, collectively; timberwork; timber.
Three-valved: Consisting of, or having, three valves; opening with three valves; as, a three-valved pericarp.
Tolerance: The power or capacity of enduring; the act of enduring; endurance.
Traverse drill: A machine tool for drilling slots, in which the work or tool has a lateral motion back and forth; also, a drilling machine in which the spindle holder can be adjusted laterally.
Tercelet: A male hawk or eagle; a tiercelet.
Top-dressing: The act of applying a dressing of manure to the surface of land; also, manure so applied.
Trumpet: To sound loudly, or with a tone like a trumpet; to utter a trumplike cry.
Telemachus: The son of Odysseus and Penelope, as told in Homer's Oddysey.
Tinnitus: A ringing, whistling, or other imaginary noise perceived in the ears; -- called also tinnitus aurium.
That: As a demonstrative pronoun (pl. Those), that usually points out, or refers to, a person or thing previously mentioned, or supposed to be understood. That, as a demonstrative, may precede the noun to which it refers; as, that which he has said is true; those in the basket are good apples.
Trimorphism: The property of crystallizing in three forms fundamentally distinct, as is the case with titanium dioxide, which crystallizes in the forms of rutile, octahedrite, and brookite. See Pleomorphism.
Thalamus: A mass of nervous matter on either side of the third ventricle of the brain; -- called also optic thalamus.
Toman: A money of account in Persia, whose value varies greatly at different times and places. Its average value may be reckoned at about two and a half dollars.
Tavern: A public house where travelers and other transient guests are accomodated with rooms and meals; an inn; a hotel; especially, in modern times, a public house licensed to sell liquor in small quantities.
Tenfold: In tens; consisting of ten in one; ten times repeated.
Twittering: The act of one who, or that which, twitters.
Tangibility: The quality or state of being tangible.
Thelphusian: One of a tribe of fresh-water crabs which live in or on the banks of rivers in tropical countries.
Thermometrically: In a thermometrical manner; by means of a thermometer.
Thai: Of or pertaining to the Thai language, a member of the Tai group of languages.
Trope: The use of a word or expression in a different sense from that which properly belongs to it; the use of a word or expression as changed from the original signification to another, for the sake of giving life or emphasis to an idea; a figure of speech.
Trothplight: The act of betrothing, or plighting faith; betrothing.
Tympany: A flatulent distention of the belly; tympanites.
Target: A kind of small shield or buckler, used as a defensive weapon in war.
Travertine: A white concretionary form of calcium carbonate, usually hard and semicrystalline. It is deposited from the water of springs or streams holding lime in solution. Extensive deposits exist at Tivoli, near Rome.
Treasury stock: Issued stock of an incorporated company held by the company itself.
Tear: The act of tearing, or the state of being torn; a rent; a fissure.
Transfusible: Capable of being transfused; transferable by transfusion.
Tubiporite: Any fossil coral of the genus Syringopora consisting of a cluster of upright tubes united together by small transverse tubules.
Teat: The protuberance through which milk is drawn from the udder or breast of a mammal; a nipple; a pap; a mammilla; a dug; a tit.
Turbidly: In a turbid manner; with muddiness or confusion.
Teak: A tree of East Indies (Tectona grandis) which furnishes an extremely strong and durable timber highly valued for shipbuilding and other purposes; also, the timber of the tree.
Tipple: An apparatus by which loaded cars are emptied by tipping; also, the place where such tipping is done.
Trabea: A toga of purple, or ornamented with purple horizontal stripes. -- worn by kings, consuls, and augurs.
Teal: Any one of several species of small fresh-water ducks of the genus Anas and the subgenera Querquedula and Nettion. The male is handsomely colored, and has a bright green or blue speculum on the wings.
Team: To convey or haul with a team; as, to team lumber.
Tettigonian: Any one of numerous species of Hemiptera belonging to Tettigonia and allied genera; a leaf hopper.
Three-mile: Of or pertaining to three miles; as, the three-mile limit, or the limit of the marine belt (the three-mile belt or three-mile zone) of three miles included in territorial waters (which see) of a state.
Turks-head: A knot of turbanlike form  worked on a rope with a piece of small line.
Troop: To move in numbers; to come or gather in crowds or troops.
Tebeth: The tenth month of the Jewish ecclesiastical year, answering to a part of December with a part of January.
turbo-: Sontaining or using a turbine; -- a combining form; as, turbojet.
Tamoxifen: a chemical compound (C26H29NO) which is non-steroidal but physiogically active as an estrogen antagonist.  It is used to treat postmenopausal breast cancer.  Chemically it is 1-p-dimethylaminoethoxyphenyl-trans-1,2-diphenyl-but-1-ene. It can be obtained as a white crystalline powder.
Thrack: To load or burden; as, to thrack a man with property.
Thecophora: A division of hydroids comprising those which have the hydranths in thecæ and the gonophores in capsules. The campanularians and sertularians are examples. Called also Thecata. See Illust. under Hydroidea.
Tubulidentate: Having teeth traversed by canals; -- said of certain edentates.
Transportment: The act of transporting, or the state of being transported; transportation.
Through: Going or extending through; going, extending, or serving from the beginning to the end; thorough; complete; as, a through line; a through ticket; a through train.  Also, admitting of passage through; as, a through bridge.
Tuberculocidin: A special substance contained in tuberculin, supposed to be the active agent of the latter freed from various impurities.
Tenace: The holding by the fourth hand of the best and third best cards of a suit led; also, sometimes, the combination of best with third best card of a suit in any hand.
Turbine: A water wheel, commonly horizontal, variously constructed, but usually having a series of curved floats or buckets, against which the water acts by its impulse or reaction in flowing either outward from a central chamber, inward from an external casing, or from above downward, etc.; -- also called turbine wheel.
Taskmaster: One who imposes a task, or burdens another with labor; one whose duty is to assign tasks; an overseer.
Tutorial: Of or pertaining to a tutor; belonging to, or exercised by, a tutor.
Tylosis: An intrusion of one vegetable cell into the cavity of another, sometimes forming there an irregular mass of cells.
Two-way: Serving to connect at will one pipe or channel with either of two others; as, a two-way cock.
Trilithon: A monument consisting of three stones; especially, such a monument forming a kind of doorway, as among the ancient Celts.
Tendance: The act of attending or waiting; attendance.
Truantship: The conduct of a truant; neglect of employment; idleness; truancy.
Trash: To follow with violence and trampling.
Travel: The act of traveling, or journeying from place to place; a journey.
Thunderproof: Secure against the effects of thunder or lightning.
Tender-hearted: Having great sensibility; susceptible of impressions or influence; affectionate; pitying; sensitive.
Transitorily: In a transitory manner; with brief continuance.
Tutty: A yellow or brown amorphous substance obtained as a sublimation product in the flues of smelting furnaces of zinc, and consisting of a crude zinc oxide.
Taskwork: Work done as a task; also, work done by the job; piecework.
Testaceous: Of or pertaining to shells; consisted of a hard shell, or having a hard shell.
Tutoress: A woman who performs the duties of a tutor; an instructress.
Thermochroic: Pertaining to or designating heat rays that have undergone selective absorption and are therefore analogous to colored light rays.
Turnip-shell: Any one of several large, thick, spiral marine shells belonging to Rapa and allied genera, somewhat turnip-shaped.
Transformable: Capable of being transformed or changed.
Titanotherium: A large American Miocene mammal, allied to the rhinoceros, and more nearly to the extinct Brontotherium.
Tanka: A kind of boat used in Canton. It is about 25 feet long and is often rowed by women. Called also tankia.
Tricennial: Of or pertaining to thirty years; consisting of thirty years; occurring once in every thirty years.
Transubstantiator: One who maintains the doctrine of transubstantiation.
Tendrac: Any one of several species of small insectivores of the family Centetidæ, belonging to Ericulus, Echinope, and related genera, native of Madagascar. They are more or less spinose and resemble the hedgehog in habits. The rice tendrac (Oryzorictes hora) is very injurious to rice crops. Some of the species are called also tenrec.
Tractability: The quality or state of being tractable or docile; docility; tractableness.
Trender: One whose business is to free wool from its filth.
Tenancy: A holding, or a mode of holding, an estate; tenure; the temporary possession of what belongs to another.
Typhoon: A violent whirlwind; specifically, a violent whirlwind occurring in the Chinese seas.
Tail-bay: One of the joists which rest one end on the wall and the other on a girder; also, the space between a wall and the nearest girder of a floor.  Cf. Case-bay.
Thinolite: A calcareous tufa, in part crystalline, occurring on a large scale as a shore deposit about the Quaternary lake basins of Nevada.
Transnatation: The act of swimming across, as a river.
Tripping: Act of one who, or that which, trips.
Timocratic: Belonging to, or constituted by, timocracy.
Triploidite: A manganese phosphate near triplite, but containing hydroxyl instead of fluorine.
Tangible: Perceptible to the touch; tactile; palpable.
Tranquil: Quiet; calm; undisturbed; peaceful; not agitated; as, the atmosphere is tranquil; the condition of the country is tranquil.
Trail: A track left by man or beast; a track followed by the hunter; a scent on the ground by the animal pursued; as, a deer trail.
Touchback: The act of touching the football down by a player behind his own goal line when it received its last impulse from an opponent; -- distinguished from safety touchdown.
Tartness: The quality or state of being tart.
Theatral: Of or pertaining to a theater; theatrical.
Together: In company or association with respect to place or time; as, to live together in one house; to live together in the same age; they walked together to the town.
Trubu: An East India herring (Clupea toli) which is extensively caught for the sake of its roe and for its flesh.
Technics: The doctrine of arts in general; such branches of learning as respect the arts.
Toparchy: A small state, consisting of a few cities or towns; a petty country governed by a toparch; as, Judea was formerly divided into ten toparchies.
Theurgic: Of or pertaining to theurgy; magical.
Tetracid: Capable of neutralizing four molecules of a monobasic acid; having four hydrogen atoms capable of replacement ba acids or acid atoms; -- said of certain bases; thus, erythrine, C4H6(OH)4, is a tetracid alcohol.
Tumescence: The act of becoming tumid; the state of being swollen; intumescence; -- applied especially to the state of swelling of the vascular tissue in the male and female sex organs when they have been stimulated to readiness for sexual intercourse.
Two-name: Having or bearing two names; as, two-name paper, that is, negotiable paper on which at least two persons are severally liable as separate makers, or, usually, one as maker and one as indorser.
Three-pointed: Having three acute or setigerous points; tricuspidate.
Turrel: A certain tool used by coopers.
Trichotomous: Divided into three parts, or into threes; three-forked; as, a trichotomous stem.
Tubulose: Resembling, or in the form of, a tube; longitudinally hollow; specifically (Bot.), having a hollow cylindrical corolla, often expanded or toothed at the border; as, a tubulose flower.
Tethyodea: A division of Tunicata including the common attached ascidians, both simple and compound. Called also Tethioidea.
Terre-tenant: One who has the actual possession of land; the occupant.
Trekometer: A field range finger used in the British service.
Tributer: One who works for a certain portion of the ore, or its value.
Thecasporous: Having the spores in thecæ, or cases.
Trespass: Any injury or offence done to another.
Thenadays: At that time; then; in those days; -- correlative to nowadays.
Tupaiid: Any one of several species of East Indian and Asiatic insectivores of the family Tupaiidæ, somewhat resembling squirrels in size and arboreal habits.  The nose is long and pointed.
Trimness: The quality or state of being trim; orderliness; compactness; snugness; neatness.
Terebic: Pertaining to, or obtained from, terbenthene (oil of turpentine); specifically, designating an acid, C7H10O4, obtained by the oxidation of terbenthene with nitric acid, as a white crystalline substance.
Tarsometatarsal: Of or pertaining to both the tarsus and metatarsus; as, the tarsometatarsal articulations.
Troilus: A large, handsome American butterfly (Euphœades troilus, or Papilio troilus). It is black, with yellow marginal spots on the front wings, and blue spots on the rear wings; -- also called troilus butterfly.
Toadfish: Any marine fish of the genus Batrachus, having a large, thick head and a wide mouth, and bearing some resemblance to a toad. The American species (Batrachus tau) is very common in shallow water. Called also oyster fish, and sapo.
Theave: A ewe lamb of the first year; also, a sheep three years old.
Transplant: To remove, and plant in another place; as, to transplant trees.
Tetradite: A person in some way remarkable with regard to the number four, as one born on the fourth day of the month, or one who reverenced four persons in the Godhead.
Tregetour: A juggler who produces illusions by the use of elaborate machinery.
Transpire: To excrete through the skin; to give off in the form of vapor; to exhale; to perspire.
Tetradrachm: A silver coin among the ancient Greeks, of the value of four drachms.
Transfer: The act of transferring, or the state of being transferred; the removal or conveyance of a thing from one place or person to another.
Tennis: To drive backward and forward, as a ball in playing tennis.
Twelfth-second: A unit for the measurement of small intervals of time, such that 1012 (ten trillion) of these units make one second.
Twaite: A piece of cleared ground. See Thwaite.
Tinkle: A small, sharp, quick sound, as that made by striking metal.
Tilestone: A kind of laminated shale or sandstone belonging to some of the layers of the Upper Silurian.
Turnicimorph\u00e6: A division of birds including Turnix and allied genera, resembling quails in appearance but differing from them anatomically.
Tribual: Of or relating to a tribe; tribal; as, a tribual characteristic; tribular worship.
Tintinnabulation: A tinkling sound, as of a bell or bells.
Three-pile: An old name for the finest and most costly kind of velvet, having a fine, thick pile.
Tetrasyllabic: Consisting of, or having, four syllables; quadrisyllabic.
Tramroad: A road prepared for easy transit of trams or wagons, by forming the wheel tracks of smooth beams of wood, blocks of stone, or plates of iron.
tchotchke: a knickknack or trinket; a decorative item or souvenir of little value.
Tetradymite: A telluride of bismuth. It is of a pale steel-gray color and metallic luster, and usually occurs in foliated masses. Called also telluric bismuth.
Tegulated: Composed of small plates, as of horn or metal, overlapping like tiles; -- said of a kind of ancient armor.
Toco: A toucan (Ramphastos toco) having a very large beak. See Illust. under Toucan.
Tide-rode: Swung by the tide when at anchor; -- opposed to wind-rode.
Tralation: The use of a word in a figurative or extended sense; ametaphor; a trope.
Telelectric: Of or pertaining to transmission, as of music, to a distance by electricity.
Testoon: An Italian silver coin. The testoon of Rome is worth 1s. 3d. sterling, or about thirty cents.
Trionychoidea: A division of chelonians which comprises Trionyx and allied genera; -- called also Trionychoides, and Trionychina.
Twinning: The assemblage of two or more crystals, or parts of crystals, in reversed position with reference to each other in accordance with some definite law; also, rarely, in artificial twinning (accomplished for example by pressure), the process by which this reversal is brought about.
Tagal: One of a Malayan race, mainly of central Luzon, next to the Visayans the most numerous of the native peoples of the Philippines. Nearly all are Christians and many are highly educated.
taximeter: a meter in a taxi that registers the fare (based on the length of the ride).
Temperate: To render temperate; to moderate; to soften; to temper.
Trachytic: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, trachyte.
Tidder: To use with tenderness; to fondle.
Tartly: In a tart manner; with acidity.
Turmerol: Turmeric oil, a brownish yellow, oily substance extracted from turmeric by ligroin.
Tremex: A genus of large hymenopterous insects allied to the sawflies. The female lays her eggs in holes which she bores in the trunks of trees with her large and long ovipositor, and the larva bores in the wood. See Illust. of Horntail.
Tarantulated: Bitten by a tarantula; affected with tarantism.
Turdus: A genus of singing birds including the true thrushes.
Top-drain: To drain the surface of, as land; as, to top-drain a field or farm.
Truthless: Devoid of truth; dishonest; dishonest; spurious; faithless.
Triangle: A figure bounded by three lines, and containing three angles.
Temper: To accord; to agree; to act and think in conformity.
Tranquilness: Quality or state of being tranquil.
Tithonometer: An instrument or apparatus for measuring or detecting tithonicity; an actinometer.
Tikur: An East Indian tree (Garcinia pedunculata) having a large yellow fleshy fruit with a pleasant acid flavor.
Tegmental: Of or pertaining to a tegument or tegmentum; as, the tegmental layer of the epiblast; the tegmental cells of the taste buds.
Tamerlane: A Tatar conquerer, also called Timur or Timour (tē*môr") or Timur Bey, also Timur-Leng ('Timur the Lame'), which was corrupted to Tamerlane.  He was born in Central Asia, 1333: died 1405.  Though he claimed descent from Jenghiz Khan, it is believed that he was in fact descended from a follower of the Khan.  He became a ruler about 1370 of a realm whose capital was Samarkand; conquered Persia, Central Asia, and in 1398 a great part of India, including Delhi; waged war with the Turkish Sultan Bajazet I. (Beyazid), whom he defeated at Ancyra in 1402 and took prisoner; and died while preparing to invade China.  He is the Tamerlaine of the plays.
Tous-les-mois: A kind of starch with very large, oval, flattened grains, often sold as arrowroot, and extensively used for adulterating cocoa. It is made from the rootstocks of a species of Canna, probably Canna edulis, the tubers of which are edible every month in the year.
Tigrine: Of or pertaining to a tiger; like a tiger.
Tarheel: a native or resident of North Carolina; -- used as a nickname.
Trafficable: Capable of being disposed of in traffic; marketable.
Third-penny: A third part of the profits of fines and penalties imposed at the country court, which was among the perquisites enjoyed by the earl.
Territorially: In regard to territory; by means of territory.
Timothy: A disciple and companion of St. Paul.  He was the son of a Greek and a Jewess, and his home was either at Derbe, or Lystra in Lycaonia.  Paul set him apart as a minister of the new gospel, and after preaching in Macedonia and Achaia, he went, at Paul's request to Ephesus, and accompanied the apostle to Jerusalem.  It was to him that the two epistles to Timothy were addressed by the apostle Paul. According to tradition, Timothy suffered martyrdom under Domitian.
Thankless: Not acknowledging favors; not expressing thankfulness; unthankful; ungrateful.
Trojan horse: a large hollow wooden horse built by Greek soldiers besieging Troy during the Trojan War, and left as a “gift” when they pretended to abandon their seige.  It was taken into the city by the Trojans, and Greek soldiers concealed inside came out and opened the gates to the city, enabling the capture of the city by the Greeks.
Thorn-headed: Having a head armed with thorns or spines.
Trochus: Any one of numerous species of marine univalve shells belonging to Trochus and many allied genera of the family Trochidæ. Some of the species are called also topshells.
Tubipore: Any species of the genus Tubipora.
Tewan: A tribe of American Indians including many of the Pueblos of New Mexico and adjacent regions.
Textually: In a textual manner; in the text or body of a work; in accordance with the text.
Tubipora: A genus of halcyonoids in which the skeleton, or coral (called organ-pipe coral), consists of a mass of parallel cylindrical tubes united at intervals by transverse plates. These corals are usually red or purple and form large masses. They are natives of the tropical parts of the Indian and Pacific Oceans.
Tolerable: Capable of being borne or endured; supportable, either physically or mentally.
Tartarean: Of or pertaining to Tartarus; hellish.
Tamale: A Mexican dish made of crushed corn (cornmeal) mixed with minced meat, seasoned with red pepper, dipped in oil, and steamed.
Twisted: Contorted; crooked spirally; subjected to torsion; hence, perverted.
Tallowy: Of the nature of tallow; resembling tallow; greasy.
Terebrating: Boring; perforating; -- applied to molluskas which form holes in rocks, wood, etc.
Tierce: A cask whose content is one third of a pipe; that is, forty-two wine gallons; also, a liquid measure of forty-two wine, or thirty-five imperial, gallons.
Telegraphy: The science or art of constructing, or of communicating by means of, telegraphs; as, submarine telegraphy.
Triphthong: A combination of three vowel sounds in a single syllable, forming a simple or compound sound; also, a union of three vowel characters, representing together a single sound; a trigraph; as, eye, -ieu in adieu, -eau in beau, are examples of triphthongs.
Titi: A tree of the southern United States (Cliftonia monophylla) having glossy leaves and racemes of fragrant white flowers succeeded by one-seeded drupes; -- called also black titi, buckwheat tree, and ironwood.
Tutti: All; -- a direction for all the singers or players to perform together.
Tillman: A man who tills the earth; a husbandman.
Typographic: Of or pertaining to the act or art of representing by types or symbols; emblematic; figurative; typical.
Tenesmic: Of or pertaining to tenesmus; characterized by tenesmus.
Tetanic: A substance (notably nux vomica, strychnine, and brucine) which, either as a remedy or a poison, acts primarily on the spinal cord, and which, when taken in comparatively large quantity, produces tetanic spasms or convulsions.
Topsman: The chief drover of those who drive a herd of cattle.
Treasure-trove: Any money, bullion, or the like, found in the earth, or otherwise hidden, the owner of which is not known. In England such treasure belongs to the crown; whereas similar treasure found in the sea, or upon the surface of the land, belongs to the finder if no owner appears.
Triclinic: Having, or characterized by, three unequal axes intersecting at oblique angles. See the Note under crystallization.
Treebeard: A pendulous branching lichen (Usnea barbata); -- so called from its resemblance to hair.
Tetanin: A poisonous base (ptomaine) formed in meat broth through the agency of a peculiar microbe from the wound of a person who has died of tetanus; -- so called because it produces tetanus as one of its prominent effects.
Technic: The method of performance in any art; technical skill; artistic execution; technique.
Trifling: Being of small value or importance; trivial; paltry; as, a trifling debt; a trifling affair.
Tapoa tafa: A small carnivorous marsupial (Phascogale penicillata) having long, soft fur, and a very long tail with a tuft of long hairs at the end; -- called also brush-tailed phascogale.
Translatorship: The office or dignity of a translator.
Trilogy: A series of three dramas which, although each of them is in one sense complete, have a close mutual relation, and form one historical and poetical picture. Shakespeare's “ Henry VI.” is an example.
Theorize: To form a theory or theories; to form opinions solely by theory; to speculate.
Tuck: A horizontal sewed fold, such as is made in a garment, to shorten it; a plait.
Trichoscolices: An extensive group of wormlike animals characterized by being more or less covered with cilia.
Trisected: Divided into three parts or segments by incisions extending to the midrib or to the base; -- said of leaves.
Tripe: The large stomach of ruminating animals, when prepared for food.
Terrible: Adapted or likely to excite terror, awe, or dread; dreadful; formidable.
Transform: To be changed in form; to be metamorphosed.
Tattle: Idle talk or chat; trifling talk; prate.
Term day: A day which is a term (as for payment of rent), or is a day in a term, as of the sitting of a court; esp., one of a series of special days, designated by scientists of different nations or stations, for making synoptic magnetic, meteorological, or other physical observations.
Triliterality: The quality of being triliteral; as, the triliterality of Hebrew roots.
Talc: A soft mineral of a soapy feel and a greenish, whitish, or grayish color, usually occurring in foliated masses. It is hydrous silicate of magnesia. Steatite, or soapstone, is a compact granular variety.
Tulipist: A person who is especially devoted to the cultivation of tulips.
Two-foot: Measuring two feet; two feet long, thick, or wide; as, a two-foot rule.
Two-parted: Divided from the border to the base into two distinct parts; bipartite.
Talk: The act of talking; especially, familiar converse; mutual discourse; that which is uttered, especially in familiar conversation, or the mutual converse of two or more.
Trenchantly: In a trenchant, or sharp, manner; sharply; severely.
Toboggan: To slide down hill over the snow or ice on a toboggan.
Temporize: To comply with the time or occasion; to humor, or yield to, the current of opinion or circumstances; also, to trim, as between two parties.
Thermolyze: To subject to thermolysis; to dissociate by heat.
Tiebeam: A beam acting as a tie, as at the bottom of a pair of principal rafters, to prevent them from thrusting out the wall. See Illust. of Timbers, under Roof.
Tocher: Dowry brought by a bride to her husband.
Therm\u00e6: Springs or baths of warm or hot water.
Telerythin: A red crystalline compound related to, or produced from, erythrin. So called because regarded as the end of the series of erythrin compounds.
Theocracy: Government of a state by the immediate direction or administration of God; hence, the exercise of political authority by priests as representing the Deity.
Thesis: A position or proposition which a person advances and offers to maintain, or which is actually maintained by argument.
Tripeman: A man who prepares or sells tripe.
Trachinoid: Of, pertaining to, or like, Trachinus, a genus of fishes which includes the weevers. See Weever.
Trow: To believe; to trust; to think or suppose.
Tachometry: Measurement by a tachometer; the science or use of tachometers.
Throatlatch: A strap of a bridle, halter, or the like, passing under a horse's throat.
Ter-: A combining form from L. ter signifying three times, thrice. See Tri-, 2.
Turfiness: Quality or state of being turfy.
Typal: Relating to a type or types; belonging to types; serving as a type; typical.
Trabecular: Of or pertaining to a trabecula or trabeculæ; composed of trabeculæ.
Trithionic: Of or pertaining to, or designating, a certain thionic acid, H2S3O6 which is obtained as a colorless, odorless liquid.
Topmost: Highest; uppermost; as, the topmost cliff; the topmost branch of a tree.
Terminer: A determining; as, in oyer and terminer. See Oyer.
Thermoelectric couple: A union of two conductors, as bars or wires of dissimilar metals joined at their extremities, for producing a thermoelectric current.
Telautograph: A facsimile telegraph for reproducing writing, pictures, maps, etc. In the transmitter the motions of the pencil are communicated by levers to two rotary shafts, by which variations in current are produced in two separate circuits. In the receiver these variations are utilized by electromagnetic devices and levers to move a pen as the pencil moves.
Terror: Extreme fear; fear that agitates body and mind; violent dread; fright.
Tumulus: An artificial hillock, especially one raised over a grave, particularly over the graves of persons buried in ancient times; a barrow.
Totter: To shake so as to threaten a fall; to vacillate; to be unsteady; to stagger; as, an old man totters with age.
Tulip-shell: A large, handsomely colored, marine univalve shell (Fasciolaria tulipa) native of the Southern United States.  The name is sometimes applied also to other species of Fasciolaria.
Tortulous: Swelled out at intervals like a knotted cord.
Transisthmian: Extending across an isthmus, as at Suez or Panama.
Theopathetic: Of or pertaining to a theopathy.
Transmigratory: Passing from one body or state to another.
Thomson process: A process of electric welding in which heat is developed by a large current passing through the metal.
Tierc\u00e9: Divided into three equal parts of three different tinctures; -- said of an escutcheon.
Tricycle: A three-wheeled velocipede. See Illust. under Velocipede.  Cf. Bicycle.
Trochantine: The second joint of the leg of an insect, -- often united with the coxa.
Turrethead: an attachment fitted to a lathe or other machinery which holds a variety of tools which can act on the object being worked, and which are interchangeable by a pivoting motion, thus allowing efficient performance of multiple operations; -- also called a turret.
Trunnioned: Provided with trunnions; as, the trunnioned cylinder of an oscillating steam engine.
Tergiversator: One who tergiversates; one who suffles, or practices evasion.
Trappings: That which serves to trap or adorn; ornaments; dress; superficial decorations.
Tern: That which consists of, or pertains to, three things or numbers together; especially, a prize in a lottery resulting from the favorable combination of three numbers in the drawing; also, the three numbers themselves.
Term: To apply a term to; to name; to call; to denominate.
Topographic: Of or pertaining to topography; descriptive of a place.
Tychism: Any theory which conceives chance as an objective reality; esp., a theory of evolution which considers that variation may be purely fortuitous.
Torulaform: Having the appearance of a torula; in the form of a little chain; as, a torulaform string of micrococci.
Trichomanes: Any fern of the genus Trichomanes. The fronds are very delicate and often translucent, and the sporangia are borne on threadlike receptacles rising from the middle of cup-shaped marginal involucres. Several species are common in conservatories; two are native in the United States.
Typifier: One who, or that which, typifies.
Tulipomania: A violent passion for the acquisition or cultivation of tulips; -- a word said by Beckman to have been coined by Menage.
Triolet: A short poem or stanza of eight lines, in which the first line is repeated as the fourth and again as the seventh line, the second being, repeated as the eighth.
Technobabble: technical jargon incomprehensible to non-specialists; -- sometimes used derogatorily of discussions using unnecessarily technical terminology and intended to impress or confuse, rather than inform, the listener.
throwback: the reappearance in an organism of characteristics of an earlier ancestral type; atavism.
Termination: The act of terminating, or of limiting or setting bounds; the act of ending or concluding; as, a voluntary termination of hostilities.
Tinsmith: One who works in tin; a tinner.
Titration: The act or process of titrating; a substance obtained by titrating.
Thalamencephalon: The segment of the brain next in front of the midbrain, including the thalami, pineal gland, and pituitary body; the diencephalon; the interbrain.
Tympano: A kettledrum; -- chiefly used in the plural to denote the kettledrums of an orchestra. See Kettledrum.
Trichina: A small, slender nematoid worm (Trichina spiralis) which, in the larval state, is parasitic, often in immense numbers, in the voluntary muscles of man, the hog, and many other animals. When insufficiently cooked meat containing the larvæ is swallowed by man, they are liberated and rapidly become adult, pair, and the ovoviviparous females produce in a short time large numbers of young which find their way into the muscles, either directly, or indirectly by means of the blood. Their presence in the muscles and the intestines in large numbers produces trichinosis.
Thrivingness: The quality or condition of one who thrives; prosperity; growth; increase.
Trivium: The three “ liberal” arts, grammar, logic, and rhetoric; -- being a triple way, as it were, to eloquence.
Tula metal: An alloy of silver, copper, and lead made at Tula in Russia.
Tineman: An officer of the forest who had the care of vert and venison by night.
Transferography: The act or process of copying inscriptions, or the like, by making transfers.
Tricuspidate: Three-pointed; ending in three points; as, a tricuspidate leaf.
take the heat: To be assigned or to accept the blame for some misdeed; as, Mary broke the vase, but she acted innocent and young Johnny had to take the heat.
Tube-nosed: Having the nostrils prolonged in the form of horny tubes along the sides of the beak; -- said of certain sea birds.
Terminator: One who, or that which, terminates.
Tartrovinic: Of, pertaining to, or designating, a certain acid composed of tartaric acid in combination with ethyl, and now called ethyltartaric acid.
Tisar: The fireplace at the side of an annealing oven.
Tameness: The quality or state of being tame.
Triticum: A genus of grasses including the various species of wheat.
Tractor airplane: An airplane having one or more tractor propellers; -- called also tractor.
Touchhole: The vent of a cannon or other firearm, by which fire is communicateed to the powder of the charge.
Tongue-tied: Destitute of the power of distinct articulation; having an impediment in the speech, esp. when caused by a short frænum.
Thyrsoid: Having somewhat the form of a thyrsus.
Typhomania: A low delirium common in typhus fever.
Tetragynia: A Linnæan order of plants having four styles.
Thionoline: A beautiful fluorescent crystalline substance, intermediate in composition between thionol and thionine.
Teague: An Irishman; -- a term used in contempt.
Trillium: A genus of liliaceous plants; the three-leaved nightshade; -- so called because all the parts of the plant are in threes.
Tyrolite: A translucent mineral of a green color and pearly or vitreous luster. It is a hydrous arseniate of copper.
Triticin: A carbohydrate isomeric with dextrin, obtained from quitch grass (Agropyrum repens, formerly Triticum repens) as a white amorphous substance.
Trialogue: A discourse or colloquy by three persons.
Though: However; nevertheless; notwithstanding; -- used in familiar language, and in the middle or at the end of a sentence.
Torose: Cylindrical with alternate swellings and contractions; having the surface covered with rounded prominences.
Trivialness: Quality or state of being trivial.
Thread: To pass a thread through the eye of; as, to thread a needle.
Thunderstorm: A storm accompanied with lightning and thunder.
turbo: Any one of numerous marine gastropods of the genus Turbo or family Turbinidæ, usually having a turbinate shell, pearly on the inside, and a calcareous operculum.
Tubicorn: Any ruminant having horns composed of a bony axis covered with a horny sheath; a hollow-horned ruminant.
Tenrec: A small insectivore (Centetes ecaudatus), native of Madagascar, but introduced also into the islands of Bourbon and Mauritius; -- called also tanrec. The name is applied to other allied genera. See Tendrac.
Tritheism: The opinion or doctrine that the Father, Son, and Holy Spirit are three distinct Gods.
Tractile: Capable of being drawn out in length; ductile.
Table dh\u00f4te: A common table for guests at a hotel; an ordinary.
Tuque: A kind of warm cap winter wear, made from a knit bag with closed tapered ends by pushing one end within the other, thus making a conical cap of double thickness.
Tribunary: Of or pertaining to tribunes; as, tribunary powers or authority.
Timepiece: A clock, watch, or other instrument, to measure or show the progress of time; a chronometer.
Terrorize: To impress with terror; to coerce by intimidation.
Transpositive: Made by transposing; consisting in transposition; transposable.
Torricellian: Of or pertaining to Torricelli, an Italian philosopher and mathematician, who, in 1643, discovered that the rise of a liquid in a tube, as in the barometer, is due to atmospheric pressure. See Barometer.
Trifloral: Three-flowered; having or bearing three flowers; as, a triflorous peduncle.
Tippling-house: A house in which liquors are sold in drams or small quantities, to be drunk on the premises.
Tidemark: a mark on a shore line indicating the normal level of the water at high tide, caused by the action of the flowing water; sometimes also used for the mark left at the point of the normal low tide; -- called also high water mark.
Tetrakosane: A hydrocarbon, C24H50, resembling paraffin, and like it belonging to the marsh-gas series; -- so called from having twenty-four atoms of carbon in the molecule.
Tuum: Lit., thine; that which is thine; -- used in meum and tuum. See 2d Meum.
Tichorrhine: A fossil rhinoceros with a vertical bony medial septum supporting the nose; the hairy rhinoceros.
Trigonia: A genus of pearly bivalve shells, numerous extinct species of which are characteristic of the Mesozoic rocks. A few living species exist on the coast of Australia.
Tubbing: The forming of a tub; also, collectively, materials for tubs.
Taslet: A piece of armor formerly worn to guard the thighs; a tasse.
Trailer: a wheeled vehicle without a motor, designed to be drawn by a motor vehicle in front of it;
Testi\u00e8re: A piece of plate armor for the head of a war horse; a tester.
Tetraonid: A bird belonging to the tribe of which the genus Tetrao is the type, as the grouse, partridge, quail, and the like. Used also adjectively.
Taffy: A kind of candy made of molasses or brown sugar boiled down and poured out in shallow pans.
Typewriting: The act or art of using a typewriter; also, a print made with a typewriter.
Telengiscope: An instrument of such focal length that it may be used as an observing telescope for objects close at hand or as a long-focused microscope.
Telegram: A message sent by telegraph; a telegraphic dispatch.
Thistly: Overgrown with thistles; as, thistly ground.
Talewise: In a way of a tale or story.
Tallboy: A kind of long-stemmed wineglass or cup.
Turriculate: Furnished with, or formed like, a small turret or turrets; somewhat turreted.
Tucan: The Mexican pocket gopher (Geomys Mexicanus). It resembles the common pocket gopher of the Western United States, but is larger. Called also tugan, and tuza.
Twin: To depart from a place or thing.
Thistle: Any one of several prickly composite plants, especially those of the genera Cnicus, Craduus, and Onopordon. The name is often also applied to other prickly plants.
Trieterical: Kept or occurring once in three years; triennial.
Tawer: One who taws; a dresser of white leather.
Transmove: To move or change from one state into another; to transform.
Truckle: To roll or move upon truckles, or casters; to trundle.
Tufaceous: Pertaining to tufa; consisting of, or resembling, tufa.
Tinctorial: Of or relating to color or colors; imparting a color; as, tinctorial matter.
Trithing: One of three ancient divisions of a county in England; -- now called riding.
Toxophilite: A lover of archery; one devoted to archery.
Temper screw: A screw link, to which is attached the rope of a rope-drilling apparatus, for feeding and slightly turning the drill jar at each stroke.
Toxicogenic: Producing toxic products; as, toxicogenic germs or bacteria.
Tr\u00e9fl\u00e9: Having a three-lobed extremity or extremities, as a cross; also, more rarely, ornamented with trefoils projecting from the edges, as a bearing.
Thursday: The fifth day of the week, following Wednesday and preceding Friday.
Thermogen: Caloric; heat; regarded as a material but imponderable substance.
Tomtit: A titmouse, especially the blue titmouse.
Thinkable: Capable of being thought or conceived; cogitable.
Tractor-trailer: a combination of a tractor{4} hooked up to a trailer, forming a common type of truck{7} used for carrying freight on highways.
Tribasic: Capable of neutralizing three molecules of a monacid base, or their equivalent; having three hydrogen atoms capable of replacement by basic elements on radicals; -- said of certain acids; thus, citric acid is a tribasic acid.
Tumidity: The quality or state of being tumid.
Trine: To put in the aspect of a trine.
Tunny: The chiefly British equivalent of tuna; any one of several species of large oceanic fishes belonging to the Mackerel family, especially the common or great tunny (Thunnus thynnus syn. Albacora thynnus, formerly Orcynus thynnus) native of the Mediterranean Sea and the Atlantic Ocean.  It sometimes weighs a thousand pounds or more, and is extensively caught in the Mediterranean.  On the American coast it is called horse mackerel. See Illust. of Horse mackerel, under Horse.
Twang: A harsh, quick sound, like that made by a stretched string when pulled and suddenly let go; as, the twang of a bowstring.
Tory: Of or pertaining to the Tories.
Tympanohyal: Of or pertaining to the tympanum and the hyoidean arch.
Teasel: To subject, as woolen cloth, to the action of teasels, or any substitute for them which has an effect to raise a nap.
Termite: Any one of numerous species of pseudoneoropterous insects belonging to Termes and allied genera; -- called also white ant. See Illust. of White ant.
Tuberculin test: The hypodermic injection of tuberculin, used as a test for past or present infection with tuberculosis.  It is used both for humans and cattle.
Telic: Denoting the final end or purpose, as distinguished from ecbatic. See Ecbatic.
Tandem: A team of horses harnessed one before the other.
Tom and Jerry: A hot sweetened drink of rum and water spiced with cinnamon, cloves, etc., and beaten up with eggs.
Thornback: A European skate (Raia clavata) having thornlike spines on its back.
Tramontane: One living beyond the mountains; hence, a foreigner; a stranger.
Tenuious: Rare or subtile; tenuous; -- opposed to dense.
Tipstock: The detachable or movable fore part of a gunstock, lying beneath the barrel or barrels, and forming a hold for the left hand.
Tights: Close-fitting garments, especially for the lower part of the body and the legs.
Thickly: In a thick manner; deeply; closely.
Trochanter: One of two processes near the head of the femur, the outer being called the great trochanter, and the inner the small trochanter.
Testate: One who leaves a valid will at death; a testate person.
Tinder: Something very inflammable, used for kindling fire from a spark, as scorched linen.
Torpedo-boat destroyer: A larger, swifter, and more powerful armed type of torpedo boat, originally intended principally for the destruction of torpedo boats, but later used also as a more formidable torpedo boat.
Testimony: To witness; to attest; to prove by testimony.
tackle: An act of tackling{4}; as, brought down by a tackle by a lineman.
Temporality: The state or quality of being temporary; -- opposed to perpetuity.
Taranis: A Celtic divinity, regarded as the evil principle, but confounded by the Romans with Jupiter.
Tether: To confine, as an animal, with a long rope or chain, as for feeding within certain limits.
Trental: An office and mass for the dead on the thirtieth day after death or burial.
Timorous: Fearful of danger; timid; deficient in courage.
Thewed: Furnished with thews or muscles; as, a well-thewed limb.
Tablespoonful: As much as a tablespoon will hold; enough to fill a tablespoon. It is usually reckoned as one half of a fluid ounce, or four fluid drams.
Trilobite: Any one of numerous species of extinct arthropods belonging to the order Trilobita. Trilobites were very common in the Silurian and Devonian periods, but became extinct at the close of the Paleozoic. So named from the three lobes usually seen on each segment.
Terre-verte: An olive-green earth used as a pigment. See Glauconite.
Tributariness: The quality or state of being tributary.
Testator: A man who makes and leaves a will, or testament, at death.
Twiggy: Of or pertaining to a twig or twigs; like a twig or twigs; full of twigs; abounding with shoots.
Thermal: Of or pertaining to heat; warm; hot; as, the thermal unit; thermal waters.
Tibiotarsus: The large bone between the femur and tarsometatarsus in the leg of a bird. It is formed by the union of the proximal part of the tarsus with the tibia.
Tiers \u00e9tat: The third estate, or commonalty, in France, answering to the commons in Great Britain; -- so called in distinction from, and as inferior to, the nobles and clergy.
Turnover: Admitting of being turned over; made to be turned over; as, a turnover collar, etc.
Three-way: Connected with, or serving to connect, three channels or pipes; as, a three-way cock or valve.
To-break: To break completely; to break in pieces.
Tallith: An undergarment worn by orthodox Jews, covering the chest and the upper part of the back. It has an opening for the head, and has tassels, called zizith, on its four corners.
Tote: The entire body, or all; as, the whole tote.
Tintamar: A hideous or confused noise; an uproar.
Tube: To furnish with a tube; as, to tube a well.
Tretis: Long and well-proportioned; nicely made; pretty.
T\u00e6nioidea: The division of cestode worms which comprises the tapeworms. See Tapeworm.
Take: That which is taken, such as the quantity of fish captured at one haul or catch, or the amouont of money collected during one event; as, the box-office take.
Tapiroid: Allied to the tapir, or the Tapir family.
Thulium: A rare metallic element of uncertain properties and identity, said to have been found in the mineral gadolinite.
Toty: A sailor or fisherman; -- so called in some parts of the Pacific.
taxicab: an automobile with a professional driver which can be hired to carry passengers; -- also called a taxi, and informally called a cab or a hack.  The driver of a taxicab is referred to as a cab driver or cabbie, and sometimes as a chauffeur or hackie.
Tergal: Of or pertaining to back, or tergum. See Dorsal.
Title: To call by a title; to name; to entitle.
Tesla coil: A transformer without iron, for high frequency alternating or oscillating currents; an oscillation transformer.
Tailor: To practice making men's clothes; to follow the business of a tailor.
Tertian: A disease, especially an intermittent fever, which returns every third day, reckoning inclusively, or in which the intermission lasts one day.
Theft: The act of stealing; specifically, the felonious taking and removing of personal property, with an intent to deprive the rightful owner of the same; larceny.
Tartan: A small coasting vessel, used in the Mediterranean, having one mast carrying large leteen sail, and a bowsprit with staysail or jib.
Trochleary: Pertaining to, or connected with, a trochlea; trochlear; as, the trochleary, or trochlear, nerve.
trial and error: The method of discovering something desirable by trying many different things until one works; as, the traditional method of finding new drugs is by trial and error.
Tetterous: Having the character of, or pertaining to, tetter.
Tiring-room: The room or place where players dress for the stage.
Thalamoc\u0153le: The cavity or ventricle of the thalamencephalon; the third ventricle.
Training: The act of one who trains; the act or process of exercising, disciplining, etc.; education.
Telescopically: In a telescopical manner; by or with the telescope.
Taxaspidean: Having the posterior tarsal scales, or scutella, rectangular and arranged in regular rows; -- said of certain birds.
Tayra: A South American carnivore (Galera barbara) allied to the grison. The tail is long and thick. The length, including the tail, is about three feet.
Trowel: A mason's tool, used in spreading and dressing mortar, and breaking bricks to shape them.
Teemless: Not fruitful or prolific; barren; as, a teemless earth.
Torcher: One who gives light with a torch, or as if with a torch.
Tango: A difficult dance in two-four time characterized by graceful posturing, frequent pointing positions, and a great variety of steps, including the cross step and turning steps. The dance is of Spanish origin, and is believed to have been in its original form a part of the fandango.
Tannic: Of or pertaining to tan; derived from, or resembling, tan; as, tannic acid.
Tannin: Same as Tannic acid, under Tannic.
Typist: A person who operates a typewriting machine; a typewriter.
Terebrantia: A division of Hymenoptera including those which have an ovipositor adapted for perforating plants. It includes the sawflies.
Troat: The cry of a buck in rutting time.
Terminable: Capable of being terminated or bounded; limitable.
Testing: The act of testing or proving; trial; proof.
Toby: A small jug, pitcher, or mug, generally used for ale, shaped somewhat like a stout man, with a cocked hat forming the brim.
Tenebrific: Rendering dark or gloomy; tenebrous; gloomy.
Tensioned: Extended or drawn out; subjected to tension.
Thorough bass: The representation of chords by figures placed under the base; figured bass; basso continuo; -- sometimes used as synonymous with harmony.
Tridacna: A genus of very large marine bivalve shells found on the coral reefs of the Indian and Pacific Oceans. One species (Tridacna gigas) often weighs four or five hundred pounds, and is sometimes used for baptismal fonts. Called also paw shell, and fountain shell.
Trussing: The timbers, etc., which form a truss, taken collectively.
Tubularia: A genus of hydroids having large, naked, flowerlike hydranths at the summits of long, slender, usually simple, stems. The gonophores are small, and form clusters at the bases of the outer tentacles.
Terrine: A dish or pan, originally of earthenware, such as those in which  various dishes are cooked and served; esp., an earthenware jar containing some table delicacy and sold with its contents.
Trimurti: The triad, or trinity, of Hindu gods, consisting of Brahma, the Creator, Vishnu, the Preserver, and Siva, the Destroyer.
Turpeth: The root of Ipomœa Turpethum, a plant of Ceylon, Malabar, and Australia, formerly used in medicine as a purgative; -- sometimes called vegetable turpeth.
Tenantry: The body of tenants; as, the tenantry of a manor or a kingdom.
Twinkling: The act of one who, or of that which, twinkles; a quick movement of the eye; a wink; a twinkle.
Turtle peg: A sharp steel spear attached to a cord, used in taking sea turtles.
Timenoguy: A rope carried taut between or over obstacles likely to engage or foul the running rigging in working a ship.
Thymene: A liquid terpene obtained from oil of thyme.
Trundle-bed: A low bed that is moved on trundles, or little wheels, so that it can be pushed under a higher bed; a truckle-bed; also, sometimes, a simiral bed without wheels.
Tip-up: The spotted sandpiper; -- called also teeter-tail. See under Sandpiper.
Turgesce: To become turgid; to swell or be inflated.
Transcendent: That which surpasses or is supereminent; that which is very excellent.
Threap: An obstinate decision or determination; a pertinacious affirmation.
Ticking: A strong, closely woven linen or cotton fabric, of which ticks for beds are made. It is usually twilled, and woven in stripes of different colors, as white and blue; -- called also ticken.
Tergite: The dorsal portion of an arthromere or somite of an articulate animal. See Illust. under Coleoptera.
Theological: Of or pertaining to theology, or the science of God and of divine things; as, a theological treatise.
Tensive: Giving the sensation of tension, stiffness, or contraction.
Thom\u00e6an: A member of the ancient church of Christians established on the Malabar coast of India, which some suppose to have been originally founded by the Apostle Thomas.
Toluid: A complex double tolyl and toluidine derivative of glycocoll, obtained as a white crystalline substance.
Tupi: An Indian of the tribe from which the Tupian stock takes its name, dwelling, at the advent of the Portuguese, about the mouth of the Amazon.  Also, their language, which is the basis of the Indian trade language of the Amazon.
Tatch: A spot or stain; also, a trick.
Trawler: One who, or that which, trawls.
Traducement: The act of traducing; misrepresentation; ill-founded censure; defamation; calumny.
Totalization: Act of totalizing, or state of being totalized.
Totally: In a total manner; wholly; entirely.
Testaceography: The science which treats of testaceans, or shellfish; the description of shellfish.
Tenuis: One of the three surd mutes κ, π, τ; -- so called in relation to their respective middle letters, or medials, γ, β, δ, and their aspirates, χ, φ, θ. The term is also applied to the corresponding letters and articulate elements in other languages.
Toilful: Producing or involving much toil; laborious; toilsome; as, toilful care.
Trachystomata: An order of tailed aquatic amphibians, including Siren and Pseudobranchus. They have anterior legs only, are eel-like in form, and have no teeth except a small patch on the palate. The external gills are persistent through life.
Tartuffe: A hypocritical devotee. See the Dictionary of Noted Names in Fiction.
Tinamou: Any one of several species of South American birds belonging to Tinamus and allied genera.
Teleology: The doctrine of the final causes of things
Toreutic: In relief; pertaining to sculpture in relief, especially of metal; also, pertaining to chasing such as surface ornamentation in metal.
Trematode: One of the Trematodea. Also used adjectively.
Tuatara: A large iguanalike reptile (Sphenodon punctatum) formerly common in New Zealand, but by 1900 confined to certain islets near the coast. It reaches a length of two and a half feet, is dark olive-green with small white or yellowish specks on the sides, and has yellow spines along the back, except on the neck.  It is the only surviving member of the order Rhyncocephala.  Also called tuatera and hatteria.
threads: Clothes; clothing; as, he was wearing his new threads at the party.
Turnbulls blue: The double cyanide of ferrous and ferric iron, a dark blue amorphous substance having a coppery luster, used in dyeing, calico printing, etc.  Cf. Prussian blue, under Prussian.
Thrash: To practice thrashing grain or the like; to perform the business of beating grain from straw; as, a man who thrashes well.
Trumpeting: A channel cut behind the brick lining of a shaft.
Trachelipodous: Having the foot united with the neck; of or pertaining to the Trachelipoda.
Thanksgiver: One who gives thanks, or acknowledges a kindness.
Torpedo boom: A spar formerly carried by men-of-war, having a torpedo on its end.
Trigenic: Of, pertaining to, or designating, an acid, C4H7N3O2, obtained, by the action of the vapor of cyanic acid on cold aldehyde, as a white crystalline substance having a slightly acid taste and faint smell; -- called also ethidene-biuret or ethylidene-biuret.
Temperance: Habitual moderation in regard to the indulgence of the natural appetites and passions; restrained or moderate indulgence; moderation; as, temperance in eating and drinking; temperance in the indulgence of joy or mirth; specifically, moderation, and sometimes abstinence, in respect to using intoxicating liquors.
Tressure: A kind of border similar to the orle, but of only half the breadth of the latter.
Theftbote: The receiving of a man's goods again from a thief, or a compensation for them, by way of composition, with the intent that the thief shall escape punishment.
Thermostable: Capable of being heated to or somewhat above 55° C. without loss of special properties; -- said of proteins, immune substances, etc.
Terebration: The act of terebrating, or boring.
Thaliacea: A division of Tunicata comprising the free-swimming species, such as Salpa and Doliolum.
Tompion: A stopper of a cannon or a musket. See Tampion.
thaumaturgist: One who deals in wonders, or believes in them; a wonder worker; a thaumaturge.
Tetrapneumona: A division of Arachnida including those spiders which have four lungs, or pulmonary sacs. It includes the bird spiders (Mygale) and the trapdoor spiders. See Mygale.
Two-cleft: Divided about half way from the border to the base into two segments; bifid.
Thoroughly: In a thorough manner; fully; entirely; completely.
Top: To cover on the top; to tip; to cap; -- chiefly used in the past participle.
Transudation: The act or process of transuding.
Tow: A rope by which anything is towed; a towline, or towrope.
Top-dress: To apply a surface dressing of manureto,as land.
Trestle: A movable frame or support for anything, as scaffolding, consisting of three or four legs secured to a top piece, and forming a sort of stool or horse, used by carpenters, masons, and other workmen; also, a kind of framework of strong posts or piles, and crossbeams, for supporting a bridge, the track of a railway, or the like.
Ton: A measure of weight or quantity.
Tetryl: Butyl; -- so called from the four carbon atoms in the molecule.
Thickskin: A coarse, gross person; a person void of sensibility or sinsitiveness; a dullard.
Transcension: The act of transcending, or surpassing; also, passage over.
Touch: The act of touching, or the state of being touched; contact.
Tog: To put toggery, or togs, on; to dress; -- usually with out, implying care, elaborateness, or the like.
Tod: To weigh; to yield in tods.
Toe: To hold or carry the toes (in a certain way).
Technicality: The quality or state of being technical; technicalness.
Traumatism: A wound or injury directly produced by causes external to the body; also, violence producing a wound or injury; as, rupture of the stomach caused by traumatism.
Touchiness: The quality or state of being touchy; peevishness; irritability; irascibility.
Titubation: The act of stumbling, rocking, or rolling; a reeling.
Trochilidist: One who studies, or is versed in, the nature and habits of humming birds, or the Trochilidæ.
Tennantite: A blackish lead-gray mineral, closely related to tetrahedrite. It is essentially a sulphide of arsenic and copper.
Trisagion: An ancient anthem, -- usually known by its Latin name tersanctus.See Tersanctus.
Tripartition: A division by threes, or into three parts; the taking of a third part of any number or quantity.
tritium: A radioactive isotope of hydrogen having one proton and two neutrons in the nucleus.  It decays spontaneously to Helium-3 by the emission of an electron (beta ray), with a half-life of 12.3 years.  Symbol 1H3.  Atomic weight 3.01605 (C-12 = 12.0000). It is one of the radioisotopes commonly used to label chemical compounds for use as tracers in biochemistry and chemistry.  It is also used as one of the fusionable components of a hydrogen bomb.
Tetrose: A monosaccharide derived from a certain alcohol.
Tidbit: A delicate or tender piece of anything eatable; a delicious morsel.
Terreous: Consisting of earth; earthy; as, terreous substances; terreous particles.
Temperateness: The quality or state of being temperate; moderateness; temperance.
Tobacco: An American plant (Nicotiana Tabacum) of the Nightshade family, much used for smoking and chewing, and as snuff. As a medicine, it is narcotic, emetic, and cathartic. Tobacco has a strong, peculiar smell, and an acrid taste.
Thrasher: One who, or that which, thrashes grain; a thrashing machine.
Troyounce: See Troy ounce, under Troy weight, above, and under Ounce.
Tonsorial: Of or pertaining to a barber, or shaving.
Transship: To transfer from one ship or conveyance to another.
Two-ranked: Alternately disposed on exactly opposite sides of the stem so as to from two ranks; distichous.
Tocology: The science of obstetrics, or midwifery; that department of medicine which treats of parturition.
Trendle: A wheel, spindle, or the like; a trundle.
Taws: A leather lash, or other instrument of punishment, used by a schoolmaster.
Thick-skinned: Having a thick skin; hence, not sensitive; dull; obtuse.
Terminology: The doctrine of terms; a theory of terms or appellations; a treatise on terms.
Talegalla: A genus of Australian birds which includes the brush turkey. See Brush turkey.
Tacksman: One who holds a tack or lease from another; a tenant, or lessee.
Tricostate: Three-ribbed; having three ribs from the base.
Tabefy: To cause to waste gradually, to emaciate.
Typolithography: A branch of lithography in which impressions from printers' types are transferred to stone for reproduction.
Trawlwarp: A rope passing through a block, used in managing or dragging a trawlnet.
Tiffany: made of stained glass by, or in the style of objects made by, Louis C. Tiffany; as, a Tiffany lamp.
Top billing: the most prominent place in an advertisement or program for a theatrical performance, movie, fundraising affair, etc.; the place where the star's name usually is located.
Treacherous: Like a traitor; involving treachery; violating allegiance or faith pledged; traitorous to the state or sovereign; perfidious in private life; betraying a trust; faithless.
Tray-trip: An old game played with dice.
Tonight: The present or the coming night; the night after the present day.
Three-torque system of control: Any system of rudders by which the pilot can exert a turning moment about each of the three rectangular axes of an aëroplane or airship.
Tagger: One who, or that which, appends or joins one thing to another.
Triassic: Of the age of, or pertaining to, the Trias.
Trilingual: Containing, or consisting of, three languages; expressed in three languages.
Teleseism: A seismic movement or shock far from the  recording instrument.
Tentaculite: Any one of numerous species of small, conical fossil shells found in Paleozoic rocks. They are supposed to be pteropods.
Tomorrow: The day after the present; the morrow.
Tidytips: A California composite plant (Layia platyglossa), the flower of which has yellow rays tipped with white.
Titmouse: Any one of numerous species of small insectivorous singing birds belonging to Parus and allied genera; -- called also tit, and tomtit.
Telemetry: The science or process of making remote measurements and sending the data by radio; the use of a telemeter.
Taxidermy: The art of preparing, preserving, and mounting the skins of animals so as to represent their natural appearance, as for cabinets.
Theatricals: Dramatic performances; especially, those produced by amateurs.
Teens: The years of one's age having the termination -teen, beginning with thirteen and ending with nineteen; as, a girl in her teens.
Torta: a flat heap of moist, crushed silver ore, prepared for the patio process.
Tunicata: A grand division of the animal kingdom, intermediate, in some respects, between the invertebrates and vertebrates, and in modern classifications considered a subphylum of the vertebrates; called also urochordata.  They were formerly classed with acephalous mollusks.  The body is usually covered with a firm external tunic, consisting in part of cellulose, and having two openings, one for the entrance and one for the exit of water.  The pharynx is usually dilated in the form of a sac, pierced by several series of ciliated slits, and serves as a gill.
Triennial: Something which takes place or appears once in three years.
Thermology: A discourse on, or an account of, heat.
Tropologic: Characterized by tropes; varied by tropes; tropical.
Tricarballylic: Of, pertaining to, or designating, a complex tribasic organic acid, C3H5.(CO2H)3 occurring naturally in unripe beet roots, and produced artificially from glycerin as a white crystalline substance.
Trifallow: To plow the third time before sowing, as land.
Twinge: A pinch; a tweak; a twitch.
Tacit: Done or made in silence; implied, but not expressed; silent; as, tacit consent is consent by silence, or by not interposing an objection.
Two-decker: A vessel of war carrying guns on two decks.
Tautologist: One who uses tautological words or phrases.
Thialdine: A weak nitrogenous sulphur base, C6H13NS2.
Terpenylic: Of, pertaining to, or designating, an acid, C8H12O4 (called also terpentic acid), homologous with terebic acid, and obtained as a white crystalline substance by the oxidation of oil of turpentine with chromic acid.
Turtling: The act, practice, or art of catching turtles.
Thermotensile: Pertaining to the variation of tensile strength with the temperature.
Tropically: In a tropical manner; figuratively; metaphorically.
thawy: Liquefying by heat after having been frozen; thawing; melting.
Tire iron: a short steel bar with one end flattened so as to form a blade, used to remove rubber tires from the rim of a wheel.
Telegony: The supposed influence of a father upon offspring subsequent to his own, begotten of the same mother by another father.
Thi\u00ebnone: A ketone derivative of thiophene obtained as a white crystalline substance, (C4H3S)2.CO, by the action of aluminum chloride and carbonyl chloride on thiophene.
Thermotaxis: The property possessed by protoplasm of moving under the influence of heat.
Tawdry: A necklace of a rural fashion, bought at St. Audrey's fair; hence, a necklace in general.
Totara: A coniferous tree (Podocarpus totara), next to the kauri the most valuable timber tree of New Zealand.  Its hard reddish wood is used for furniture and building, esp. in wharves, bridges, etc.  Also mahogany pine.
Transfluent: Flowing or running across or through; as, a transfluent stream.
Truit\u00e9: Having a delicately crackled surface; -- applied to porcelian, etc.
Thionaphthene: A double benzene and thiophene nucleus, C8H6S, analogous to naphthalene, and like it the base of a large series of derivatives.
Tallyho: The huntsman's cry to incite or urge on his hounds.
Transcriber: One who transcribes, or writes from a copy; a copier; a copyist.
Toxodonta: An extinct order of Mammalia found in the South American Tertiary formation. The incisor teeth were long and curved and provided with a persistent pulp. They are supposed to be related both to the rodents and ungulates. Called also Toxodontia.
Thermotaxic: Pertaining to, or connected with, the regulation of temperature in the animal body; as, the thermotaxic nervous system.
Theretofore: Up to that time; before then; -- correlative with heretofore.
Toluate: A salt of any one of the toluic acids.
Turnstile: A revolving frame in a footpath, preventing the passage of horses or cattle, but admitting that of persons; a turnpike. See Turnpike, n., 1.
Trypsin: A proteolytic enzyme present in the pancreatic juice. Unlike the pepsin of the gastric juice, it acts in a neutral or alkaline fluid, and not only converts the albuminous matter of the food into soluble peptones, but also, in part, into leucin and tyrosin.
Tubinares: A tribe of sea birds comprising the petrels, shearwaters, albatrosses, hagdons, and allied birds having tubular horny nostrils.
Ten-oclock: A plant, the star-of-Bethlehem. See under Star.
Tradeoff: the exchange of one thing (object, right, opportunity) for another of approximately equal value, so as to seal a bargain, or effect a compromise.
Trematoid: Of or pertaining to the Trematodea. See Illustration in Appendix.
Tantalite: A heavy mineral of an iron-black color and submetallic luster.  It is essentially a tantalate of iron.
Troopship: A vessel built or fitted for the conveyance of troops; a transport.
Trochilic: OF or pertaining to rotary motion; having power to draw out or turn round.
Throw-off: A start in a hunt or a race.
Tissue: To form tissue of; to interweave.
Tuf-taffeta: A silk fabric formerly in use, having a nap or pile.
