Taoism: One of the popular religions of China, sanctioned by the state.
Tongs: An instrument, usually of metal, consisting of two parts, or long shafts, jointed together at or near one end, or united by an elastic bow, used for handling things, especially hot coals or metals; -- often called a pair of tongs.
Typology: A discourse or treatise on types.
Tibiale: The bone or cartilage of the tarsus which articulates with the tibia and corresponds to a part of the astragalus in man and most mammals.
Threatful: Full of threats; having a menacing appearance.
Tartronyl: A hypothetical radical constituting the characteristic residue of tartronic acid and certain of its derivatives.
Tegmentum: A covering; -- applied especially to the bundles of longitudinal fibers in the upper part of the crura of the cerebrum.
Thornbill: Any one of several species of small, brilliantly colored American birds of the genus Rhamphomicron. They have a long, slender, sharp bill, and feed upon honey, insects, and the juice of the sugar cane.
Telescoping: Capable of being extended or compacted, like a telescope, by the sliding of sections or parts one within the other; telescopic; as, telescoping tripod legs; a telescoping table, etc.; -- a term replacing the formerly used telescope.
Tirade: A declamatory strain or flight of censure or abuse; a rambling invective; an oration or harangue abounding in censorious and bitter language.
Thrummy: Like thrums; made of, furnished with, or characterized by, thrums.
Tiercel: The male of various falcons, esp. of the peregrine; also, the male of the goshawk.
Topknot: A crest or knot of feathers upon the head or top, as of a bird; also, an ornamental knot worn on top of the head, as by women.
Toil: Labor with pain and fatigue; labor that oppresses the body or mind, esp. the body.
Tiercet: A triplet; three lines, or three lines rhyming together.
Tribulation: That which occasions distress, trouble, or vexation; severe affliction.
Tenaillon: A work constructed on each side of the ravelins, to increase their strength, procure additional ground beyond the ditch, or cover the shoulders of the bastions.
Trapstick: A stick used in playing the game of trapball; hence, fig., a slender leg.
Transmit: To cause to pass over or through; to communicate by sending; to send from one person or place to another; to pass on or down as by inheritance; as, to transmit a memorial; to transmit dispatches; to transmit money, or bills of exchange, from one country to another.
Tillodontia: An extinct group of Mammalia found fossil in the Eocene formation. The species are related to the carnivores, ungulates, and rodents. Called also Tillodonta.
Tzar: The emperor of Russia.  See Czar.
Turbinella: A genus of large marine gastropods having a thick heavy shell with conspicuous folds on the columella.
Texas: A structure on the hurricane deck of a steamer, containing the pilot house, officers' cabins, etc.
Typewriter: An instrument for writing by means of type, a typewheel, or the like, in which the operator makes use of a sort of keyboard, in order to obtain printed impressions of the characters upon paper.
Trapezate: Having the form of a trapezium; trapeziform.
Tamis: A sieve, or strainer, made of a kind of woolen cloth.
Tonus: Tonicity, or tone; as, muscular tonus.
Tympanize: To stretch, as a skin over the head of a drum; to make into a drum or drumhead, or cause to act or sound like a drum.
Tag-rag: The lowest class of people; the rabble.  Cf. Rag, tag, and bobtail, under Bobtail.
Tentage: A collection of tents; an encampment.
Tropilidene: A liquid hydrocarbon obtained by the dry distillation of tropine with quicklime. It is regarded as being homologous with dipropargyl.
Tranquilizer: One who, or that which, tranquilizes.
Thumbscrew: A screw having a flat-sided or knurled head, so that it may be turned by the thumb and forefinger.
Transatlantic: Lying or being beyond the Atlantic Ocean.
Touching: The sense or act of feeling; touch.
Toed: Having (such or so many) toes; -- chiefly used in composition; as, narrow-toed, four-toed.
Turbinoid: Like or pertaining to Turbo or the family Turbinidæ.
Tamil: One of a Dravidian race of men native of Northern Ceylon and Southern India.
Tendon: A tough insensible cord, bundle, or band of fibrous connective tissue uniting a muscle with some other part; a sinew.
Teredo: A genus of long, slender, wormlike bivalve mollusks which bore into submerged wood, such as the piles of wharves, bottoms of ships, etc.; -- called also shipworm. See Shipworm. See Illust. in Appendix.
Telemeteorograph: Any apparatus recording meteorological phenomena at a distance from the measuring apparatus, as by electricity or by compressed air; esp., an apparatus recording conditions at many distant stations at a central office.
Trimmer: One who trims, arranges, fits, or ornaments.
Thewy: Having strong or large thews or muscles; muscular; sinewy; strong.
Thrift: A thriving state; good husbandry; economical management in regard to property; frugality.
Two-edged: Having two edges, or edges on both sides; as, a two-edged sword.
Transumption: Act of taking from one place to another.
Trout-colored: White, with spots of black, bay, or sorrel; as, a trout-colored horse.
Tropine: A white crystalline alkaloid, C8H15NO, produced by decomposing atropine.
Testacea: Invertebrate animals covered with shells, especially mollusks; shellfish.
Tyrannicidal: Of or pertaining to tyrannicide, or the murder of a tyrant.
Turmeric: Of or pertaining to turmeric; resembling, or obtained from, turmeric; specif., designating an acid obtained by the oxidation of turmerol.
Transient: That which remains but for a brief time.
Truism: An undoubted or self-evident truth; a statement which is pliantly true; a proposition needing no proof or argument; -- opposed to falsism.
Terneplate: Thin iron sheets coated with an alloy of lead and tin; -- so called because made up of three metals.
Tringle: A curtain rod for a bedstead.
Telephone: To convey or announce by telephone.
Terrapin: Any one of numerous species of tortoises living in fresh and brackish waters. Many of them are valued for food.
Telephony: The art or process of reproducing sounds at a distance, as with the telephone.
Terpsichore: The Muse who presided over the choral song and the dance, especially the latter.
touch on: To mention briefly, or in passing.
Twayblade: Any one of several orchidaceous plants which have only two leaves, as the species of Listera and of Liparis.
Turanians: An extensive division of mankind including the Mongols and allied races of Asia, together with the Malays and Polynesians.
Two-forked: Divided into two parts, somewhat after the manner of a fork; dichotomous.
Tressured: Provided or bound with a tressure; arranged in the form of a tressure.
Trackwalker: A person employed to walk over and inspect a section of tracks.
Tolane: A hydrocarbon, C14H10, related both to the acetylene and the aromatic series, and produced artificially as a white crystalline substance; -- called also diphenyl acetylene.
Thermography: Any process of writing involving the use of heat.
Top-draining: The act or practice of drining the surface of land.
Tragi-comedy: A kind of drama representing some action in which serious and comic scenes are blended; a composition partaking of the nature both of tragedy and comedy.
Transcursion: A rambling or ramble; a passage over bounds; an excursion.
Triquadrantal: Having three quadrants; thus, a triquadrantal triangle is one whose three sides are quadrants, and whose three angles are consequently right angles.
Trihybrid: A hybrid whose parents differ by three pairs of contrasting Mendelian characters.
Three-flowered: Bearing three flowers together, or only three flowers.
Tripoli: An earthy substance originally brought from Tripoli, used in polishing stones and metals. It consists almost wholly of the siliceous shells of diatoms.
Telharmonium: An instrument for producing music (Tel*har"mo*ny [&unr_;]), at a distant point or points by means of alternating currents of electricity controlled by an operator who plays on a keyboard. The music is produced by a receiving instrument similar or analogous to the telephone, but not held to the ear. The pitch corresponds with frequency of alternation of current.
Topper: One that tops, in any sense of the verb;
Trousseau: The collective lighter equipments or outfit of a bride, including clothes, jewelry, and the like; especially, that which is provided for her by her family.
Tetrapla: A Bible consisting of four different Greek versions arranged in four columns by Origen; hence, any version in four languages or four columns.
Tegula: A small appendage situated above the base of the wings of Hymenoptera and attached to the mesonotum.
Truncal: Of or pertaining to the trunk, or body.
Tonsured: Having the tonsure; shaven; shorn; clipped; hence, bald.
Thrips: Any one of numerous small species of Thysanoptera, especially those which attack useful plants, as the grain thrips (Thrips cerealium).
Trajection: The act of trajecting; a throwing or casting through or across; also, emission.
Teratoid: Resembling a monster; abnormal; of a pathological growth, exceedingly complex or highly organized.
Trilobita: An extinct order of arthropods comprising the trilobites.
Third: The quotient of a unit divided by three; one of three equal parts into which anything is divided.
Termless: Having no term or end; unlimited; boundless; unending; as, termless time.
Tubeform: In the form of a tube; tubular; tubiform.
Termagancy: The quality or state of being termagant; turbulence; tumultuousness; as, a violent termagancy of temper.
Transportal: Transportation; the act of removing from one locality to another.
Tetrabasic: Capable of neutralizing four molecules of a monacid base; having four hydrogen atoms capable of replacement by bases; quadribasic; -- said of certain acids; thus, normal silicic acid, Si(OH)4, is a tetrabasic acid.
Triobolar: Of the value of three oboli; hence, mean; worthless.
Triangulate: To divide into triangles; specifically, to survey by means of a series of triangles properly laid down and measured.
Tapeworm: Any one of numerous species of cestode worms belonging to Tænia and many allied genera. The body is long, flat, and composed of numerous segments or proglottids varying in shape, those toward the end of the body being much larger and longer than the anterior ones, and containing the fully developed sexual organs. The head is small, destitute of a mouth, but furnished with two or more suckers (which vary greatly in shape in different genera), and sometimes, also, with hooks for adhesion to the walls of the intestines of the animals in which they are parasitic. The larvæ (see Cysticercus) live in the flesh of various creatures, and when swallowed by another animal of the right species develop into the mature tapeworm in its intestine. See Illustration in Appendix.
Tatta: A bamboo frame or trellis hung at a door or window of a house, over which water is suffered to trickle, in order to moisten and cool the air as it enters.
Text-book: A book with wide spaces between the lines, to give room for notes.
Tidesman: A customhouse officer who goes on board of a merchant ship to secure payment of the duties; a tidewaiter.
Tussicular: Of or pertaining to a cough.
Troco: An old English game; -- called also lawn billiards.
Traject: A place for passing across; a passage; a ferry.
Town: Formerly: (a) An inclosure which surrounded the mere homestead or dwelling of the lord of the manor. [Obs.] (b) The whole of the land which constituted the domain. [Obs.] (c) A collection of houses inclosed by fences or walls.
Tonga: A kind of light two-wheeled vehicle, usually for four persons, drawn by ponies or bullocks.
Thatching: The act or art of covering buildings with thatch; so as to keep out rain, snow, etc.
Thyrohyoid: Of or pertaining to the thyroid cartilage of the larynx and the hyoid arch.
Tabasheer: A concretion in the joints of the bamboo, which consists largely or chiefly of pure silica. It is highly valued in the East Indies as a medicine for the cure of bilious vomitings, bloody flux, piles, and various other diseases.
Tank ship: A vessel fitted with tanks for the carrying of oil or other liquid in bulk; -- called also tanker.  A tank ship of very large capacity is called a supertanker.
Tongo: The mangrove; -- so called in the Pacific Islands.
Tetard: A gobioid fish (Eleotris gyrinus) of the Southern United States; -- called also sleeper.
Tectorial: Of or pertaining to covering; -- applied to a membrane immediately over the organ of Corti in the internal ear.
Tallow: To grease or smear with tallow.
Threadbare: Worn to the naked thread; having the nap worn off; threadbare clothes.
Turnhalle: A building used as a school of gymnastics.
Transilience: A leap across or from one thing to another.
Twain: Two; -- nearly obsolete in common discourse, but used in poetry and burlesque.
Trochilus: A genus of humming birds. It Formerly included all the known species.
Thorite: A mineral of a brown to black color, or, as in the variety orangite, orange-yellow. It is essentially a silicate of thorium.
Tyrannicide: The act of killing a tyrant.
Terse: Appearing as if rubbed or wiped off; rubbed; smooth; polished.
Traitorous: Guilty of treason; treacherous; perfidious; faithless; as, a traitorous officer or subject.
Tempter: One who tempts or entices; especially, Satan, or the Devil, regarded as the great enticer to evil.
Techiness: The quality or state of being techy.
Thievish: Given to stealing; addicted to theft; as, a thievish boy, a thievish magpie.
Torsion electrometer: A torsion balance used for measuring electric attraction or repulsion.
Talker: One who talks; especially, one who is noted for his power of conversing readily or agreeably; a conversationist.
Tapadera: One of the leather hoods which cover the stirrups of a Mexican saddle.
Tetrahedrite: A sulphide of antimony and copper, with small quantities of other metals. It is a very common ore of copper, and some varieties yield a considerable presentage of silver. Called also gray copper ore, fahlore, and panabase.
Tapestry beetle: A small black dermestoid beetle (Attagenus piceus) whose larva feeds on tapestry, carpets, silk, fur, flour, and various other goods.
Typhous: Of or pertaining to typhus; of the nature of typhus.
Tetractinellida: A division of Spongiæ in which the spicules are siliceous and have four branches diverging at right angles. Called also Tetractinellinæ.
Tidewaiter: A customhouse officer who watches the landing of goods from merchant vessels, in order to secure payment of duties.
Tumpline: A strap placed across a man's forehead to assist him in carrying a pack on his back.
Throaty: Guttural; hoarse; having a guttural voice.
Talesman: A person called to make up a deficiency in the number of jurors when a tales is awarded.
Temptation: The act of tempting, or enticing to evil; seduction.
Tetartohedral: Having one fourth the number of planes which are requisite to complete symmetry.
Tappet rod: A rod carrying a tappet or tappets, as one for closing the valves in a Cornish pumping engine.
Tipulary: Of or pertaining to the tipulas.
Teacup: A small cup from which to drink tea.
Tercine: A cellular layer derived from the nucleus of an ovule and surrounding the embryo sac.  Cf. Quintine.
Tergiversation: The act of tergiversating; a shifting; shift; subterfuge; evasion.
Tride: Short and ready; fleet; as, a tride pace; -- a term used by sportsmen.
Toothing: The act or process of indenting or furnishing with teeth.
Tributary: A ruler or state that pays tribute, or a stated sum, to a conquering power, for the purpose of securing peace and protection, or as an acknowledgment of submission, or for the purchase of security.
Taborine: A small, shallow drum; a tabor.
thaumaturgy: The act or art of performing something wonderful; magic; legerdemain.
Thoral: Of or pertaining to a bed.
Turnus: A common, large, handsome, American swallowtail butterfly, now regarded as one of the forms of Papilio glaucus syn. Jasoniades glaucus.  The wings are yellow, margined and barred with black, and with an orange-red spot near the posterior angle of the hind wings.  Called also tiger swallowtail. See Illust. under Swallowtail.
Third-rail system: A system in which a third rail is used for carrying the current for operating the motors, the rail being insulated from the ground and the current being taken off by means of contact brushes or other devices.
Tetramethylene: A hypothetical hydrocarbon, C4H8, analogous to trimethylene, and regarded as the base of well-known series or derivatives.
Telautogram: A message transmitted and recorded by a teleautograph.
Terbic: Of, pertaining to, or containing, terbium; also, designating certain of its compounds.
Twill: An appearance of diagonal lines or ribs produced in textile fabrics by causing the weft threads to pass over one and under two, or over one and under three or more, warp threads, instead of over one and under the next in regular succession, as in plain weaving.
Terpene: Any one of a series of isomeric hydrocarbons of pleasant aromatic odor, occurring especially in coniferous plants and represented by oil of turpentine, but including also certain hydrocarbons found in some essential oils.
Tenthmeter: A unit for the measurement of many small lengths, such that 1010 of these units make one meter; the ten millionth part of a millimeter.
Trimellic: Of, pertaining to, or designating, a certain tribasic acid (called also trimellitic acid) metameric with trimesitic acid.
Transparent: Having the property of transmitting rays of light, so that bodies can be distinctly seen through; pervious to light; diaphanous; pellucid; as, transparent glass; a transparent diamond; -- opposed to opaque.
Thorax: The part of the trunk between the neck and the abdomen, containing that part of the body cavity the walls of which are supported by the dorsal vertebræ, the ribs, and the sternum, and which the heart and lungs are situated; the chest.
Take off: To remove, as from the surface or outside; to remove from the top of anything; as, to take off a load; to take off one's hat, coat or other article of clothing; to take off a coat of paint from a surface.
Theophany: A manifestation of God to man by actual appearance, usually as an incarnation.
Theomachy: A fighting against the gods, as the battle of the gaints with the gods.
Tonguy: Ready or voluble in speaking; as, a tonguy speaker.
Transshipment: The act of transshipping, or transferring, as goods, from one ship or conveyance to another.
Threaden: Made of thread; as, threaden sails; a threaden fillet.
thanedom: The property or jurisdiction of a thane; thanage.
Trinkle: To act secretly, or in an underhand way; to tamper.
Tintometer: An apparatus for the determination of colors by comparison with arbitrary standards; a colorimeter.
Truismatic: Of or pertaining to truisms; consisting of truisms.
Temporo-auricular: Of or pertaining to both the temple and the ear; as, the temporo-auricular nerve.
Traversable: Capable of being traversed, or passed over; as, a traversable region.
Three-ply: Consisting of three distinct webs inwrought together in weaving, as cloth or carpeting; having three strands; threefold.
Trigonocerous: Having horns with three angles, like those of some species of goats.
Threader: A device for assisting in threading a needle.
Trullization: The act of laying on coats of plaster with a trowel.
Tenesmus: An urgent and distressing sensation, as if a discharge from the intestines must take place, although none can be effected; -- always referred to the lower extremity of the rectum.
Tongkang: A kind of boat or junk used in the seas of the Malay Archipelago.
tuppence: A former U.K. silver coin; a U.K. bronze decimal coin worth two pennies.
Toughness: The quality or state of being tough.
Tontine: An annuity, with the benefit of survivorship, or a loan raised on life annuities with the benefit of survivorship. Thus, an annuity is shared among a number, on the principle that the share of each, at his death, is enjoyed by the survivors, until at last the whole goes to the last survivor, or to the last two or three, according to the terms on which the money is advanced. Used also adjectively; as, tontine insurance.
Triamine: An amine containing three amido groups.
Terreplein: The top, platform, or horizontal surface, of a rampart, on which the cannon are placed. See Illust. of Casemate.
Thysanuran: One of the Thysanura. Also used adjectively.
Teenful: Full of teen; harmful; grievous; grieving; afflicted.
Troche: A medicinal tablet or lozenge; strictly, one of circular form.
Trabecula: A small bar, rod, bundle of fibers, or septal membrane, in the framework of an organ part.
Torvity: Sourness or severity of countenance; sternness.
Talbot: A sort of dog, noted for quick scent and eager pursuit of game.
Tuxedo: A kind of black jacket for semiformal evening dress made without tails, usually of black or dark blue color and having satin or grosgrain facing on the lapels; -- so named after a fashionable country club at Tuxedo Park, New York.
Taintless: Free from taint or infection; pure.
Telegraphone: An instrument for recording and reproducing sound by local magnetization of a steel wire, disk, or ribbon, moved against the pole of a magnet connected electrically with a telephone receiver, or the like.
Transom: A horizontal crossbar in a window, over a door, or between a door and a window above it. Transom is the horizontal, as mullion is the vertical, bar across an opening. See Illust. of Mullion.
Teamed: Yoked in, or as in, a team.
Technologist: One skilled in technology; one who treats of arts, or of the terms of arts.
Tracheate: Any arthropod having tracheæ; one of the Tracheata.
Tabernacle: To dwell or reside for a time; to be temporary housed.
Turfen: Made of turf; covered with turf.
Tetrameter: A verse or line consisting of four measures, that is, in iambic, trochaic, and anapestic verse, of eight feet; in other kinds of verse, of four feet.
Trochee: A foot of two syllables, the first long and the second short, as in the Latin word ante, or the first accented and the second unaccented, as in the English word motion; a choreus.
Tenosynovitis: Inflammation of the synovial sheath of a tendon.
Tetraspaston: A machine in which four pulleys act together.
Torch song: a popular song with a sentimental theme of unrequited love or other form of unhappiness.
Trimestrial: Of or pertaining to a trimester, or period of three months; occurring once in every three months; quarterly.
Transire: A customhouse clearance for a coasting vessel; a permit.
Talcose: Of or pertaining to talc; composed of, or resembling, talc.
Transmitter: One who, or that which, transmits; specifically, that portion of a telegraphic or telephonic instrument by means of which a message is sent; -- opposed to receiver.
Terephthalic: Of, pertaining to, or designating, a dibasic acid of the aromatic series, metameric with phthalic acid, and obtained, as a tasteless white crystalline powder, by the oxidation of oil of turpentine; -- called also paraphthalic acid.  Cf. Phthalic.
Treasurer: One who has the care of a treasure or treasure or treasury; an officer who receives the public money arising from taxes and duties, or other sources of revenue, takes charge of the same, and disburses it upon orders made by the proper authority; one who has charge of collected funds; as, the treasurer of a society or corporation.
Theta: A letter of the Greek alphabet corresponding to th in English; -- sometimes called the unlucky letter, from being used by the judges on their ballots in passing condemnation on a prisoner, it being the first letter of the Greek qa`natos, death.
Tactician: One versed in tactics; hence, a skillful maneuverer; an adroit manager.
Top-light: A lantern or light on the top of a vessel.
Tercel: See Tiercel. Called also tarsel, tassel.
Telegraphic: Of or pertaining to the telegraph; made or communicated by a telegraph; as, telegraphic signals; telegraphic art; telegraphic intelligence.
trades union: An organized combination among workmen for the purpose of maintaining their rights, privileges, and interests with respect to wages, hours of labor, customs, etc.
Tensility: The quality or state of being tensile, or capable of extension; tensibility; as, the tensility of the muscles.
Tubularian: Of or pertaining to the tubularians.
Trape: To walk or run about in an idle or slatternly manner; to traipse.
Tangent: Touching; touching at a single point
Trichromatism: The quality, state, or phenomenon of being trichromatic.
Telephotograph: a photograph transmitted and reproduced by telephotography.
Teacher: One who teaches or instructs; one whose business or occupation is to instruct others; an instructor; a tutor.
Teller: One who tells, relates, or communicates; an informer, narrator, or describer.
Tear-thumb: A name given to several species of plants of the genus Polygonum, having angular stems beset with minute reflexed prickles.
Twifallow: To plow, or fallow, a second time (land that has been once fallowed).
Testiculate: Shaped like a testicle, ovate and solid.
Tetramerous: Having the parts arranged in sets of four; as, a tetramerous flower.
Trombone: A powerful brass instrument of the trumpet kind, thought by some to be the ancient sackbut, consisting of a tube in three parts, bent twice upon itself and ending in a bell.  The middle part, bent double, slips into the outer parts, as in a telescope, so that by change of the vibrating length any tone within the compass of the instrument (which may be bass or tenor or alto or even, in rare instances, soprano) is commanded.  It is the only member of the family of wind instruments whose scale, both diatonic and chromatic, is complete without the aid of keys or pistons, and which can slide from note to note as smoothly as the human voice or a violin.  Softly blown, it has a rich and mellow sound, which becomes harsh and blatant when the tones are forced; used with discretion, its effect is often solemn and majestic.
Triquetrum: One of the bones of the carpus; the cuneiform. See Cuneiform (b).
Tombac: An alloy of copper and zinc, resembling brass, and containing about 84 per cent of copper; -- called also German brass or Dutch brass.  It is very malleable and ductile, and when beaten into thin leaves is sometimes called Dutch metal.  The addition of arsenic makes white tombac.
Tidiness: The quality or state of being tidy.
Thermometrograph: An instrument for recording graphically the variations of temperature, or the indications of a thermometer.
The: By that; by how much; by so much; on that account; -- used before comparatives; as, the longer we continue in sin, the more difficult it is to reform.
Tut-work: Work done by the piece, as in nonmetaliferous rock, the amount done being usually reckoned by the fathom.
Trackman: One employed on work on the track; specif., a trackwalker.
Tother: A colloquial contraction of the other, and formerly a contraction for that other. See the Note under That, 2.
Trop\u00e6olin: A name given to any one of a series of orange-red dyestuffs produced artificially from certain complex sulphonic acid derivatives of azo and diazo hydrocarbons of the aromatic series; -- so called because of the general resemblance to the shades of nasturtium (Tropæolum).
Touring car: An automobile designed for touring; specif., a roomy car, not a limousine, for five or more passengers.
Tsar: The title of the emperor of Russia. See Czar.
Trisnitrate: A nitrate formed from three molecules of nitric acid; also, less properly, applied to certain basic nitrates; as, trisnitrate of bismuth.
Trinodal: Having three knots or nodes; having three points from which a leaf may shoot; as, a trinodal stem.
Triweekly: Occurring or appearing three times a week; thriceweekly; as, a triweekly newspaper.
Taxonomic: Pertaining to, or involving, taxonomy, or the laws and principles of classification; classificatory.
touch up paint: A paint applied to small areas of a painted surface, to cover small blemishes, especially on an automobile.
Tolyl: The hydrocarbon radical, CH3.C6H4, regarded as characteristic of certain compounds of the aromatic series related to toluene; as, tolyl carbinol.
Tetradynamian: Belonging to the order Tetradynamia; having six stamens, four of which are uniformly longer than the others.
Tubulicole: Any hydroid which has tubular chitinous stems.
Tenable: Capable of being held, maintained, or defended, as against an assailant or objector, or against attempts to take or process; as, a tenable fortress, a tenable argument.
Tonneau: In France, a light-wheeled vehicle with square or rounded body and rear entrance.
Thyroid: Shaped like an oblong shield; shield-shaped; as, the thyroid cartilage.
Thoracic: One of a group of fishes having the ventral fins placed beneath the thorax or beneath the pectorial fins.
Telpher: A contrivance for the conveyance of vehicles or loads by means of electricity.
Triglyphic: Consisting of, or pertaining to, triglyphs.
Theist: One who believes in the existence of a God; especially, one who believes in a personal God; -- opposed to atheist.
Tum-tum: A dish made in the West Indies by beating boiled plantain quite soft in a wooden mortar.
Thoracentesis: The operation of puncturing the chest wall so as to let out liquids contained in the cavity of the chest.
Theism: The morbid condition resulting from the excessive use of tea.
Turbid: Not clear; having suspended matter that scatters light passing through; having the lees or sediment disturbed; roiled; muddy; thick; -- used of liquids of any kind; as, turbid water; turbid wine.
Treater: One who treats; one who handles, or discourses on, a subject; also, one who entertains.
Treasure-house: A house or building where treasures and stores are kept.
Theodolitic: Of or pertaining to a theodolite; made by means of a theodolite; as, theodolitic observations.
Tetanize: To throw, as a muscle, into a state of permanent contraction; to cause tetanus in. See Tetanus, n., 2.
Tucker: To tire; to weary; -- usually with out.
theanthropic: Partaking of, or combining, both divinity and humanity.
Timaline: Of or pertaining to the genus Timalus or family Timalidæ, which includes the babblers thrushes, and bulbuls.
telegraphese: language characterized by terseness and ellipsis as in telegrams.
Transgression: The act of transgressing, or of passing over or beyond any law, civil or moral; the violation of a law or known principle of rectitude; breach of command; fault; offense; crime; sin.
Torpid: An inferior racing boat, or one who rows in such a boat.
Tailing: The part of a projecting stone or brick inserted in a wall.
Timeserver: One who adapts his opinions and manners to the times; one who obsequiously compiles with the ruling power; -- now used only in a bad sense.
Trachelidan: Any one of a tribe of beetles (Trachelides) which have the head supported on a pedicel. The oil beetles and the Cantharides are examples.
Tyrociny: The state of being a tyro, or beginner; apprenticeship.
Turrical: Of or pertaining to a turret, or tower; resembling a tower.
Tradeswoman: A woman who trades, or is skilled in trade.
Tickler: One who, or that which, tickles.
Townhall: A public hall or building, belonging to a town, where the public offices are established, the town council meets, the people assemble in town meeting, etc.
Trawl: A fishing line, often extending a mile or more, having many short lines bearing hooks attached to it. It is used for catching cod, halibut, etc.; a boulter.
Treachery: Violation of allegiance or of faith and confidence; treasonable or perfidious conduct; perfidy; treason.
Tyro: A beginner in learning; one who is in the rudiments of any branch of study; a person imperfectly acquainted with a subject; a novice.
Transmogrify: To change into a different shape; to transform.
Tillot: A bag made of thin glazed muslin, used as a wrapper for dress goods.
Tellurism: An hypothesis of animal magnetism propounded by Dr. Keiser, in Germany, in which the phenomena are ascribed to the agency of a telluric spirit or influence.
Thalweg: A line following the lowest part of a valley, whether under water or not.
Thirty: The sum of three tens, or twenty and ten; thirty units or objects.
Thanatology: A description, or the doctrine, of death.
Tupperware party: a social gathering at which the host (or more typically hostess) entertains the guests, and provides them with an opportunity to order Tupperware.  This was used as an effective sales strategy by the Tupperware manufacturer, and provided income to the host(ess) from commissions on sales.
Tucum: A fine, strong fiber obtained from the young leaves of a Brazilian palm (Astrocaryum vulgare), used for cordage, bowstrings, etc.; also, the plant yielding this fiber. Called also tecum, and tecum fiber.
Tarantella: A rapid and delirious sort of Neapolitan dance in 6-8 time, which moves in whirling triplets; -- so called from a popular notion of its being a remedy against the poisonous bite of the tarantula. Some derive its name from Taranto in Apulia.
Thanksgiving: The act of rending thanks, or expressing gratitude for favors or mercies.
Tractarianism: The principles of the Tractarians, or of those persons accepting the teachings of the “Tracts for the Times.”
Tonicity: The state of healthy tension or partial contraction of muscle fibers while at rest; tone; tonus.
Tantalum: A rare nonmetallic element found in certain minerals, as tantalite, samarskite, and fergusonite, and isolated as a dark powder which becomes steel-gray by burnishing. Symbol Ta. Atomic weight 182.0. Formerly called also tantalium.
Typograph: A machine for setting type or for casting lines of type and setting them.
Tortrix: Any one of numerous species of small moths of the family Tortricidæ, the larvæ of which usually roll up the leaves of plants on which they live; -- also called leaf roller.
Twittingly: In a twitting manner; with upbraiding.
Transpassable: Capable of being transpassed, or crossed over.
Thumbkin: An instrument of torture for compressing the thumb; a thumbscrew.
Tuft: To grow in, or form, a tuft or tufts.
turaco: Any one of several species of large brightly crested birds of the genus Turacus, native of Africa.  They eat plantain and are remarkable for the peculiar green and red pigments found in their feathers.
Templet: A gauge, pattern, or mold, commonly a thin plate or board, used as a guide to the form of the work to be executed; as, a mason's or a wheelwright's templet.
Tameless: Incapable of being tamed; wild; untamed; untamable.
Thirsty: Feeling thirst; having a painful or distressing sensation from want of drink; hence, having an eager desire.
Turgent: Rising into a tumor, or a puffy state; swelling; tumid; as, turgent humors.
Throstle: The song thrush. See under Song.
Triliteral: Consisting of three letters; trigrammic; as, a triliteral root or word.
Tienda: In Cuba, Mexico, etc., a booth, stall, or shop where merchandise is sold.
Tontine insurance: Insurance in which the benefits of the insurance are distributed upon the tontine principle. Under the old, or full tontine, plan, all benefits were forfeited on lapsed policies, on the policies of those who died within the tontine period only the face of the policy was paid without any share of the surplus, and the survivor at the end of the tontine period received the entire surplus. This plan of tontine insurance has been replaced in the United States by the semitontine plan, in which the surplus is divided among the holders of policies in force at the termination of the tontine period, but the reverse for the paid-up value is paid on lapsed policies, and on the policies of those that have died the face is paid. Other modified forms are called free tontine, deferred dividend, etc., according to the nature of the tontine arrangement.
Trapeziform: Having the form of a trapezium; trapezoid.
Tarot: A game of cards; -- called also taroc.
Templed: Supplied with a temple or temples, or with churches; inclosed in a temple.
Telford: Designating, or pert. to, a road pavement having a surface of small stone rolled hard and  smooth, distinguished from macadam road by its firm foundation of large stones with fragments of stone wedged tightly, in the interstices; as, telford pavement, road, etc.
Trinitarianism: The doctrine of the Trinity; the doctrine that there are three distinct persons in the Godhead.
Takeoff: An imitation, especially in the way of caricature; -- used with of or on; as, the comedian did a hilarious takeoff on the president.
Tantrism: The system of doctrines and  rites taught in the tantras.
Taglock: An entangled lock, as of hair or wool.
Trilateral: Having three sides; being three-sided; as, a trilateral triangle.
Trainable: Capable of being trained or educated; as, boys trainable to virtue.
Tantalic: Of or pertaining to tantalum; derived from, or containing, tantalum; specifically, designating any one of a series of acids analogous to nitric acid and the polyacid compounds of phosphorus.
Thesicle: A little or subordinate thesis; a proposition.
Tait: A small nocturnal and arboreal Australian marsupial (Tarsipes rostratus) about the size of a mouse. It has a long muzzle, a long tongue, and very few teeth, and feeds upon honey and insects. Called also noolbenger.
Trihoral: Occurring once in every three hours.
Thermotype: A picture (as of a slice of wood) obtained by first wetting the object slightly with hydrochloric or dilute sulphuric acid, then taking an impression with a press, and next strongly heating this impression.
Tain: Thin tin plate; also, tin foil for mirrors.
Tronator: An officer in London whose duty was to weigh wool.
Tail: To hold by the end; -- said of a timber when it rests upon a wall or other support; -- with in or into.
Tentaculate: Having tentacles, or organs like tentacles; tentacled.
Trehala: An amorphous variety of manna obtained from the nests and cocoons of a Syrian coleopterous insect (Larinus maculatus, Larinus nidificans, etc.) which feeds on the foliage of a variety of thistle. It is used as an article of food, and is called also nest sugar.
Thrifty: Given to, or evincing, thrift; characterized by economy and good menegement of property; sparing; frugal.
Translatable: Capable of being translated, or rendered into another language.
Tentaculata: A division of Ctenophora including those which have two long tentacles.
Tribunician: Of or pertaining to tribunes; befitting a tribune; as, tribunitial power or authority.
Trachoma: a contagious granular conjunctivitis caused by the bacterium Chlamydia trachomatis.  It is a chronic inflammation of the conjunctiva
Temerarious: Unreasonably adventurous; despising danger; rash; headstrong; audacious; reckless; heedless.
Teache: Any one of the series of boilers or evaporating pans in which the cane juice is concentrated in making sugar; especially, the last boiler of the series.
Theobroma: A genus of small trees. See Cacao.
Towery: Having towers; adorned or defended by towers.
Trachymedus\u00e6: A division of acalephs in which the development is direct from the eggs, without a hydroid stage. Some of the species are parasitic on other medusæ.
Trabeculate: Crossbarred, as the ducts in a banana stem.
Tivy: With great speed; -- a huntsman's word or sound.
Transactor: One who transacts, performs, or conducts any business.
Trousse: A case for small implements; as, a surgeon's trousse.
Thorium: A metallic element found in certain rare minerals, as thorite, pyrochlore, monazite, etc., and isolated as an infusible gray metallic powder which burns in the air and forms thoria; -- formerly called also thorinum. Symbol Th. Atomic weight 232.0.
Tundra: One of the level or undulating treeless plains characteristic of northern arctic regions in both hemispheres; the term is most commony associated with the arctic plains of Siberia.  The tundras mark the limit of arborescent vegetation; they consist of black mucky soil with a permanently frozen subsoil, but support a dense growth of mosses and lichens, and dwarf herbs and shrubs, often showy-flowered.
Trirectangular: Having three right angles. See Triquadrantal.
Twenty-fourmo: Having twenty-four leaves to a sheet; as, a twenty-fourmo form, book, leaf, size, etc.
Transmission dynamometer: A dynamometer in which power is measured, without being absorbed or used up, during transmission.
Tuberculosis: A constitutional disease caused by infection with Mycobacterium tuberculosis (also called the Tubercle bacillus), characterized by the production of tubercles in the internal organs, and especially in the lungs, where it constitutes the most common variety of pulmonary phthisis (consumption).  The Mycobacteria are slow-growing and without cell walls, and are thus not affected by the beta-lactam antibiotics; treatment is difficult, usually requiring simultaneous administration of multiple antibiotics to effect a cure.  Prior to availability of antibiotic treatment, the cure required extensive rest, for which special sanatoriums were constructed.
Terry: A kind of heavy colored fabric, either all silk, or silk and worsted, or silk and cotton, often called terry velvet, used for upholstery and trimmings.
Tropic: Of or pertaining to the tropics; tropical.
Tetragonal: Of or pertaining to a tetragon; having four angles or sides; thus, the square, the parallelogram, the rhombus, and the trapezium are tetragonal fingers.
Torsional: Of or pertaining to torsion; resulting from torsion, or the force with which a thread or wire returns to a state of rest after having been twisted round its axis; as, torsional force.
Twaddell: A form of hydrometer for liquids heavier than water, graduated with an arbitrary scale such that the readings when multiplied by .005 and added to unity give the specific gravity.
Tubule: A small pipe or fistular body; a little tube.
thaumaturgics: Feats of legerdemain, or magical performances.
Torpedo: to destroy by, or subject to the action of, a torpedo.
Telestich: A poem in which the final letters of the lines, taken consequently, make a name.  Cf. Acrostic.
Tun-great: Having the circumference of a tun.
Tentaculocyst: One of the auditory organs of certain medusæ; -- called also auditory tentacle.
Tracheata: An extensive division of arthropods comprising all those which breathe by tracheæ, as distinguished from Crustacea, which breathe by means of branchiæ.
Thallophyte: A plant belonging to the Thallophyta.
Thallophyta: A phylum of plants of very diverse habit and structure, including the algæ, fungi, and lichens. The simpler forms, as many blue-green algæ, yeasts, etc., are unicellular and reproduce vegetatively or  by means of asexual spores; in the higher forms the plant body is a thallus, which may be filamentous or may consist of plates of cells; it is commonly undifferentiated into stem, leaves, and roots, and shows no distinct tissue systems; the fronds of many algæ, however, are modified to serve many of the functions of the above-named organs. Both asexual and sexual reproduction, often of a complex type, occur in these forms. The Thallophyta exist almost exclusively as gametophytes, the sporophyte being absent or rudimentary. By those who do not separate the Myxophyta from the Tallophyta as a distinct phylum the latter is treated as the lowermost group in the vegetable kingdom.
Tabling: A forming into tables; a setting down in order.
Thwaite: Forest land cleared, and converted to tillage; an assart.
Touchstone: Lydian stone; basanite; -- so called because used to test the purity of gold and silver by the streak which is left upon the stone when it is rubbed by the metal. See Basanite.
Telson: The terminal joint or movable piece at the end of the abdomen of Crustacea and other articulates. See Thoracostraca.
Thrombus: A clot of blood formed of a passage of a vessel and remaining at the site of coagulation.
Teenage: of or pertaining to a teenager; being in one's teens; as, a busload of teenage football fans; teenage inexperience.
Tossy: Tossing the head, as in scorn or pride; hence, proud; contemptuous; scornful; affectedly indifferent; as, a tossy commonplace.
Tulipomaniac: One who is affected with tulipomania.
Transudatory: Of or pertaining to transudation; passing by transudation.
thou: The second personal pronoun, in the singular number, denoting the person addressed; thyself; the pronoun which is used in addressing persons in the solemn or poetical style.
Trebly: In a treble manner; with a threefold number or quantity; triply.
Tidings: Account of what has taken place, and was not before known; news.
Thermobarograph: An instrument for recording simultaneously the pressure and temperature of a gas; a combined thermograph and barograph.
Totem: A rude picture, as of a bird, beast, or the like, used by the North American Indians as a symbolic designation, as of a family or a clan; also, the object or animal itself, considered as an symbol of the family.
Tractator: One who writes tracts; specif., a Tractarian.
Toter: The stone roller. See Stone roller (a), under Stone.
Teaze-hole: The opening in the furnaces through which fuel is introduced.
Transcript: That which has been transcribed; a writing or composition consisting of the same words as the original; a written copy.
Tomcod: A small edible American fish (Microgadus tomcod) of the Codfish family, very abundant in autumn on the Atlantic coast of the Northen United States; -- called also frostfish. See Illust. under Frostfish.
Taxicorn: One of a family of beetles (Taxicornes) whose antennæ are largest at the tip. Also used adjectively.
Tectonics: The science, or the art, by which implements, vessels, dwellings, or other edifices, are constructed, both agreeably to the end for which they are designed, and in conformity with artistic sentiments and ideas.
Thermochemistry: That branch of chemical science which includes the investigation of the various relations existing between chemical action and that manifestation of force termed heat, or the determination of the heat evolved by, or employed in, chemical actions.
Title-page: The page of a book which contains it title.
T\u00e6nidium: The chitinous fiber forming the spiral thread of the tracheæ of insects. See Illust. of Trachea.
Tureen: A large, deep vessel for holding soup, or other liquid food, at the table.
Tripitaka: The three divisions, or “baskets” (pitakas), of buddhist scriptures, -- the Vinayapitaka [Skr. Vinayapi&tsdot_;aka] , or Basket of Discipline; Suttapitaka [Pali] , or Basket of Discourses; and Abhidhammapitaka [Pali] , or Basket of Metaphysics.
Trepang: Any one of several species of large holothurians, some of which are dried and extensively used as food in China; -- called also bêche de mer, sea cucumber, and sea slug.
Temperature: Constitution; state; degree of any quality.
Tachygrapher: One who writes shorthand; a stenographer; esp., an ancient Greek or Roman notary.
Tumulous: Full of small hills or mounds; hilly; tumulose.
Text hand: A large hand in writing; -- so called because it was the practice to write the text of a book in a large hand and the notes in a smaller hand.
Thamyn: An Asiatic deer (Rucervus Eldi) resembling the swamp deer; -- called also Eld's deer.
Tremolite: A white variety of amphibole, or hornblende, occurring in long, bladelike crystals, and coarsely fibrous masses.
Taurus: The Bull; the second in order of the twelve signs of the zodiac, which the sun enters about the 20th of April; -- marked thus [&taurus_;] in almanacs.
Toned: Having (such) a tone; -- chiefly used in composition; as, high-toned; sweet-toned.
Tabes: Progressive emaciation of the body, accompanied with hectic fever, with no well-marked local symptoms.
Transferee: The person to whom a transfer in made.
Trocar: A stylet, usually with a triangular point, used for exploring tissues or for inserting drainage tubes, as in dropsy.
Throttler: One who, or that which, throttles, or chokes.
Tyrosin: A white crystalline nitrogenous substance present in small amount in the pancreas and spleen, and formed in large quantity from the decomposition of proteid matter by various means, -- as by pancreatic digestion, by putrefaction as of cheese, by the action of boiling acids, etc. Chemically, it consists of oxyphenol and amidopropionic acid, and by decomposition yields oxybenzoic acid, or some other benzol derivative.
Tachygraph: An example of tachygraphy; esp., an ancient Greek or Roman tachygraphic manuscript.
Torture: Extreme pain; anguish of body or mind; pang; agony; torment; as, torture of mind.
Tenaculum: An instrument consisting of a fine, sharp hook attached to a handle, and used mainly for taking up arteries, and the like.
Tabasco sauce: A kind of very pungent sauce made from red peppers.
Temptability: The quality or state of being temptable; lability to temptation.
Tac-au-tac: The parry which is connected with a riposte; also, a series of quick attacks and parries in which neither fencer gains a point.
Teratological: Of or pertaining to teratology; as, teratological changes.
Turnstone: Any species of limicoline birds of the genera Strepsilas and Arenaria, allied to the plovers, especially the common American and European species (Strepsilas interpres). They are so called from their habit of turning up small stones in search of mollusks and other aquatic animals. Called also brant bird, sand runner, sea quail, sea lark, sparkback, and skirlcrake.
Tensity: The quality or state of being tense, or strained to stiffness; tension; tenseness.
Transformism: The hypothesis, or doctrine, that living beings have originated by the modification of some other previously existing forms of living matter; -- opposed to abiogenesis.
Trisacramentarian: One who recognizes three sacraments, and no more; -- namely, baptism, the Lord's Supper, and penance. See Sacrament.
Technicolor: the name of one process used for color cinematography; -- also used attributively.
Thematic: Of or pertaining to the theme of a word. See Theme, n., 4.
Tortuoslty: the quality or state of being tortuous.
Teneral: Of, pertaining to, or designating, a condition assumed by the imago of certain Neuroptera, after exclusion from the pupa. In this state the insect is soft, and has not fully attained its mature coloring.
Torosity: The quality or state of being torose.
Theophilanthropist: A member of a deistical society established at Paris during the French revolution.
Toparch: The ruler or principal man in a place or country; the governor of a toparchy.
Triptote: A noun having three cases only.
Theophilanthropism: The doctrine of the theophilanthropists; theophilanthropy.
Thorny: Full of thorns or spines; rough with thorns; spiny; as, a thorny wood; a thorny tree; a thorny crown.
Timbuctoo: A city on the southern edge of the Sahara, in central Africa, some nine miles from the Niger.  It is about three miles around, and was formerly surrounded by a clay wall.  Timbuctoo has a large caravan trade, gold dust being the most important export.  The people are negroes, Tuariks, Mandingoes, Arabs, Foolahs, etc.  The city was founded in the 12th century, but was first seen by a white man in 1826.  Timbuctoo now belongs to France, and a railroad is proposed to connect Algiers, Timbuctoo and Senegambia.  Population, 13,000 (1893), greatly increased during the trading season from November to January.
Tumultuation: Irregular or disorderly movement; commotion; as, the tumultuation of the parts of a fluid.
Torrent: Rolling or rushing in a rapid stream.
Tittuppy: Given to tittuping; gay; lively; prancing; also, shaky; unsteady.
Telesm: A kind of amulet or magical charm.
Temporarily: In a temporary manner; for a time.
Tomjohn: A kind of open sedan used in Ceylon, carried by a single pole on men's shoulders.
Tradescantia: A genus including spiderwort and Wandering Jew.
Taproom: A room where liquors are kept on tap; a barroom.
Trachyte: An igneous rock, usually light gray in color and breaking with a rough surface. It consists chiefly of orthoclase feldspar with sometimes hornblende and mica.
Tisri: The seventh month of the Jewish ecclesiastical year, answering to a part of September with a part of October.
Tripersonality: The state of existing as three persons in one Godhead; trinity.
Taproot: The root of a plant which penetrates the earth directly downward to a considerable depth without dividing.
Tasty: Having a good taste; -- applied to persons; as, a tasty woman. See Taste, n., 5.
Theosophy: Any system of philosophy or mysticism which proposes to attain intercourse with God and superior spirits, and consequent superhuman knowledge, by physical processes, as by the theurgic operations of some ancient Platonists, or by the chemical processes of the German fire philosophers; also, a direct, as distinguished from a revealed, knowledge of God, supposed to be attained by extraordinary illumination; especially, a direct insight into the processes of the divine mind, and the interior relations of the divine nature.
Tweak: A sharp pinch or jerk; a twist or twitch; as, a tweak of the nose.
Tracheitis: Inflammation of the trachea, or windpipe.
Tuck pointing: The finishing of joints along the center lines with a narrow ridge of putty or fine lime mortar.
Tubular: Having the form of a tube, or pipe; consisting of a pipe; fistular; as, a tubular snout; a tubular calyx. Also, containing, or provided with, tubes.
Troilite: Native iron protosulphide, FeS. It is known only in meteoric irons, and is usually in imbedded nodular masses of a bronze color.
Thermochemic: Of or pertaining to thermochemistry; obtained by, or employed in, thermochemistry.
T is: A common contraction of it is.
Tsarina: The title of the empress of Russia. See Czarina.
Tinean: Any species of Tinea, or of the family Tineidæ, which includes numerous small moths, many of which are injurious to woolen and fur goods and to cultivated plants. Also used adjectively.
Tungstenic: Of or pertaining to tungsten; containing tungsten; as, tungstenic ores.
Temporal: Anything temporal or secular; a temporality; -- used chiefly in the plural.
Thickskull: A dullard, or dull person; a blockhead; a numskull.
Tilery: A place where tiles are made or burned; a tile kiln.
Tithonographic: Of, relating to, or produced by, the chemical action of rays of light; photographic.
Teamwork: Work done by a team, as distinguished from that done by personal labor.
Tripetaloid: Having the form or appearance of three petals; appearing as if furnished with three petals.
Tid: Tender; soft; nice; -- now only used in tidbit.
Tie: To make a tie; to make an equal score.
Tumultuariness: The quality or state of being tumultuary.
Thyrohyal: One of the lower segments in the hyoid arch, often consolidated with the body of the hyoid bone and forming one of its great horns, as in man.
Transfeminate: To change into a woman, as a man.
Theorizer: One who theorizes or speculates; a theorist.
Three-square: Having a cross section in the form of an equilateral triangle; -- said especially of a kind of file.
Talipot: A beautiful tropical palm tree (Corypha umbraculifera), a native of Ceylon and the Malabar coast. It has a trunk sixty or seventy feet high, bearing a crown of gigantic fan-shaped leaves which are used as umbrellas and as fans in ceremonial processions, and, when cut into strips, as a substitute for writing paper.
Tweedle: To handle lightly; -- said with reference to awkward fiddling; hence, to influence as if by fiddling; to coax; to allure.
Tree calf: A bright brown polished calfskin binding of  books, stained with a conventional treelike design.
Tachymeter: An instrument, esp. a transit or theodolite with stadia wires, for determining quickly the distances, bearings, and elevations of distant objects.
Thalia: That one of the nine Muses who presided over comedy.
Tube-shell: Any bivalve mollusk which secretes a shelly tube around its siphon, as the watering-shell.
Tentacle: A more or less elongated process or organ, simple or branched, proceeding from the head or cephalic region of invertebrate animals, being either an organ of sense, prehension, or motion.
Tottlish: Trembling or tottering, as if about to fall; unsteady.
Trephine: To perforate with a trephine; to trepan.
Tidal: Of or pertaining to tides; caused by tides; having tides; periodically rising and falling, or following and ebbing; as, tidal waters.
Thoroughwax: An umbelliferous plant (Bupleurum rotundifolium) with perfoliate leaves.
Tachylyte: A vitreous form of basalt; -- so called because decomposable by acids and readily fusible.
Technicalness: The quality or state of being technical; technicality.
Thoric: Of or pertaining to thorium; designating the compounds of thorium.
Thrum-eyed: Having the anthers raised above the stigma, and visible at the throat of the corolla, as in long-stamened primroses; -- the reverse of pin-eyed.
Transliterate: To express or represent in the characters of another alphabet; as, to transliterate Sanskrit words by means of English letters.
Thimblerig: To swindle by means of small cups or thimbles, and a pea or small ball placed under one of them and quickly shifted to another, the victim laying a wager that he knows under which cup it is; hence, to cheat by any trick.
Thymic: Pertaining to, or derived from, thyme; as, thymic acid.
Thermotic: Of or pertaining to heat; produced by heat; as, thermotical phenomena.
Transhumanize: To make more than human; to purity; to elevate above humanity.
Try-square: An instrument used by carpenters, joiners, etc., for laying off right angles off right angles, and testing whether work is square.
Topsail: In a square-rigged vessel, the sail next above the lowermost sail on a mast. This sail is the one most frequently reefed or furled in working the ship. In a fore-and-aft rigged vessel, the sail set upon and above the gaff. See Cutter, Schooner, Sail, and Ship.
Teleseme: A system of apparatus for electric signals providing for automatic transmission of a definite number of different signals or calls, as in connection with hotel annunciators.
Totalizator: A machine for registering and indicating the number and nature of bets made on horse races. Called also totalizer.
Terebratulid: Any species of Terebratula or allied genera. Used also adjectively.
Tailzie: An entailment or deed whereby the legal course of succession is cut off, and an arbitrary one substituted.
Tungsten: A rare element of the chromium group found in certain minerals, as wolfram and scheelite, and isolated as a heavy steel-gray metal which is very hard and infusible. It has both acid and basic properties. When alloyed in small quantities with steel, it greatly increases its hardness. Symbol W (Wolframium). Atomic weight, 183.6. Specific gravity, 18.
Transverse: To change from prose into verse, or from verse into prose.
Talmudist: One versed in the Talmud; one who adheres to the teachings of the Talmud.
Tenotomy: The division of a tendon, or the act of dividing a tendon.
Trifurcate: Having three branches or forks; trichotomous.
Transpass: To pass by; to pass away.
Tenotome: A slender knife for use in the operation of tenotomy.
Taster: One who tastes; especially, one who first tastes food or drink to ascertain its quality.
Terrace: To form into a terrace or terraces; to furnish with a terrace or terraces, as, to terrace a garden, or a building.
Turnpike: To form, as a road, in the manner of a turnpike road; to throw into a rounded form, as the path of a road.
Tarre: To set on, as a dog; to incite.
Testamentary: Of or pertaining to a will, or testament; as, letters testamentary.
Tetraxile: Having four branches diverging at right angles; -- said of certain spicules of sponges.
throwaway: an advertisement (usually printed on a page or in a leaflet) intended for wide distribution.
Tridecane: A hydrocarbon, C13H28, of the methane series, which is a probable ingredient both of crude petroleum and of kerosene, and is produced artificially as a light colorless liquid.
Typolite: A stone or fossil which has on it impressions or figures of plants and animals.
Taxidermic: Of or pertaining to the art of preparing and preserving the skins of animals.
Torpify: To make torpid; to numb, or benumb.
Top-armor: A top railing supported by stanchions and equipped with netting.
Tryout: a test of the performance capability of a person, to ascertain fitness for a particular task; in sports, a test by which the fitness of a player or contestant to remain in a certain class is determined.
Transference: The act of transferring; conveyance; passage; transfer.
Trogon: Any one of numerous species of beautiful tropical birds belonging to the family Trogonidæ. They are noted for the brilliant colors and the resplendent luster of their plumage.
Trochanteric: Of or pertaining to one or both of the trochanters.
Tingle: To feel a kind of thrilling sensation, as in hearing a shrill sound.
Tramper: One who tramps; a stroller; a vagrant or vagabond; a tramp.
Tripod: Any utensil or vessel, as a stool, table, altar, caldron, etc., supported on three feet.
Tall: High in stature; having a considerable, or an unusual, extension upward; long and comparatively slender; having the diameter or lateral extent small in proportion to the height; as, a tall person, tree, or mast.
Tacky: An ill-conditioned, ill-fed, or neglected horse; also, a person in a like condition.
Territory: A large extent or tract of land; a region; a country; a district.
Trivial: One of the three liberal arts forming the trivium.
Thumb: To play with the thumb or thumbs; to play clumsily; to thrum.
Taotai: In China, an official at the head of the civil and military affairs of a circuit, which consists of two or more fu, or territorial departments; -- called also, by foreigners, intendant of circuit. Foreign consuls and commissioners associated with taotais as superintendants of trade at the treaty ports are ranked with the taotai.
Telethermometer: An apparatus for determining the temperature of a distant point, as by a thermoelectric circuit or otherwise.
Theory: A doctrine, or scheme of things, which terminates in speculation or contemplation, without a view to practice; hypothesis; speculation.
Thoroughfare: A passage through; a passage from one street or opening to another; an unobstructed way open to the public; a public road; hence, a frequented street.
Thrusting: The act of pushing with force.
Tachistoscope: An apparatus for exposing briefly to view a screen bearing letters or figures.  It is used in studying the range of attention, or the power of distinguishing separate objects in a single impression.
Teatish: Peevish; tettish; fretful; -- said of a child. See Tettish.
Tenementary: Capable of being leased; held by tenants.
Torpedinous: Of or pertaining to a torpedo; resembling a torpedo; exerting a benumbing influence; stupefying; dull; torpid.
Transprose: To change from prose into verse; to versify; also, to change from verse into prose.
Tempera: A mode or process of painting; distemper.
Terete: Cylindrical and slightly tapering; columnar, as some stems of plants.
Tripalmitate: A palmitate derived from three molecules of palmitic acid.
Tetroxide: An oxide having four atoms of oxygen in the molecule; a quadroxide; as, osmium tetroxide, OsO4.
Tivoli: A game resembling bagatelle, played on a special oblong board or table (Tivoli board or Tivoli table), which has a curved upper end, a set of numbered compartments at the lower end, side alleys, and the surface studded with pins and sometimes furnished with numbered depressions or cups.
Triseralous: Having three sepals, or calyx leaves.
Tuscan: A native or inhabitant of Tuscany.
Totemism: The system of distinguishing families, clans, etc., in a tribe by the totem.
Thlipsis: Compression, especially constriction of vessels by an external cause.
Trafficker: One who traffics, or carries on commerce; a trader; a merchant.
Thou: To use the words thou and thee in discourse after the manner of the Friends.
Telescopic: Of or pertaining to a telescope; performed by a telescope.
Twopence: A small coin, and money of account, in England, equivalent to two pennies, -- minted to a fixed annual amount, for almsgiving by the sovereign on Maundy Thursday.
Telephoto lens: a special compound camera lens with a long effective focal length but used in a camera with a short focal length, allowing large images to be obtained of distant objects when used in a camera in place of an ordinary lens; -- called also telephotographic lens.
Thor: The god of thunder, and son of Odin.
Trammel: To entangle, as in a net; to catch.
Truth: To assert as true; to declare.
Thornbird: A small South American bird (Anumbius anumbii) allied to the ovenbirds of the genus Furnarius). It builds a very large and complex nest of twigs and thorns in a bush or tree.
Turbogenerator: An electric generator or dynamo which is combined on one frame with a turbomotor, by which it is driven.
Totemist: One belonging to a clan or tribe having a totem.
Transvasate: To pour out of one vessel into another.
Tensibility: The quality or state of being tensible; tensility.
Tuko-tuko: A burrowing South American rodent (Ctenomys Braziliensis). It has small eyes and ears and a short tail. It resembles the pocket gopher in size, form, and habits, but is more nearly allied to the porcupines.
Tantalize: To tease or torment by presenting some good to the view and exciting desire, but continually frustrating the expectations by keeping that good out of reach; to tease; to torment.
Tesselar: Formed of tesseræ, as a mosaic.
Triplex: Having three principal operative parts or motions, so as to produce a three-fold effect.
Tramble: To wash, as tin ore, with a shovel in a frame fitted for the purpose.
Trunkwork: Work or devices suitable to be concealed; a secret stratagem.
Tampico fiber: A tough vegetable fiber used as a substitute for bristles in making brushes. The piassava and the ixtle are both used under this name.
Tracheoscopy: Examination of the interior of the trachea by means of a mirror.
Toothache: Pain in a tooth or in the teeth; odontalgia.
Tolsey: A tollbooth; also, a merchants' meeting place, or exchange.
Triandrian: Of or pertaining to the Triandria; having three distinct and equal stamens in the same flower.
Traffic mile: Any unit of the total obtained by adding the passenger miles and ton miles in a railroad's transportation for a given period; -- a term and practice of restricted or erroneous usage.
Temerity: Unreasonable contempt of danger; extreme venturesomeness; rashness; as, the temerity of a commander in war.
Tectibranchiate: Having the gills covered by the mantle; of or pertaining to the Tectibranchiata.
Turbulent: Disturbed; agitated; tumultuous; roused to violent commotion; as, the turbulent ocean.
Thermophilic: Heat-loving; -- applied especially to microorganisms such as certain bacteria, fungi and algae, which grow best at temperatures above 40° C (e.g. between 50° and 60°), and in some cases at temperatures that would kill ordinary microorganisms.  They are found in naturally hot locations, such as at hot springs or the thermal vents at the ocean bottom.
Teleostean: Of or pertaining to the teleosts.
Tobacconist: A dealer in tobacco; also, a manufacturer of tobacco.
Trigynia: A Linnæan order of plants having three pistils or styles.
Twank: To cause to make a sharp twanging sound; to twang, or twangle.
Tannery: A place where the work of tanning is carried on.
Thitsee: The varnish tree of Burmah (Melanorrhœa usitatissima).
Tegular: Of or pertaining to a tile; resembling a tile, or arranged like tiles; consisting of tiles; as, a tegular pavement.
Tumefaction: The act or process of tumefying, swelling, or rising into a tumor; a tumor; a swelling.
Tigh: A close, or inclosure; a croft.
Thi\u00ebnyl: The hypothetical radical C4H3S., regarded as the essential residue of thiophene and certain of its derivatives.
Transistor: a component used in electronic devices consisting of three regions of at least two types of a semiconducting material, such as doped silicon, connected to each other and to three electrodes in a conducting path so as to modify the current or voltage in an electronic circuit.
Taurid: Any of a group of meteors appearing November 20-23; -- so called because they appear to radiate from a point in Taurus.
Turpentine: A semifluid or fluid oleoresin, primarily the exudation of the terebinth, or turpentine, tree (Pistacia Terebinthus), a native of the Mediterranean region. It is also obtained from many coniferous trees, especially species of pine, larch, and fir.
Tulle: A kind of silk lace or light netting, used for veils, etc.
Toga: The loose outer garment worn by the ancient Romans, consisting of a single broad piece of woolen cloth of a shape approaching a semicircle. It was of undyed wool, except the border of the toga prætexta.
Troupial: Any one of numerous species of bright-colored American birds belonging to Icterus and allied genera, especially Icterus icterus, a native of the West Indies and South America. Many of the species are called orioles in America.
Tremolo: The rapid reiteration of tones without any apparent cessation, so as to produce a tremulous effect.
Tank warfare: combat between tanks of opposing armies.
Thitherward: To ward that place; in that direction.
torquated: Having or wearing a torque, or neck chain.
Tibio-: A combining form used in anatomy to indicate connection with, or relation to, the tibia; as, tibiotarsus, tibiofibular.
Turgid: Distended beyond the natural state by some internal agent or expansive force; swelled; swollen; bloated; inflated; tumid; -- especially applied to an enlarged part of the body; as, a turgid limb; turgid fruit.
Thy: Of thee, or belonging to thee; the more common form of thine, possessive case of thou; -- used always attributively, and chiefly in the solemn or grave style, and in poetry. Thine is used in the predicate; as, the knife is thine. See Thine.
Turning: The act of one who, or that which, turns; also, a winding; a bending course; a flexure; a meander.
Tarboosh: A red cap worn by Turks and other Eastern nations, sometimes alone and sometimes swathed with linen or other stuff to make a turban. See Fez.
Tutor: To have the guardianship or care of; to teach; to instruct.
Thigh: The proximal segment of the hind limb between the knee and the trunk. See Femur.
Trisulcate: Having three furrows, forks, or prongs; having three grooves or sulci; three-grooved.
Ticpolonga: A very venomous viper (Daboia Russellii), native of Ceylon and India; -- called also cobra monil.
Triamide: An amide containing three amido groups.
Thyine wood: The fragrant and beautiful wood of a North African tree (Callitris quadrivalvis), formerly called Thuja articulata. The tree is of the Cedar family, and furnishes a balsamic resin called sandarach.
Thick wind: A defect of respiration in a horse, that is unassociated with noise in breathing or with the signs of emphysema.
Traducible: Capable of being derived or propagated.
Tumbling: a. & vb. n. from Tumble, v.
Theopneusty: Divine inspiration; the supernatural influence of the Divine Spirit in qualifying men to receive and communicate revealed truth.
Trot: The pace of a horse or other quadruped, more rapid than a walk, but of various degrees of swiftness, in which one fore foot and the hind foot of the opposite side are lifted at the same time.
Tartronic: Of, pertaining to, or designating, an organic acid (called also hydroxy malonic acid) obtained, by reducing mesoxalic acid, as a white crystalline substance.
Towline: A line used to tow vessels; a towrope.
Tenability: The quality or state of being tenable; tenableness.
Tarsus: The ankle; the bones or cartilages of the part of the foot between the metatarsus and the leg, consisting in man of seven short bones.
Tartaric: Of or pertaining to tartar; derived from, or resembling, tartar.
Tetractinellid: Any species of sponge of the division Tetractinellida. Also used adjectively.
Tonsil: One of the two glandular organs situated in the throat at the sides of the fauces. The tonsils are sometimes called the almonds, from their shape.
Trews: Trowsers; especially, those of the Scotch Highlanders.
Tetterwort: A plant used as a remedy for tetter, -- in England the calendine, in America the bloodroot.
Testamur: A certificate of merit or proficiency; -- so called from the Latin words, Ita testamur, with which it commences.
Thermetograph: A self-registering thermometer, especially one that registers the maximum and minimum during long periods.
Trumpets: A plant (Sarracenia flava) with long, hollow leaves.
Tungstite: The oxide of tungsten, a yellow mineral occurring in a pulverulent form. It is often associated with wolfram.
Trickery: The art of dressing up; artifice; stratagem; fraud; imposture.
Tridactyl: Having three fingers or toes, or composed of three movable parts attached to a common base.
Trave: A crossbeam; a lay of joists.
thaumaturgus: A miracle worker; -- a title given by the Roman Catholics to some saints.
Threpsology: The doctrine of nutrition; a treatise on nutrition.
Tenement: That which is held of another by service; property which one holds of a lord or proprietor in consideration of some military or pecuniary service; fief; fee.
Tectrices: The wing coverts of a bird. See Covert, and Illust. of Bird.
Thoth: The god of eloquence and letters among the ancient Egyptians, and supposed to be the inventor of writing and philosophy. He corresponded to the Mercury of the Romans, and was usually represented as a human figure with the head of an ibis or a lamb.
Thorough-brace: A leather strap supporting the body of a carriage, and attached to springs, or serving as a spring. See Illust. of Chaise.
Thalassography: The study or science of the life of marine organisms.
Temperament: Internal constitution; state with respect to the relative proportion of different qualities, or constituent parts.
Tokay: A grape of an oval shape and whitish color.
Tungsten steel: A steel containing a small amount of tungsten, noted for tenacity and hardness, even under a considerable degree of heat.  Magnets made of it are said to be highly permanent.  It often contains manganese.
Trichiuriform: Like or pertaining to the genus Trichiurus or family Trichiuridæ, comprising the scabbard fishes and hairtails.
tortoise-shell: Having a color like that of a tortoise's shell, black with white and orange spots; --  used mostly to describe cats of that color.
Torteau: A roundel of a red color.
Topstone: A stone that is placed on the top, or which forms the top.
Thermotropism: The phenomenon of turning towards a source of warmth, seen in the growing parts of some plants.
Teleosaurus: A genus of extinct crocodilian reptiles of the Jurassic period, having a long and slender snout.
Trisyllable: A word consisting of three syllables only; as, a-ven-ger.
Tag day: A day on which contributions to some public or private charity or fund are solicited promiscuously on the street, and tags given to contributors to wear as an evidence of their having contributed. Such solicitation is now subject to legal restriction in various places.
Transfusive: Tending to transfuse; having power to transfuse.
Tommy: Bread, -- generally a penny roll; the supply of food carried by workmen as their daily allowance.
-type: A combining form signifying impressed form; stamp; print; type; typical form; representative; as in stereotype phototype, ferrotype, monotype.
Toat: The handle of a joiner's plane.
Timbale: A seasoned preparation, as of chicken, lobster, cheese, or fish, cooked in a drum-shaped mold; also, a pastry case, usually small, filled with a cooked mixture.
Telemetrograph: A combination of the camera lucida and telescope for drawing and measuring distant objects.
Taha: The African rufous-necked weaver bird (Hyphantornis texor).
Tatusiid: Any armadillo of the family Tatusiidæ, of which the peba and mule armadillo are examples. Also used adjectively.
Tourney: To perform in tournaments; to tilt.
Tripinnatifid: Thrice pinnately cleft; -- said of a pinnatifid leaf when its segments are pinnatifid, and the subdivisions of these also are pinnatifid.
Thecodactyl: Any one of a group of lizards of the Gecko tribe, having the toes broad, and furnished with a groove in which the claws can be concealed.
Tooter: One who toots; one who plays upon a pipe or horn.
Turndown: An act of refusing or of being refused; as, to get a turndown in an application for a job, a grant, etc.
Triplicity: The quality or state of being triple, or threefold; trebleness.
Trophic: Of or connected with nutrition; nitritional; nourishing; as, the so-called trophic nerves, which have a direct influence on nutrition.
Trierarchy: The office duty of a trierarch.
Trolley wire: A heavy conducting wire on which the trolley car runs and from which it receives the current.
Tonsilar: Of or pertaining to the tonsils; tonsilitic.
Tri\u0153cious: Having three sorts of flowers on the same or on different plants, some of the flowers being staminate, others pistillate, and others both staminate and pistillate; belonging to the order Triœcia.
Those: The plural of that. See That.
Tissued: Clothed in, or adorned with, tissue; also, variegated; as, tissued flowers.
Tragopan: Any one of several species of Asiatic pheasants of the genus Ceriornis. They are brilliantly colored with a variety of tints, the back and breast are usually covered with white or buff ocelli, and the head is ornamented with two bright-colored, fleshy wattles. The crimson tragopan, or horned pheasant (Ceriornis satyra), of India is one of the best-known species.
Torrefaction: The act or process of torrefying, or the state of being torrefied.
Temporariness: The quality or state of being temporary; -- opposed to perpetuity.
Tarpeian: Pertaining to or designating a rock or peak of the Capitoline hill, Rome, from which condemned criminals were hurled.
Threnetic: Pertaining to a threne; sorrowful; mournful.
Twine: To mutually twist together; to become mutually involved.
Tath: To manure (land) by pasturing cattle on it, or causing them to lie upon it.
Tram: To operate, or conduct the business of, a tramway; to travel by tramway.
Trollop: A stroller; a loiterer; esp., an idle, untidy woman; a slattern; a slut; a whore.
Terminal: That which terminates or ends; termination; extremity.
To: The preposition to primarily indicates approach and arrival, motion made in the direction of a place or thing and attaining it, access; and also, motion or tendency without arrival; movement toward; -- opposed to from.
Torsion head: That part of a torsion balance from  which the wire or filament is suspended.
Twiner: Any plant which twines about a support.
Th: In Old English, the article the, when the following word began with a vowel, was often written with elision as if a part of the word. Thus in Chaucer, the forms thabsence, tharray, thegle, thend, thingot, etc., are found for the absence, the array, the eagle, the end, etc.
Tatt: To make (anything) by tatting; to work at tatting; as, tatted edging.
Tyrotoxicon: A ptomaine discovered by Vaughan in putrid cheese and other dairy products, and producing symptoms similar to cholera infantum. Chemically, it appears to be related to, or identical with, diazobenzol.
Tonka bean: The seed of a leguminous tree (Dipteryx odorata), native of Guiana. It has a peculiarly agreeable smell, and is employed in the scenting of snuff. Called also tonquin bean.
Tracheal: Of or pertaining to the trachea; like a trachea.
Transpare: To be, or cause to be, transparent; to appear, or cause to appear, or be seen, through something.
Tighten: To draw tighter; to straiten; to make more close in any manner.
Transpirable: Capable of being transpired, or of transpiring.
