Thunderbolt: A shaft of lightning; a brilliant stream of electricity passing from one part of the heavens to another, or from the clouds to the earth.
Tachyscope: An early form of animated-picture machine, devised in 1889 by Otto Anschütz of Berlin, in which the chronophotographs were mounted upon the periphery of a rotating wheel.
Testes: pl. of Teste, or of Testis.
Tester: An old French silver coin, originally of the value of about eighteen pence, subsequently reduced to ninepence, and later to sixpence, sterling. Hence, in modern English slang, a sixpence; -- often contracted to tizzy. Called also teston.
Tepidity: The quality or state of being tepid; moderate warmth; lukewarmness; tepidness.
Tottle: To walk in a wavering, unsteady manner; to toddle; to topple.
Trudge: To walk or march with labor; to jog along; to move wearily.
Tubuliform: Having the form of a small tube.
Thermoscopic: Of or pertaining to the thermoscope; made by means of the thermoscope; as, thermoscopic observations.
Trimera: A division of Coleoptera including those which have but three joints in the tarsi.
Triangulation: The series or network of triangles into which the face of a country, or any portion of it, is divided in a trigonometrical survey; the operation of measuring the elements necessary to determine the triangles into which the country to be surveyed is supposed to be divided, and thus to fix the positions and distances of the several points connected by them.
Tentacular: Of or pertaining to a tentacle or tentacles.
Tiller: A lever of wood or metal fitted to the rudder head and used for turning side to side in steering. In small boats hand power is used; in large vessels, the tiller is moved by means of mechanical appliances. See Illust. of Rudder.  Cf. 2d Helm, 1.
Taking-off: Removal; murder. See To take off (c), under Take, v. t.
Tansy: Any plant of the composite genus Tanacetum. The common tansy (Tanacetum vulgare) has finely divided leaves, a strong aromatic odor, and a very bitter taste. It is used for medicinal and culinary purposes.
Teach: To give instruction; to follow the business, or to perform the duties, of a preceptor.
Trouble: The state of being troubled; disturbance; agitation; uneasiness; vexation; calamity.
Tracheophon\u00e6: A group of passerine birds having the syrinx at the lower end of the trachea.
Tighter: A ribbon or string used to draw clothes closer.
Tuggingly: In a tugging manner; with laborious pulling.
Tinct: To color or stain; to imblue; to tint.
Tussocky: Having the form of tussocks; full of, or covered with, tussocks, or tufts.
Textrine: Of or pertaining to weaving, textorial; as, the textrine art.
Throw back: to revert to an ancestral type or character.
Tendinous: Pertaining to a tendon; of the nature of tendon.
Trades-unionist: A member of a trades union, or a supporter of trades unions.
Thought: The act of thinking; the exercise of the mind in any of its higher forms; reflection; cogitation.
Tringa: A genus of limicoline birds including many species of sandpipers. See Dunlin, Knot, and Sandpiper.
Trimming: The act of one who trims.
Transvert: To cause to turn across; to transverse.
Torpedo shell: A shell longer than a deck-piercing shell, with thinner walls and a larger cavity for the bursting charge, which consists of about 130 pounds of high explosive. It has no soft cap, and is intended to effect its damage by the powerful explosion which follows on slight resistance. It is used chiefly in 12-inch mortars.
Trellis: A structure or frame of crossbarred work, or latticework, used for various purposes, as for screens or for supporting plants.
Trigeminal: Of, pertaining to, or designating, the fifth pair of cranial nerves, which divide on each side of the head into three main branches distributed to the orbits, jaws, and parts of the mouth; trifacial.
Tedge: The gate of a mold, through which the melted metal is poured; runner, geat.
Thorntail: A beautiful South American humming bird (Gouldia Popelairii), having the six outer tail feathers long, slender, and pointed. The head is ornamented with a long, pointed crest.
Trimethylamine: A colorless volatile alkaline liquid, N.(CH3)3, obtained from herring brine, beet roots, etc., with a characteristic herringlike odor. It is regarded as a substituted ammonia containing three methyl groups.
Townish: Of or pertaining to the inhabitants of a town; like the town.
Tailstock: The sliding block or support, in a lathe, which carries the dead spindle, or adjustable center. The headstock supports the live spindle.
Temperer: One who, or that which, tempers; specifically, a machine in which lime, cement, stone, etc., are mixed with water.
Threnodist: One who composes, delivers, or utters, a threnode, or threnody.
Tufa: A soft or porous stone formed by depositions from water, usually calcareous; -- called also calcareous tufa.
Testicardines: A division of brachiopods including those which have a calcareous shell furnished with a hinge and hinge teeth. Terebratula and Spirifer are examples.
Thallous: Of or pertaining to thallium; derived from, or containing, thallium; specifically, designating those compounds in which the element has a lower valence as contrasted with the thallic compounds.
Trickle: The act or state of trickling; also, that which trickles; a small stream; drip.
Tempered: Brought to a proper temper; as, tempered steel; having (such) a temper; -- chiefly used in composition; as, a good-tempered or bad-tempered man; a well-tempered sword.
Tapestry: To adorn with tapestry, or as with tapestry.
Twinner: One who gives birth to twins; a breeder of twins.
Two-hand: Employing two hands; as, the two-hand alphabet. See Dactylology.
Trijugate: In three pairs; as, a trijugate leaf, or a pinnate leaf with three pairs of leaflets.
Top rake: The angle that the front edge of the point of a tool is set back from the normal to the surface being cut.
Tintinnabular: Having or making the sound of a bell; tinkling.
Trippingly: In a tripping manner; with a light, nimble, quick step; with agility; nimbly.
Torsion: The act of turning or twisting, or the state of being twisted; the twisting or wrenching of a body by the exertion of a lateral force tending to turn one end or part of it about a longitudinal axis, while the other is held fast or turned in the opposite direction.
Tritozooid: A zooid of the third generation in asexual reproduction.
Toadstone: A local name for the igneous rocks of Derbyshire, England; -- said by some to be derived from the German todter stein, meaning dead stone, that is, stone which contains no ores.
Tetanomotor: An instrument from tetanizing a muscle by irritating its nerve by successive mechanical shocks.
Trough: A long, hollow vessel, generally for holding water or other liquid, especially one formed by excavating a log longitudinally on one side; a long tray; also, a wooden channel for conveying water, as to a mill wheel.
Tactility: The quality or state of being tactile; perceptibility by touch; tangibleness.
Tellurous: Of or pertaining to tellurium; derived from, or containing, tellurium; specifically, designating those compounds in which the element has a lower valence as contrasted with telluric compounds; as, tellurous acid, which is analogous to sulphurous acid.
Turpentine State: North Carolina; -- a nickname alluding to its extensive production of turpentine.
Trainman: a member of the crew of a railroad train, often an assistant to a conductor.
Tewtaw: To beat; to break, as flax or hemp.
Thoughtless: Lacking thought; careless; inconsiderate; rash; as, a thoughtless person, or act.
Thermobarometer: An instrument for determining altitudes by the boiling point of water.
Telephone exchange: A central office in which the  wires of telephones from local subscribers may be connected by switches to other local telephones or to long-distance lines, to permit transmission of conversation or data.
Teetotaler: One pledged to entire abstinence from all intoxicating drinks.
Tachymetry: The science or use of the tachymeter.
Transfiguratien: A change of form or appearance; especially, the supernatural change in the personal appearance of our Savior on the mount.
Turbot: A large European flounder (Rhombus maximus) highly esteemed as a food fish. It often weighs from thirty to forty pounds.  Its color on the upper side is brownish with small roundish tubercles scattered over the surface.  The lower, or blind, side is white.  Called also bannock fluke.
Tipper: A kind of ale brewed with brackish water obtained from a particular well; -- so called from the first brewer of it, one Thomas Tipper.
Tippet: A cape, or scarflike garment for covering the neck, or the neck and shoulders, -- usually made of fur, cloth, or other warm material.
Tangelo: A hybrid between the tangerine orange and the grapefruit, or pomelo; also, the fruit.
Transitional: Of or pertaining to transition; involving or denoting transition; as, transitional changes; transitional stage.
Tiaraed: Adorned with, or wearing, a tiara.
Throatboll: The Adam's apple in the neck.
Turtleback: A rude stone celt of a form suggesting the back of a turtle.
Titillative: Tending or serving to titillate, or tickle; tickling.
Tenderly: In a tender manner; with tenderness; mildly; gently; softly; in a manner not to injure or give pain; with pity or affection; kindly.
Telephotography: The photography of distant objects in more enlarged form than is possible by the ordinary means, usually by a camera provided with a telephoto lens or mounted in place of the eyepiece of a telescope, so that the real or a magnified image falls on the sensitive plate.
Tripper: One who trips or supplants; also, one who walks or trips nimbly; a dancer.
Try out: to use (something not previously used) to determine its fitness for a particular purpose; also, to attempt (a deed) to determine if it will accomplish a particular purpose.
Taxability: The quality or state of being taxable; taxableness.
Tricurvate: Curved in three directions; as, a tricurvate spicule (see Illust. of Spicule).
Tetraschistic: Characterized by division into four parts.
Tripolitan: Of or pertaining to Tripoli or its inhabitants; Tripoline.
Tool-post: The part of a tool-rest in which a cutting tool is clamped.
Turret steamer: A whaleback steamer with a hatch coaming, usually about seven feet high, extending almost continuously fore and aft.
torture: To put to torture; to pain extremely; to harass; to vex.
Trituration: The act of triturating, or reducing to a fine or impalpable powder by grinding, rubbing, bruising, etc.
Tungsten lamp: An electric glow lamp having filaments of metallic tungsten, and contained in a glass bulb which is evacuated or has an inert gas, to avoid oxidation of the tungsten; a common form of light bulb. Such lamps, owing to the refractory nature of the metal, may be maintained at a very high temperature and require an expenditure of only about 1.25 watts per candle power, depending on the total wattage and the design of the bulb.  By mid-20th century tungsten lamps became the most common type of incandescent (as contrasted with fluorescent) lamp; thus the phrase incandescent lamp or incandescent light typically refers to a tungsten lamp.
Tibiotarsal: Of or pertaining to both to the tibia and the tarsus; as, the tibiotarsal articulation.
Topaz: A mineral occurring in rhombic prisms, generally yellowish and pellucid, also colorless, and of greenesh, bluish, or brownish shades. It sometimes occurs massive and opaque. It is a fluosilicate of alumina, and is used as a gem.
Terrane: A region or limited area considered with reference to some special feature; as, the terrane of a river, that is, its drainage basin.
Tuner: One who tunes; especially, one whose occupation is to tune musical instruments.
Turcism: A mode of speech peculiar to the Turks; a Turkish idiom or expression; also, in general, a Turkish mode or custom.  Same as Turkism.
Trilobitic: Of, pertaining to or containing, trilobites; as, trilobitic rocks.
Taboo: Set apart or sacred by religious custom among certain races of Polynesia, New Zealand, etc., and forbidden to certain persons or uses; hence, prohibited under severe penalties; interdicted; as, food, places, words, customs, etc., may be taboo.
Titrated: Standardized; determined or analyzed by titration; as, titrated solutions.
Thermolysis: The resolution of a compound into parts by heat; dissociation by heat.
Thunderer: One who thunders; -- used especially as a translation of L. tonans, an epithet applied by the Romans to several of their gods, esp. to Jupiter.
Toponomy: The designation of position and direction.
Tufted: Adorned with a tuft; as, the tufted duck.
Thuringite: A mineral occurring as an aggregation of minute scales having an olive-green color and pearly luster. It is a hydrous silicate of aluminia and iron.
T\u00e6niata: A division of Ctenophora including those which have a long, ribbonlike body. The Venus's girdle is the most familiar example.
Thiophthene: A double thiophene nucleus, C6H4S2, analogous to thionaphthene, and the base of a large series of compounds.
Translative: tropical; figurative; as, a translative sense.
Tiewig: A wig having a tie or ties, or one having some of the curls tied up; also, a wig tied upon the head.
Three-coat: Having or consisting of three coats; -- applied to plastering which consists of pricking-up, floating, and a finishing coat; or, as called in the United States, a scratch coat, browning, and finishing coat.
Tailboard: The board at the rear end of a cart or wagon, which can be removed or let down, for convenience in loading or unloading.
Tabular: Having the form of, or pertaining to, a table (in any of the uses of the word).
Tag sale: A sale of usually used items (such as furniture, clothing, household items or bric-a-brac), conducted by one or a small group of individuals, at a location which is not a normal retail establishment.
Train dispatcher: An official who gives the orders on a railroad as to the running of trains and their right of way.
Two-to-one: Designating, or pert. to, a gear for reducing or increasing a velocity ratio two to one.
Triclinium: A couch for reclining at meals, extending round three sides of a table, and usually in three parts.
Thermolysin: a proteolytic enzyme obtained from the bacterium Bacillus thermoproteolyticus, which hydrolyses the N-terminal amide bonds of hydrophobic amino acid residues in proteins.  It is used in studies of protein structure.  It has a molecular weight of about 37,500 and contains zinc and calcium in its active configuration.
Tockay: A spotted lizard native of India.
Tedious: Involving tedium; tiresome from continuance, prolixity, slowness, or the like; wearisome.
Tunguses: A group of roving Turanian tribes occupying Eastern Siberia and the Amur valley. They resemble the Mongols.
Tappen: An obstruction, or indigestible mass, found in the intestine of bears and other animals during hibernation.
Time-table: A tabular statement of the time at which, or within which, several things are to take place, as the recitations in a school, the departure and arrival of railroad trains or other public conveyances, the rise and fall of the tides, etc.
Termes: A genus of Pseudoneuroptera including the white ants, or termites. See Termite.
Termer: One who resorted to London during the law term only, in order to practice tricks, to carry on intrigues, or the like.
Thesmothete: A lawgiver; a legislator; one of the six junior archons at Athens.
Teaspoon: A small spoon used in stirring and sipping tea, coffee, etc., and for other purposes.
Two-step: A kind of round dance in march or polka time; also, a piece of music for this dance.
Teaching: The act or business of instructing; also, that which is taught; instruction.
Tittle: A particle; a minute part; a jot; an iota.
Tricennarious: Of or pertaining to thirty years; tricennial.
Transformation: The act of transforming, or the state of being transformed; change of form or condition.
Tyrannize: To subject to arbitrary, oppressive, or tyrannical treatment; to oppress.
Tautomerism: The condition, quality, or relation of metameric substances, or their respective derivatives, which are more or less interchangeable, according as one form or the other is the more stable. It is a special case of metamerism; thus, the lactam and the lactim compounds exhibit tautomerism.
Tittle-tattling: The act or habit of parting idly or gossiping.
Task wage: A wage paid by the day, or some fixed period, on condition that a minimum task be performed. When the workman is paid in proportion for excess over the minimum, the wage is one for piece-work.
Telegrapher: One who sends telegraphic messages; a telegraphic operator; a telegraphist.
Tumbledung: Any one of numerous species of scaraboid beetles belonging to Scarabæus, Copris, Phanæus, and allied genera. The female lays her eggs in a globular mass of dung which she rolls by means of her hind legs to a burrow excavated in the earth in which she buries it.
Triangular: Having three angles; having the form of a triangle.
Triethylamine: A tertiary amine analogous to trimethylamine.
Towardness: Quality or state of being toward.
Torsion meter: An instrument for determining the torque on a shaft, and hence the horse power of an engine, esp. of a marine engine of high power, by measuring the amount of twist of a given length of the shaft. Called also torsimeter, torsiometer, torsometer.
Transpeciate: To change from one species to another; to transform.
Tubiform: Having the form of a tube; tubeform.
Turbellarian: One of the Turbellaria. Also used adjectively.
Tysonite: A fluoride of the cerium metals occurring in hexagonal crystals of a pale yellow color.   Cf. Fluocerite.
Throttle: To have the throat obstructed so as to be in danger of suffocation; to choke; to suffocate.
Twiddle: A slight twist with the fingers.
Tindal: A petty officer among lascars, or native East Indian sailors; a boatswain's mate; a cockswain.
Tangency: The quality or state of being tangent; a contact or touching.
Trepan: To insnare; to trap; to trapan.
Typography: The act or art of expressing by means of types or symbols; emblematical or hieroglyphic representation.
Telelectroscope: Any apparatus for making distant objects visible by the aid of electric transmission.
Talebearing: The act of informing officiously; communication of sectrts, scandal, etc., maliciously.
Tangent spoke: A tension spoke of a bicycle or similar wheel, secured tangentially to the hub.
Teinoscope: An instrument formed by combining prisms so as to correct the chromatic aberration of the light while linear dimensions of objects seen through the prisms are increased or diminished; -- called also prism telescope.
Traveler: One who travels; one who has traveled much.
Trivalent: Having a valence of three; capable of being combined with, substituted for, or compared with, three atoms of hydrogen; -- said of triad atoms or radicals; thus, nitrogen is trivalent in ammonia.
Tankage: The act or process of putting or storing in tanks.
Triforium: The gallery or open space between the vaulting and the roof of the aisles of a church, often forming a rich arcade in the interior of the church, above the nave arches and below the clearstory windows.
Targumist: The writer of a Targum; one versed in the Targums.
Trench: A long, narrow cut in the earth; a ditch; as, a trench for draining land.
Teeing ground: The space from within which the ball must be struck in beginning the play for each hole.
Throughout: In every part; as, the cloth was of a piece throughout.
Thereby: By that; by that means; in consequence of that.
Tornaria: The peculiar free swimming larva of Balanoglossus. See Illust. in Append.
Tequila: An intoxicating liquor made from the maguey in the district of Tequila, Mexico.
titanic: Of or pertaining to titanium; derived from, or containing, titanium; specifically, designating those compounds of titanium in which it has a higher valence as contrasted with the titanous compounds.
Tripetalous: Having three petals, or flower leaves; three-petaled.
Trente et quarante: Same as Rouge et noir, under Rouge.
Thermifugine: An artificial alkaloid of complex composition, resembling thalline and used as an antipyretic, -- whence its name.
Tactual: Of or pertaining to the sense, or the organs, of touch; derived from touch.
Toff: A fop; a beau; a swell.
Thermoluminescence: Luminescence exhibited by a substance on being moderately heated. It is shown esp. by certain substances that have been exposed to the action of light or to X-rays.
Torpedo station: A headquarters for torpedo vessels and their supplies, usually having facilities for repairs and for instruction and experiments. The principal torpedo station of the United States is at Newport, R.I.
Thallogen: One of a large class or division of the vegetable kingdom, which includes those flowerless plants, such as fungi, algæ, and lichens, that consist of a thallus only, composed of cellular tissue, or of a congeries of cells, or even of separate cells, and never show a distinction into root, stem, and leaf.
Troll: The act of moving round; routine; repetition.
Turncoat: One who forsakes his party or his principles; a renegade; an apostate; a defector to the enemy.
Tread: A step or stepping; pressure with the foot; a footstep; as, a nimble tread; a cautious tread.
Tantalizingly: In a tantalizing or teasing manner.
Tithing: The act of levying or taking tithes; that which is taken as tithe; a tithe.
Tringoid: Of or pertaining to Tringa, or the Sandpiper family.
Truffled: Provided or cooked with truffles; stuffed with truffles; as, a truffled turkey.
Tagliacotain: Of or pertaining to Tagliacozzi, a Venetian surgeon; as, the Tagliacotian operation, a method of rhinoplasty described by him.
Trispermous: Containing three seeds; three-seeded; as, a trispermous capsule.
Theriac: Of or pertaining to theriac; medicinal.
Torsibillty: The tendency, as of a rope, to untwist after being twisted.
Terpinol: Any oil substance having a hyacinthine odor, obtained by the action of acids on terpin, and regarded as a related hydrate.
Tithonic: Of, pertaining to, or denoting, those rays of light which produce chemical effects; actinic.
Trudgen stroke: A racing stroke in which a double over-arm motion is used; -- so called from its use by an amateur named Trudgen, but often erroneously written trudgeon.
Transliteration: The act or product of transliterating, or of expressing words of a language by means of the characters of another alphabet.
Taj Mahal: A marble mausoleum built at Agra, India, by the Mogul Emperor Shah Jahan, in memory of his favorite wife.  In beauty of design and rich decorative detail it is one of the best examples of Saracenic architecture, and specifically of Mogul architecture.
Tophus: One of the mineral concretions about the joints, and in other situations, occurring chiefly in gouty persons. They consist usually of urate of sodium; when occurring in the internal organs they are also composed of phosphate of calcium.
Tautozonal: Belonging to the same zone; as, tautozonal planes.
Tosspot: A toper; one habitually given to strong drink; a drunkard.
Theodolite: An instrument used, especially in trigonometrical surveying, for the accurate measurement of horizontal angles, and also usually of vertical angles. It is variously constructed.
Taxable: Capable of being taxed; liable by law to the assessment of taxes; as, taxable estate; taxable commodities.
Traffic: Commerce, either by barter or by buying and selling; interchange of goods and commodities; trade.
Toluene: A hydrocarbon, C6H5.CH3, of the aromatic series, homologous with benzene, and obtained as a light mobile colorless liquid, by distilling tolu balsam, coal tar, etc.; -- called also methyl benzene, phenyl methane, etc.
T\u00e6niosomi: An order of fishes remarkable for their long and compressed form. The ribbon fishes are examples. See Ribbon fish, under Ribbon.
Thankworthiness: The quality or state of being thankworthy.
Tripery: A place where tripe is prepared or sold.
Tribe: To distribute into tribes or classes.
Tetramorph: The union of the four attributes of the Evangelists in one figure, which is represented as winged, and standing on winged fiery wheels, the wings being covered with eyes. The representations of it are evidently suggested by the vision of Ezekiel (ch. i.)
Top-cloth: A piece of canvas used to cover the hammocks which are lashed to the top in action to protect the topmen.
Transplantation: The act of transplanting, or the state of being transplanted; also, removal.
Tarpum: A very large marine fish (Megapolis Atlanticus) of the Southern United States and the West Indies. It often becomes six or more feet in length, and has large silvery scales. The scales are a staple article of trade, and are used in fancywork. Called also tarpon, sabalo, savanilla, silverfish, and jewfish.
Tailpin: The center in the spindle of a turning lathe.
Tourbillion: An ornamental firework which turns round, when in the air, so as to form a scroll of fire.
Tremor: A trembling; a shivering or shaking; a quivering or vibratory motion; as, the tremor of a person who is weak, infirm, or old.
Ternate: Having the parts arranged by threes; as, ternate branches, leaves, or flowers.
Theanthropist: One who advocates, or believes in, theanthropism.
Tapayaxin: A Mexican spinous lizard (Phrynosoma orbiculare) having a head somewhat like that of a toad; -- called also horned toad.
Ten-strike: A knocking down of all ten pins at one delivery of the ball.
Timbreled: Sung to the sound of the timbrel.
Therein: In that or this place, time, or thing; in that particular or respect.
Triality: Three united; state of being three.
Thermotank: A tank containing pipes through which circulates steam, water, air, or the like, for heating or cooling; -- used in some heating and ventilation systems.
Tartrazine: An artificial dyestuff obtained as an orange-yellow powder, and regarded as a phenyl hydrazine derivative of tartaric and sulphonic acids.
Tartarize: To cause to resemble the Tartars and their civilization, as by conquest.
Trinomial: Consisting of three terms; of or pertaining to trinomials; as, a trinomial root.
Traveled: Having made journeys; having gained knowledge or experience by traveling; hence, knowing; experienced.
Thurrok: The hold of a ship; a sink.
Trooper: A soldier in a body of cavalry; a cavalryman; also, the horse of a cavalryman.
Torment: To put to extreme pain or anguish; to inflict excruciating misery upon, either of body or mind; to torture.
Tetradynamia: A Linnæan class of plants having six stamens, four of which are longer than the others.
Tetrazo-: A combining form (also used adjectively), designating any one of a series of double derivatives of the azo and diazo compounds containing four atoms of nitrogen.
Tift: A fit of pettishness, or slight anger; a tiff.
Transit: To pass over the disk of (a heavenly body).
Territorialize: To enlarge by extension of territory.
Tricky: Given to tricks; practicing deception; trickish; knavish.
Tubercular: Having tubercles; affected with tubercles; tubercled; tuberculate.
Toyhouse: A house for children to play in or to play with; a playhouse.
Tartramic: Of, pertaining to, or designating, an acid which is the primary acid amide derivative of tartaric acid.
Tetrazine: A hypothetical compound, C2H2N4 which  may be regarded as benzene with four CH groups replaced by nitrogen atoms; also, any of various derivatives of the same. There are three isomeric varieties.
Tusk: To bare or gnash the teeth.
Trieterics: Festival games celebrated once in three years.
Thelytokous: Producing females only; -- said of certain female insects.
Traction: The act of drawing, or the state of being drawn; as, the traction of a muscle.
Testamental: Of or pertaining to a testament; testamentary.
Totality: The quality or state of being total; as, the totality of an eclipse.
Tarquinish: Like a Tarquin, a king of ancient Rome; proud; haughty; overbearing.
Toxodon: A gigantic extinct herbivorous mammal from South America, having teeth bent like a bow. It is the type of the order Toxodonta.
Trochiscus: A kind of tablet or lozenge; a troche.
Tigella: That part of an embryo which represents the young stem; the caulicle or radicle.
Tatter: To rend or tear into rags; -- used chiefly in the past participle as an adjective.
Tropical: Of or pertaining to the tropics; characteristic of, or incident to, the tropics; being within the tropics; as, tropical climate; tropical latitudes; tropical heat; tropical diseases.
Travois: A primitive vehicle, common among the North American Indians, usually two trailing poles serving as shafts and bearing a platform or net for a load.
Transfrete: To pass over a strait or narrow sea.
Taplash: Bad small beer; also, the refuse or dregs of liquor.
Tenuirostral: Thin-billed; -- applied to birds with a slender bill, as the humming birds.
Tocsin: An alarm bell, or the ringing of a bell for the purpose of alarm.
Thermometry: The estimation of temperature by the use of a thermometric apparatus.
Tetrabranchiata: An order of Cephalopoda having four gills. Among living species it includes only the pearly nautilus. Numerous genera and species are found in the fossil state, such as Ammonites, Baculites, Orthoceras, etc.
Towilly: The sanderling; -- so called from its cry.
Thread-shaped: Having the form of a thread; filiform.
Telegraphoscope: An instrument for telegraphically transmitting a picture and reproducing its image as a positive or negative.  The transmitter includes a camera obscura and a row of minute selenium cells.  The receiver includes an oscillograph, relay, equilibrator, and an induction coil the sparks from which perforate a paper with tiny holes that form the image.  It is now (1999) obsolete, having been replaced by telefax and internet transmission of images.
Taen: p. p. of Ta, to take, or a contraction of Taken.
Tael: A denomination of money, in China, worth nearly six shillings sterling, or about a dollar and forty cents; also, a weight of one ounce and a third.
Tetrazone: Any one of a certain series of basic compounds containing a chain of four nitrogen atoms; for example, ethyl tetrazone, (C2H5)2N.N2.N(C2H5)2, a colorless liquid having an odor of leeks.
Treenail: A long wooden pin used in fastening the planks of a vessel to the timbers or to each other.
Tsung tu: A viceroy or governor-general, the highest provincial official in China, with civil and military authority over one or more provinces.
Transshape: To change into another shape or form; to transform.
Technical: Of or pertaining to the useful or mechanic arts, or to any science, business, or the like; specially appropriate to any art, science, or business; as, the words of an indictment must be technical.
Tantalus: A Phrygian king who was punished in the lower world by being placed in the midst of a lake whose waters reached to his chin but receded whenever he attempted to allay his thirst, while over his head hung branches laden with choice fruit which likewise receded whenever he stretched out his hand to grasp them.
Tetrodont: Of or pertaining to the tetrodons.
Teazer: The stoker or fireman of a furnace, as in glass works.
Theurgist: One who pretends to, or is addicted to, theurgy.
Thin-skinned: Having a thin skin; hence, sensitive; irritable.
Throwing stick: An instrument  used by various savage races for throwing a spear; -- called also throw stick and spear thrower.  One end of the stick receives the butt of the spear, as upon a hook or thong, and the other end is grasped with the hand, which also holds the spear, toward the middle, above it with the finger and thumb, the effect being to bring the place of support nearer the center of the spear, and practically lengthen the arm in the act of throwing.  In Mexico, one such device is called the atlatl.
Tetrapod: An insect characterized by having but four perfect legs, as certain of the butterflies.
Turtler: One who catches turtles or tortoises.
Turban-top: A kind of fungus with an irregularly wrinkled, somewhat globular pileus (Helvella esculenta syn. Gyromitra esculenta.).
Tapish: To lie close to the ground, so as to be concealed; to squat; to crouch; hence, to hide one's self.
Totemic: Of or pertaining to a totem, or totemism.
Tattling: Given to idle talk; apt to tell tales.
Tinselly: In a showy and cheap manner.
Tumultuary: Attended by, or producing, a tumult; disorderly; promiscuous; confused; tumultuous.
Thiller: The horse which goes between the thills, or shafts, and supports them; also, the last horse in a team; -- called also thill horse.
Tightness: The quality or condition of being tight.
Tricliniary: Of or pertaining to a triclinium, or to the ancient mode of reclining at table.
Transgressive: Disposed or tending to transgress; faulty; culpable. -
Tenet: Any opinion, principle, dogma, belief, or doctrine, which a person holds or maintains as true; as, the tenets of Plato or of Cicero.
Traitor: To act the traitor toward; to betray; to deceive.
Trivet: A tree-legged stool, table, or other support; especially, a stand to hold a kettle or similar vessel near the fire; a tripod.
Trusion: The act of pushing or thrusting.
Toothpick: A pointed instrument for clearing the teeth of substances lodged between them.
Technically: In a technical manner; according to the signification of terms as used in any art, business, or profession.
Thirtieth: The quotient of a unit divided by thirty; one of thirty equal parts.
Track: To follow the tracks or traces of; to pursue by following the marks of the feet; to trace; to trail; as, to track a deer in the snow.
Tuberculose: Having tubercles; affected with, or characterized by, tubercles; tubercular.
Traduce: To transfer; to transmit; to hand down; as, to traduce mental qualities to one's descendants.
Telugu: Of or pertaining to the Telugu language, or the Telugus.
Turfite: A votary of the turf, or race course; hence, sometimes, a blackleg.
Tussah silk: A silk cloth made from the cocoons of a caterpillar other than the common silkworm, much used in Bengal and China.
Two-cycle: A two-stroke cycle for an internal-combustion engine.
Tumultuous: Full of tumult; characterized by tumult; disorderly; turbulent.
Thriftless: Without thrift; not prudent or prosperous in money affairs.
Testiness: The quality or state of being testy; fretfulness; petulance.
Trigger: A catch to hold the wheel of a carriage on a declivity.
Traduct: That which is traducted; that which is transferred; a translation.
Twinned: Composed of parts united according to a law of twinning. See Twin, n., 4.
Three-quarter: Measuring thirty inches by twenty-five; -- said of portraitures.
Translate: To make a translation; to be engaged in translation.
Trimesitic: Of, pertaining to, or designating, a tribasic acid, C6H3.(CO2)3, of the aromatic series, obtained, by the oxidation of mesitylene, as a white crystalline substance.
Tetrabranchiate: Of or pertaining to the Tetrabranchiata.
Transferrer: One who makes a transfer or conveyance.
Transcendentalism: The transcending, or going beyond, empiricism, and ascertaining a priori the fundamental principles of human knowledge.
Transvasation: The act or process of pouring out of one vessel into another.
Tethys: A genus of a large naked mollusks having a very large, broad, fringed cephalic disk, and branched dorsal gills. Some of the species become a foot long and are brilliantly colored.
Tarsometatarsus: The large bone next the foot in the leg of a bird. It is formed by the union of the distal part of the tarsus with the metatarsus.
Tangerine: A kind of orange, much like the mandarin, but of deeper color and higher flavor. It is said to have been produced in America from the mandarin.
Transitory: Continuing only for a short time; not enduring; fleeting; evanescent.
Thallate: A salt of a hypothetical thallic acid.
Trochosphere: A young larval form of many annelids, mollusks, and bryozoans, in which a circle of cilia is developed around the anterior end.
Tripoline: Of or pertaining to Tripoli or its inhabitants; Tripolitan.
Tozy: Soft, like wool that has been teased.
Testifier: One who testifies; one who gives testimony, or bears witness to prove anything; a witness.
Task: To impose a task upon; to assign a definite amount of business, labor, or duty to.
Tritubercular: Having or designating teeth with three cusps or tubercles; tricuspid.
Torpedo catcher: A small fast vessel for pursuing and destroying torpedo boats.
Tatou: The giant armadillo (Priodontes gigas) of tropical South America. It becomes nearly five feet long including the tail. It is noted for its burrowing powers, feeds largely upon dead animals, and sometimes invades human graves.
Two: The sum of one and one; the number next greater than one, and next less than three; two units or objects.
Tropologize: To use in a tropological sense, as a word; to make a trope of.
Thermomagnetism: Magnetism as affected or caused by the action of heat; the relation of heat to magnetism.
Trebleness: The quality or state of being treble; as, the trebleness of tones.
Theologaster: A pretender or quack in theology.
Tetrastyle: Having four columns in front; -- said of a temple, portico, or colonnade.
Torch race: A race by men carrying torches, as in ancient Greece.
Tincture: To communicate a slight foreign color to; to tinge; to impregnate with some extraneous matter.
Toponymy: A system of toponyms; the use of toponyms.
Thoroughpaced: Perfect in what is undertaken; complete; going all lengths; as, a thoroughplaced Tory or Whig.
Typhus: A contagious continued fever lasting from two to three weeks, attended with great prostration and cerebral disorder, and marked by a copious eruption of red spots upon the body. Also called jail fever, famine fever, putrid fever, spottled fever, etc. See Jail fever, under Jail.
Twitcher: One who, or that which, twitches.
Thermotherapy: Treatment of disease by heat, esp. by hot air.
Tabanus: A genus of blood sucking flies, including the horseflies.
Talma: A kind of large cape, or short, full cloak, forming part of the dress of ladies.
Tautochronous: Occupying the same time; pertaining to, or having the properties of, a tautochrone.
telencephalon: the anterior division of the forebrain; the cerebrum and related parts of the hypothalamus.
Thibet cloth: A fabric made of coarse goat's hair; a kind of camlet.
Trainbearer: One who holds up a train, as of a robe.
Threefold: Consisting of three, or thrice repeated; triple; as, threefold justice.
Tartramide: An acid amide derivative of tartaric acid, obtained as a white crystalline substance.
T\u00eate-de-pont: A work thrown up at the end of a bridge nearest the enemy, for covering the communications across a river; a bridgehead.
Tragus: The prominence in front of the external opening of the ear. See Illust. under Ear.
Tenpenny: Denoting a size of nails. See 1st Penny.
Transact: To conduct matters; to manage affairs.
Treasure: To collect and deposit, as money or other valuable things, for future use; to lay up; to hoard; usually with up; as, to treasure up gold.
Triungulus: The active young larva of any oil beetle. It has feet armed with three claws, and is parasitic on bees. See Illust. of Oil beetle, under Oil.
Toxalbumin: Any of a class of toxic substances of protein nature; a toxin.
Triangulares: The triangular, or maioid, crabs. See Illust. under Maioid, and Illust. of Spider crab, under Spider.
Theologize: To frame a system of theology; to theorize or speculate upon theological subjects.
turnkey: Of or pertaining to a building, complex device, system, or industrial installation which is sold by a contractor only after it is ready for immediate occupation or use; fully functional and ready for use;  -- used of complex systems of a type which often require preparation or installation by the user before being capable of functioning as intended; as, a turnkey ethylene production plant;  a turnkey apartment building.
Tumbler: One who tumbles; one who plays tricks by various motions of the body; an acrobat.
Threaten: To use threats, or menaces; also, to have a threatening appearance.
Tacet: It is silent; -- a direction for a vocal or instrumental part to be silent during a whole movement.
Toddler: One who toddles; especially, a young child.
Top-tool: A tool applied to the top of the work, in distinction from a tool inserted in the anvil and on which the work is placed.
Tureenful: As much as a tureen can hold; enough to fill a tureen.
Transversion: The act of changing from prose into verse, or from verse into prose.
Teracrylic: Of, pertaining to, or designating, an acid of the acrylic series, obtained by the distillation of terpenylic acid, as an only substance having a peculiar cheesy odor.
Totem pole: A pole or pillar, carved and  painted with a series of totemic symbols, set up  before the house of certain Indian tribes of the northwest coast of North America, esp. Indians of the Koluschan stock.
Terminism: The doctrine held by the Terminists.
Taciturn: Habitually silent; not given to converse; not apt to talk or speak.
Theorbist: One who plays on a theorbo.
Terminist: One of a class of theologians who maintain that God has fixed a certain term for the probation of individual persons, during which period, and no longer, they have the offer to grace.
Traducingly: In a traducing manner; by traduction; slanderously.
Tun: To put into tuns, or casks.
Towering: Very high; elevated; rising aloft; as, a towering height.
Thymiatechny: The art of employing perfumes in medicine.
Torrential: Of or pertaining to a torrent; having the character of a torrent; caused by a torrent .
Tirralirra: A verbal imitation of a musical sound, as of the note of a lark or a horn.
Tatouay: An armadillo (Xenurus unicinctus), native of the tropical parts of South America. It has about thirteen movable bands composed of small, nearly square, scales. The head is long; the tail is round and tapered, and nearly destitute of scales; the claws of the fore feet are very large. Called also tatouary, and broad-banded armadillo.
Turnspit: One who turns a spit; hence, a person engaged in some menial office.
Trappist: A monk belonging to a branch of the Cistercian Order, which was established by Armand de Rancé in 1660 at the monastery of La Trappe in Normandy.  Extreme austerity characterizes their discipline.  They were introduced permanently into the United States in 1848, and have monasteries in Iowa and Kentucky.
Tuberculization: The development of tubercles; the condition of one who is affected with tubercles.
This: As a demonstrative pronoun, this denotes something that is present or near in place or time, or something just mentioned, or that is just about to be mentioned.
Turbellaria: An extensive group of worms which have the body covered externally with vibrating cilia. It includes the Rhabdocœla and Dendrocœla. Formerly, the nemerteans were also included in this group.
Tolerate: To suffer to be, or to be done, without prohibition or hindrance; to allow or permit negatively, by not preventing; not to restrain; to put up with; as, to tolerate doubtful practices.
Teil: The lime tree, or linden; -- called also teil tree.
Tergant: Showing the back; as, the eagle tergant.
Torchon paper: Paper with a rough surface; esp., handmade paper of great hardness for the use of painters in water colors.
Threadworm: Any long, slender nematode worm, especially the pinworm and filaria.
Toadstool: A name given to many umbrella-shaped fungi, mostly of the genus Agaricus. The species are almost numberless. They grow on decaying organic matter.
Thin: To grow or become thin; -- used with some adverbs, as out, away, etc.; as, geological strata thin out, i. e., gradually diminish in thickness until they disappear.
Torbernite: A mineral occurring in emerald-green tabular crystals having a micaceous structure.  It is a hydrous phosphate of uranium and copper. Called also copper uranite, and chalcolite.
Thecla: Any one of many species of small delicately colored butterflies belonging to Thecla and allied genera; -- called also hairstreak, and elfin.
Teleocephali: An extensive order of bony fishes including most of the common market species, as bass, salmon, cod, perch, etc.
Thylacine: The zebra wolf. See under Wolf.
Troweled: Formed with a trowel; smoothed with a trowel; as, troweled stucco, that is, stucco laid on and ready for the reception of paint.
Titanitic: Pertaining to, or containing, titanium; as, a titanitic mineral.
Teneriffe: A white wine resembling Madeira in taste, but more tart, produced in Teneriffe, one of the Canary Islands; -- called also Vidonia.
Taurocholate: A salt of taurocholic acid; as, sodium taurocholate, which occurs in human bile.
Tumulosity: The quality or state of being tumulous; hilliness.
Transcalency: The quality or state of being transcalent.
Thecosomata: An order of Pteropoda comprising those species which have a shell. See Pteropoda.
Tibicinate: To play on a tibia, or pipe.
Trygon: Any one of several species of large sting rays belonging to Trygon and allied genera.
Trustee process: The process of attachment by garnishment.
Theocratic: Of or pertaining to a theocracy; administred by the immediate direction of God; as, the theocratical state of the Israelites.
Tawdriness: Quality or state of being tawdry.
Turgescent: Becoming turgid or inflated; swelling; growing big.
Top-block: A large ironbound block strapped with a hook, and, when used, hung to an eyebolt in the cap, -- used in swaying and lowering the topmast.
Trivialism: A trivial matter or method; a triviality.
Tetraspore: A nonsexual spore, one of a group of four regularly occurring in red seaweeds.
Tonguester: One who uses his tongue; a talker; a story-teller; a gossip.
Toxoglossa: A division of marine gastropod mollusks in which the radula are converted into poison fangs. The cone shells (Conus), Pleurotoma, and Terebra, are examples. See Illust. of Cone, n., 4, Pleurotoma, and Terebra.
Tetradecane: A light oily hydrocarbon, C14H30, of the marsh-gas series; -- so called from the fourteen carbon atoms in the molecule.
Texture: To form a texture of or with; to interweave.
Teledu: An East Indian carnivore (Mydaus meliceps) allied to the badger, and noted for the very offensive odor that it emits, somewhat resembling that of a skunk. It is a native of the high mountains of Java and Sumatra, and has long, silky fur. Called also stinking badger, and stinkard.
Tamine: A kind of woolen cloth; tammy.
Tephrosia: A genus of leguminous shrubby plants and herbs, mostly found in tropical countries, a few herbaceous species being North American. The foliage is often ashy-pubescent, whence the name.
Tetrachotomous: Having a division by fours; separated into four parts or series, or into series of fours.
Trigonid: The cutting region of the crown of an upper molar, usually the anterior part. That of a lower molar is the Tri"go*nid (&unr_;).
Torpidness: The qualityy or state of being torpid.
Thyrsus: A staff entwined with ivy, and surmounted by a pine cone, or by a bunch of vine or ivy leaves with grapes or berries. It is an attribute of Bacchus, and of the satyrs and others engaging in Bacchic rites.
Transmutable: Capable of being transmuted or changed into a different substance, or into into something of a different form a nature; transformable.
Tapster: One whose business is to tap or draw ale or other liquor.
Tetravalent: Having a valence of four; tetratomic; quadrivalent.
Tripody: Three metrical feet taken together, or included in one measure.
Thick-knee: A stone curlew. See under Stone.
Tasto: A key or thing touched to produce a tone.
Tree burial: Disposal of the dead by placing the corpse among the branches of a tree or in a hollow trunk, a practice among many primitive peoples.
Trapan: To insnare; to catch by stratagem; to entrap; to trepan.
Truckle-bed: A low bed on wheels, that may be pushed under another bed; a trundle-bed.
Tier: A row or rank, especially one of two or more rows placed one above, or higher than, another; as, a tier of seats in a theater.
Theogony: The generation or genealogy of the gods; that branch of heathen theology which deals with the origin and descent of the deities; also, a poem treating of such genealogies; as, the Theogony of Hesiod.
Tonsillitis: Inflammation of the tonsils; --- same as tonsilitis.
Torsade: A twisted cord; also, a molded or worked ornament of similar form.
Thermostatic: Of or pertaining to the thermostat; made or effected by means of the thermostat.
Treatment: The act or manner of treating; management; manipulation; handling; usage; as, unkind treatment; medical treatment.
Thermomotor: A heat engine; a hot-air engine.
Telemotor: A hydraulic device by which the movement of the wheel on the bridge operates the steering gear at the stern.
Tellural: Of or pertaining to the earth.
Trucebreaker: One who violates a truce, covenant, or engagement.
Telodynamic: Relating to a system for transmitting power to a distance by means of swiftly moving ropes or cables driving grooved pulleys of large diameter.
Train oil: Oil procured from the blubber or fat of whales, by boiling.
Tow-head: An urchin who has soft, whitish hair.
Taxis: Manipulation applied to a hernial tumor, or to an intestinal obstruction, for the purpose of reducing it.
Tongue-shaped: Shaped like a tongue; specifically (Bot.), linear or oblong, and fleshy, blunt at the end, and convex beneath; as, a tongue-shaped leaf.
Thermoneurosis: A neurosis caused by exposure to heat.
Tetel: A large African antelope (Alcelaphus tora). It has widely divergent, strongly ringed horns.
Taupie: A foolish or thoughtless young person, esp. a slothful or slovenly woman.
Tesseral: Of, pertaining to, or containing, tesseræ.
Tumefy: To rise in a tumor; to swell.
Trogue: A wooden trough, forming a drain.
Talaria: Small wings or winged shoes represented as fastened to the ankles, -- chiefly used as an attribute of Mercury.
Thief: One who steals; one who commits theft or larceny. See Theft.
Tunicle: A slight natural covering; an integument.
Triumpher: One who was honored with a triumph; a victor.
Tegumentary: Of or pertaining to a tegument or teguments; consisting of teguments; serving as a tegument or covering.
Thermotypy: The art or process of obtaining thermotypes.
Throw-crook: An instrument used for twisting ropes out of straw.
Testification: The act of testifying, or giving testimony or evidence; as, a direct testification of our homage to God.
Transportability: The quality or state of being transportable.
Thebaine: A poisonous alkaloid, C19H21NO3, found in opium in small quantities, having a sharp, astringent taste, and a tetanic action resembling that of strychnine.
Testudo: A genus of tortoises which formerly included a large number of diverse forms, but is now restricted to certain terrestrial species, such as the European land tortoise (Testudo Græca) and the gopher of the Southern United States.
Trehalose: Mycose; -- so called because sometimes obtained from trehala.
Toyshop: A shop where toys are sold.
Terek: A sandpiper (Terekia cinerea) of the Old World, breeding in the far north of eastern Europe and Asia and migrating to South Africa and Australia. It frequents rivers.
Tryst: To mutually agree to meet at a certain place.
Transmissive: Capable of being transmitted; derived, or handed down, from one to another.
Treason: The offense of attempting to overthrow the government of the state to which the offender owes allegiance, or of betraying the state into the hands of a foreign power; disloyalty; treachery.
Trimeran: One of the Trimera. Also used adjectively.
Tridented: Having three prongs; trident; tridentate; as, a tridented mace.
Treacle: A remedy against poison. See Theriac, 1.
Truffle: Any one of several kinds of roundish, subterranean fungi, usually of a blackish color. The French truffle (Tuber melanosporum) and the English truffle (Tuber æstivum) are much esteemed as articles of food.
Traverser: One who, or that which, traverses, or moves, as an index on a scale, and the like.
triboelectricity: electrical charge developed by rubbing objects together, suc as amber on cat fur.
Tailblock: A block with a tail. See Tail, 9.
Telespectroscope: A spectroscope arranged to be attached to a telescope for observation of distant objects, as the sun or stars.
Theca: A sheath; a case; as, the theca, or cell, of an anther; the theca, or spore case, of a fungus; the theca of the spinal cord.
Thousand: Consisting of ten hundred; being ten times one hundred.
Time-honored: Honored for a long time; venerable, and worthy of honor, by reason of antiquity, or long continuance.
Telenergy: Display of force or energy at a distance, or without contact; now more commonly called telekinesis; -- applied to mediumistic phenomena.
Town-crier: A town officer who makes proclamations to the people; the public crier of a town.
Turbinate: Whirling in the manner of a top.
Transvection: The act of conveying or carrying over.
Teratoma: A tumor, sometimes found in newborn children, which is made up of a heterigenous mixture of tissues, as of bone, cartilage and muscle.
Tharos: A small American butterfly (Phycoides tharos) having the upper surface of the wings variegated with orange and black, the outer margins black with small white crescents; -- called also pearl crescent.
Trueness: The quality of being true; reality; genuineness; faithfulness; sincerity; exactness; truth.
Ticket: To distinguish by a ticket; to put a ticket on; as, to ticket goods.
Ticker: One who, or that which, ticks, or produces a ticking sound, as a watch or clock, a telegraphic sounder, etc.
Toftman: The owner of a toft. See Toft, 3.
Transition: Passage from one place or state to another; charge; as, the transition of the weather from hot to cold.
Thiophene: A sulphur hydrocarbon, C4H4S, analogous to furfuran and benzene, and acting as the base of a large number of substances which closely resemble the corresponding aromatic derivatives.
Thermocurrent: A current developed or set in motion by heat; specif., an electric current, in a heterogeneous circuit, due to differences of temperature between the junctions of the substances of which the circuit is composed.
Tillable: Capable of being tilled; fit for the plow; arable.
Theriodont: One of the Theriodontia. Used also adjectively.
Tweezers: Small pinchers used to pluck out hairs, and for other purposes.
Titanic: The name of a large ocean liner which hit an iceberg and sank on its maiden voyage from England to New York in 1912, with the loss of hundreds of lives.  Also, the name of several movies made about the incident.
Terpilene: A polymeric form of terpene, resembling terbene.
Torsel: A plate of timber for the end of a beam or joist to rest on.
Trap: To set traps for game; to make a business of trapping game; as, to trap for beaver.
Taylor-White process: A process (invented about 1899 by Frederick W. Taylor and Maunsel B. White) for giving toughness to self-hardening steels. The steel is heated almost to fusion, cooled to a temperature of from 700° to 850° C. in molten lead, further cooled in oil, reheated to between 370° and 670° C., and cooled in air.
Thirlage: The right which the owner of a mill possesses, by contract or law, to compel the tenants of a certain district, or of his sucken, to bring all their grain to his mill for grinding.
Treaty: The act of treating for the adjustment of differences, as for forming an agreement; negotiation.
Tricksiness: The quality or state of being tricksy; trickiness.
Tetanus: A painful and usually fatal disease, resulting generally from a wound, and having as its principal symptom persistent spasm of the voluntary muscles. When the muscles of the lower jaw are affected, it is called locked-jaw, or lickjaw, and it takes various names from the various incurvations of the body resulting from the spasm.
Triplicate: A third thing corresponding to two others of the same kind.
Tannigen: A compound obtained as a yellowish gray powder by the action of acetyl chloride or acetic anhydride or ordinary tannic acid. It is used as an intestinal astringent, and locally in rhinitis and pharyngitis.
Tonophant: A modification of the kaleidophon, for showing composition of acoustic vibrations. It consists of two thin slips of steel welded together, their length being adjustable by a screw socket.
Trip: A quick, light step; a lively movement of the feet; a skip.
Torchon lace: a simple thread lace worked upon a pillow with coarse thread; also, a similar lace made by machinery.
Thrasonical: Of or pertaining to Thraso; like, or becoming to, Thraso; bragging; boastful; vainglorious.
Tenebr\u00e6: The matins and lauds for the last three days of Holy Week, commemorating the sufferings and death of Christ, -- usually sung on the afternoon or evening of Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday, instead of on the following days.
Tender: To have a care of; to be tender toward; hence, to regard; to esteem; to value.
Tsung-li Yamen: The board or department of foreign affairs in the Chinese government. See Yamen.
Top out: To top off; to finish by putting on a cap of top (uppermost) course (called a top`ping-out" course).
Trampoose: To walk with labor, or heavily; to tramp.
Thenal: Of or pertaining to the thenar; corresponding to thenar; palmar.
theandric: Relating to, or existing by, the union of divine and human operation in Christ, or the joint agency of the divine and human nature.
Taro: A name for several aroid plants (Colocasia antiquorum, var. esculenta, Colocasia macrorhiza, etc.), and their rootstocks. They have large ovate-sagittate leaves and large fleshy tuberous rootstocks, which are cooked and used for food in tropical countries.
Tetrinic: Of, pertaining to, or designating, a complex ketonic acid, C5H6O3, obtained as a white crystalline substance; -- so called because once supposed to contain a peculiar radical of four carbon atoms. Called also acetyl-acrylic acid.
Tomentum: The closely matted hair or downy nap covering the leaves or stems of some plants.
Top-boots: High boots, having generally a band of some kind of light-colored leather around the upper part of the leg; riding boots.
Triune: Being three in one; -- an epithet used to express the unity of a trinity of persons in the Godhead.
Tare: To ascertain or mark the tare of (goods).
Truncate: Appearing as if cut off at the tip; as, a truncate leaf or feather.
Territorial: Of or pertaining to territory or land; as, territorial limits; territorial jurisdiction.
Trigastric: Having three bellies; -- said of a muscle.
Temporofacial: Of or pertaining to both the temple and the face.
Tiresome: Fitted or tending to tire; exhausted; wearisome; fatiguing; tedious; as, a tiresome journey; a tiresome discourse.
Truckage: Money paid for the conveyance of goods on a truck; freight.
Terraqueous: Consisting of land and water; as, the earth is a terraqueous globe.
Tenebrose: Characterized by darkness or gloom; tenebrous.
Taffeta: A fine, smooth stuff of silk, having usually the wavy luster called watering. The term has also been applied to different kinds of silk goods, from the 16th century to modern times.
Teeter: To move up and down on the ends of a balanced plank, or the like, as children do for sport; to seesaw; to titter; to titter-totter.
Toreumatography: A description of sculpture such as bas-relief in metal.
Three-parted: Divided into, or consisting of, three parts; tripartite.
Tomahawk: To cut, strike, or kill, with a tomahawk.
Tamarin: Any one of several species of small squirrel-like South American monkeys of the genus Midas, especially Midas ursulus.
Tamaric: A shrub or tree supposed to be the tamarisk, or perhaps some kind of heath.
Transmigrant: Migrating or passing from one place or state to another; passing from one residence to another.
Tilly-vally: A word of unknown origin and signification, formerly used as expressive of contempt, or when anything said was rejected as trifling or impertinent.
Teetee: Any one of several species of small, soft-furred South American monkeys belonging to Callithrix, Chrysothrix, and allied genera; as, the collared teetee (Callithrix torquatus), and the squirrel teetee (Chrysothrix sciurea). Called also pinche, titi, and saimiri. See Squirrel monkey, under Squirrel.
Thalassic: Of or pertaining to the sea; -- sometimes applied to rocks formed from sediments deposited upon the sea bottom.
True-bred: Of a genuine or right breed; as, a true-bred beast.
Trashy: Like trash; containing much trash; waste; rejected; worthless; useless; as, a trashy novel.
Tabby: To water; to cause to look wavy, by the process of calendering; to calender; as, to tabby silk, mohair, ribbon, etc.
Tautomeric: Relating to, or characterized by, tautomerism.
Tartrated: Containing, or derived from, tartar; combined with tartaric acid.
Tapioca: A coarsely granular substance obtained by heating, and thus partly changing, the moistened starch obtained from the roots of the cassava. It is much used in puddings and as a thickening for soups. See Cassava.
Tesseraic: Diversified by squares; done in mosaic; tessellated.
Topography: The description of a particular place, town, manor, parish, or tract of land; especially, the exact and scientific delineation and description in minute detail of any place or region.
Ton mileage: Ton miles collectively; esp., the total ton miles performed by a railroad in a given period.
Torpedo tube: A tube fixed below or near the water line through which a torpedo is fired, usually by a small charge of gunpowder. On torpedo vessels the tubes are on deck and usually in broadside, on larger vessels usually submerged in broadside and fitted with a movable shield which is pushed out from the vessel's side to protect the torpedo until clear, but formerly sometimes in the bow. In submarine torpedo boats they are in the bow.
Torchwood: The inflammable wood of certain trees (Amyris balsamifera, Amyris Floridana, etc.); also, the trees themselves.
Tithymal: Any kind of spurge, esp. Euphorbia Cyparissias.
Tommy Atkins: Any white regular soldier of the British army; also, such soldiers collectively; -- said to be fictitious name inserted in the models given to soldiers to guide them in filling out account blanks, etc.
Tralucency: Translucency; as, the tralucency of a gem.
Troilus butterfly: A large American butterfly (Papilio troilus). It is black, with yellow marginal spots on the front wings, and blue on the rear; -- also called troilus.
Triose: A sugar derived from a trihydric alcohol
Testatrix: A woman who makes and leaves a will at death; a female testator.
Tortricid: Of or pertaining to Tortix, or the family Tortricidæ.
Turmoil: To be disquieted or confused; to be in commotion.
Thrave: Twenty-four (in some places, twelve) sheaves of wheat; a shock, or stook.
Taxonomy: That division of the natural sciences which treats of the classification of animals and plants, primarily by consideration of their natural relationships with respect to their structure or genetic origin; the laws or principles of classification; systematics.
Thwite: To cut or clip with a knife; to whittle.
Tilt: A thrust, as with a lance.
Tetrolic: Of, pertaining to, or designating, an acid, C3H3.CO2H, of the acetylene series, homologous with propiolic acid, obtained as a white crystalline substance.
Trippet: A cam, wiper, or projecting piece which strikes another piece repeatedly.
Trigynian: Having three pistils or styles; of or pertaining to the Trigynia.
Triumvirate: Government by three in coalition or association; the term of such a government.
Threadfin: Any one of several species of fishes belonging to Polynemus and allied genera. They have numerous long pectoral filaments.
Table work: Typesetting of tabular nmatter, or the type matter set in tabular form.
Troching: One of the small branches of a stag's antler.
Thermosystaltic: Influenced in its contraction by heat or cold; -- said of a muscle.
Turbination: The act of spinning or whirling, as a top.
twenty-four-seven: Without interruption; non-stop; continuous; as, the computer manufacturer provides 24/7 technical help.
Tam-o-shanter: A kind of Scotch cap of wool, worsted, or the like, having a round, flattish top much wider than the band which fits the head, and usually having a tassel in the center.
Turreted: Furnished with a turret or turrets; specifically (Zoöl.), having the whorls somewhat flattened on the upper side and often ornamented by spines or tubercles; -- said of certain spiral shells.
Thinking: The act of thinking; mode of thinking; imagination; cogitation; judgment.
Tinchel: A circle of sportsmen, who, by surrounding an extensive space and gradually closing in, bring a number of deer and game within a narrow compass.
Trachelobranchiate: Having the gills situated upon the neck; -- said of certain mollusks.
Thetine: Any one of a series of complex basic sulphur compounds analogous to the sulphines.
Taring: The common tern; -- called also tarret, and tarrock.
Thecodontia: A group of fossil saurians having biconcave vertebræ and the teeth implanted in sockets.
Tomopteris: A genus of transparent marine annelids which swim actively at the surface of the sea. They have deeply divided or forked finlike organs (parapodia). This genus is the type of the order, or suborder, Gymnocopa.
Trover: The gaining possession of any goods, whether by finding or by other means.
Tuckahoe: A curious vegetable production of the Southern Atlantic United States, growing under ground like a truffle and often attaining immense size. The real nature is unknown. Called also Indian bread, and Indian loaf.
Triplet: A collection or combination of three of a kind; three united.
Tubfish: The sapphirine gurnard (Trigla hirundo). See Illust. under Gurnard.
Thereinto: Into that or this, or into that place.
Typhlosole: A fold of the wall which projects into the cavity of the intestine in bivalve mollusks, certain annelids, starfishes, and some other animals.
Toolshed: a small closed structure in which tools are stored, often found in the back yard of a residence.
Twitch: The act of twitching; a pull with a jerk; a short, sudden, quick pull; as, a twitch by the sleeve.
Tonsure: The act of clipping the hair, or of shaving the crown of the head; also, the state of being shorn.
Thermograph: An instrument for automatically recording indications of the variation of temperature.
Tedesco: German; -- used chiefly of art, literature, etc.
Thracian: Of or pertaining to Thrace, or its people.
Taxeopoda: An order of extinct Mammalia found in the Tertiary formations.
Tartrelic: Of, pertaining to, or designating, an anhydride, C4H4O5, of tartaric acid, obtained as a white crystalline deliquescent substance.
Trichoptera: A suborder of Neuroptera usually having the wings covered with minute hairs. It comprises the caddice flies, and is considered by some to be a distinct order.
Turquoise: Having a fine light blue color, like that of choice mineral turquoise.
Threepenny: Costing or worth three pence; hence, worth but little; poor; mean.
Tetratomic: Consisting of four atoms; having four atoms in the molecule, as phosphorus and arsenic.
Ticktack: With a ticking noise, like that of a watch.
T\u00e6nioglossate: Of or pertaining to the Tænioglossa.
Timeless: Done at an improper time; unseasonable; untimely.
Trundle: To go or move on small wheels; as, a bed trundles under another.
takeover: The acquisition of ownership of one company by another company, usually by purchasing a controlling percentage of its stock or by exchanging stock of the purchasing company for that of the purchased company.  It is a hostile takeover if the management of the company being taken over is opposed to the deal.  A hostile takeover is sometimes organized by a corporate raider.
Tutorship: The office, duty, or care of a tutor; guardianship; tutelage.
Turgescence: The act of swelling, or the state of being swollen, or turgescent.
Table-land: A broad, level, elevated area of land; a plateau.
Thiosulphuric: Of, pertaining to, or designating, an unstable acid, H2S2O3, analogous to sulphuric acid, and formerly called hyposulphurous acid.
Thunderstone: A thunderbolt, -- formerly believed to be a stone.
Trichopterous: Of, pertaining to, or characterizing, the Trichoptera.
Toise: An old measure of length in France, containing six French feet, or about 6.3946 French feet.
Trusting: Having or exercising trust; confiding; unsuspecting; trustful.
Tops-and-bottoms: Small rolls of dough, baked, cut in halves, and then browned in an oven, -- used as food for infants.
Titler: A large truncated cone of refined sugar.
Timist: A performer who keeps good time.
Traditionary: One, among the Jews, who acknowledges the authority of traditions, and explains the Scriptures by them.
Tokened: Marked by tokens, or spots; as, the tokened pestilence.
Triunity: The quality or state of being triune; trinity.
Townsfolk: The people of a town; especially, the inhabitants of a city, in distinction from country people; townspeople.
Transformer: One who, or that which, transforms. Specif. (Elec.), an apparatus for producing from a given electrical current another current of different voltage.
Tillandsia: An immense genus of epiphytic bromeliaceous plants confined to tropical and subtropical America. They usually bear a rosette of narrow overlapping basal leaves, which often hold a considerable quantity of water. The spicate or paniculate flowers have free perianth segments, and are often subtended by colored bracts. Also, a plant of this genus.
Turnix: Any one of numerous species of birds belonging to Turnix or Hemipodius and allied genera of the family Turnicidæ. These birds resemble quails and partridges in general appearance and in some of their habits, but differ in important anatomical characteristics.  The hind toe is usually lacking.  They are found in Asia, Africa, Southern Europe, the East Indian Islands, and esp. in Australia and adjacent islands, where they are called quails (see Quail, n., 3.). See Turnicimorphæ.
Taplings: The strong double leathers by which the two parts of a flail are united.
Tardiness: The quality or state of being tardy.
Toison dor: Lit., the golden fleece; specif., the order of the Golden Fleece, or its jewel.
Trayful: As much as a tray will hold; enough to fill a tray.
Thermodin: A white crystalline substance derived from urethane, used in medicine as an antipyretic, etc.
Toyer: One who toys; one who is full of trifling tricks; a trifler.
Turio: A shoot or sprout from the ground.
Temple: To build a temple for; to appropriate a temple to; as, to temple a god.
Tuscaroras: A tribe of North American Indians formerly living on the Neuse and Tar rivers in North Carolina. They were conquered in 1713, after which the remnant of the tribe joined the Five Nations, thus forming the Six Nations. See Six Nations, under Six.
Tiffin: A lunch, or slight repast between breakfast and dinner; -- originally, a Provincial English word, but introduced into India, and brought back to England in a special sense.
Tapeline: A painted tape, marked with linear dimensions, as inches, feet, etc., and often inclosed in a case, -- used for measuring.
Thundercloud: A cloud charged with electricity, and producing lightning and thunder.
Tamandu: A small ant-eater (Tamandua tetradactyla) native of the tropical parts of South America.
Tying: The act or process of washing ores in a buddle.
Tightener: That which tightens; specifically (Mach.), a tightening pulley.
Tenonian: Discovered or described by M. Tenon, a French anatomist.
Tormentil: A rosaceous herb (Potentilla Tormentilla), the root of which is used as a powerful astringent, and for alleviating gripes, or tormina, in diarrhea.
Trigonal: Having three angles, or corners; triangular; as, a trigonal stem, one having tree prominent longitudinal angles.
Tautoousian: Having the same essence; being identically of the same nature.
Triphthongal: Of or pertaining to a triphthong; consisting of three vowel sounds pronounced together in a single syllable.
Three-color: Designating, or pert. to, a photomechanical process employing printings in three colors, as red, yellow, and blue.
Traditive: Transmitted or transmissible from father to son, or from age, by oral communication; traditional.
Technicist: One skilled in technics or in one or more of the practical arts.
Tallow-face: One who has a sickly, pale complexion.
Tridecatoic: Of, pertaining to, or designating, that acid of the fatty acids heterologous with tridecane. It is a white crystalline substance.
Thalian: Of or pertaining to Thalia; hence, of or pertaining to comedy; comic.
Tufthunting: The practice of seeking after, and hanging on, noblemen, or persons of quality, especially in English universities.
Typhotoxin: A basic substance, C7H17NO2, formed from the growth of the typhoid bacillus on meat pulp. It induces in small animals lethargic conditions with liquid dejecta.
Terebra: A genus of marine gastropods having a long, tapering spire. They belong to the Toxoglossa. Called also auger shell.
Tingis: A genus of small hemipterous insects which injure trees by sucking the sap from the leaves. See Illustration in Appendix.
Teleutospore: The thick-celled winter or resting spore of the rusts (order Uredinales), produced in late summer. See Illust. of Uredospore.
Themis: The goddess of law and order; the patroness of existing rights.
Talpa: A genus of small insectivores including the common European mole.
Templar: Of or pertaining to a temple.
Tufthunter: A hanger-on to noblemen, or persons of quality, especially in English universities; a toady. See 1st Tuft, 3.
Topless: Having no top, or no visble fop; hence, fig.: very lofty; supreme; unequaled.
Thiophenic: Of, pertaining to, or derived from, thiophene; specifically, designating a certain acid analogous to benzoic acid.
True-born: Of genuine birth; having a right by birth to any title; as, a true-born Englishman.
Top-shell: Any one of numerous species of marine top-shaped shells of the genus Trochus, or family Trochidæ.
Tandem cart: A kind of two-wheeled vehicle with seats back to back, the front one somewhat elevated.
Trisulphide: A sulphide containing three atoms of sulphur.
Theoretic: Pertaining to theory; depending on, or confined to, theory or speculation; speculative; terminating in theory or speculation: not practical; as, theoretical learning; theoretic sciences.
Thurst: The ruins of the fallen roof resulting from the removal of the pillars and stalls.
Theorist: One who forms theories; one given to theory and speculation; a speculatist.
Tire: To exhaust the strength of, as by toil or labor; to exhaust the patience of; to wear out (one's interest, attention, or the like); to weary; to fatigue; to jade.
Tether-ball: A game played with rackets and a ball suspended by a string from an upright pole, the object of each side being to wrap the string around the pole by striking the ball in a direction opposite to the other.
Theologian: A person well versed in theology; a professor of theology or divinity; a divine.
Tragi-comic: Of or pertaining to tragi-comedy; partaking of grave and comic scenes.
Testify: In a testy manner; fretfully; peevishly; with petulance.
Tiddledywinks: A game in which the object is to snap small disks of plastic, bone, ivory, or the like, from a flat surface, as of a table, into a small cup or basket; -- called also tiddlywinks.
Tirl: To quiver; to vibrate; to veer about.
Teguexin: A large South American lizard (Tejus teguexin). It becomes three or four feet long, and is blackish above, marked with yellowish spots of various sizes. It feeds upon fruits, insects, reptiles, young birds, and birds' eggs. The closely allied species Tejus rufescens is called red teguexin.
Toxin: A poisonous product formed by an organism, such as a pathogenic bacterium, a plant or an animal, usually having a high molecular weight, often a protein or a polysaccharide, but occasionally a low-molecular weight agent such as tetrodotoxin.
Transude: To pass, as perspirable matter does, through the pores or interstices of textures; as, liquor may transude through leather or wood.
Teeswater: A breed of cattle formerly bred in England, but supposed to have originated in Holland and to have been the principal stock from which the shorthorns were derived.
Toxic: Of or pertaining to poison; poisonous; as, toxic medicines.
Teleosaur: Any one of several species of fossil suarians belonging to Teleosaurus and allied genera. These reptiles are related to the crocodiles, but have biconcave vertebræ.
Transmissionist: An adherent of a theory, the transmission theory, that the brain serves to “transmit,” rather than to originate, conclusions, and hence that consciousness may exist independently of the brain.
Tideway: Channel in which the tide sets.
Trout: Any one of numerous species of fishes belonging to Salmo, Salvelinus, and allied genera of the family Salmonidæ. They are highly esteemed as game fishes and for the quality of their flesh. All the species breed in fresh water, but after spawning many of them descend to the sea if they have an opportunity.
Turdiformes: A division of singing birds including the thrushes and allied kinds.
Torridness: The quality or state of being torrid or parched.
Tricrotic: Of or pertaining to tricrotism; characterized by tricrotism.
Taxation: The act of laying a tax, or of imposing taxes, as on the subjects of a state, by government, or on the members of a corporation or company, by the proper authority; the raising of revenue; also, a system of raising revenue.
Trenton period: A subdivision in the lower Silurian system of America; -- so named from Trenton Falls, in New York. The rocks are mostly limestones, and the period is divided into the Trenton, Utica, and Cincinnati epochs. See the Chart of Geology.
Terpsichorean: Of or pertaining to Terpsichore; of or pertaining to dancing.
Top secret: containing information whose disclosure could result in grave danger to the national security; -- the highest of the three commonly known levels of national security classification, the others being confidential and secret.
Thirty-second: Being one of thirty-two equal parts into which anything is divided.
Top-tackle: A tackle used in hoisting and lowering the topmast.
Tideland: Land that is overflowed by tide water; hence, land near the sea.
Tithable: Subject to the payment of tithes; as, tithable lands.
Trichogyne: The slender, hairlike cell which receives the fertilizing particles, or antherozoids, in red seaweeds.
Timberhead: The top end of a timber, rising above the gunwale, and serving for belaying ropes, etc.; -- called also kevel head.
Thionyl: The hypothetical radical SO, regarded as an essential constituent of certain sulphurous compounds; as, thionyl chloride.
T\u00eate: A kind of wig; false hair.
Towpath: A path traveled by men or animals in towing boats; -- called also towing path.
Teretial: Rounded; as, the teretial tracts in the floor of the fourth ventricle of the brain of some fishes.
Thirl: To bore; to drill or thrill. See Thrill.
Tiptoe: To step or walk on tiptoe.
Triens: A Roman copper coin, equal to one third of the as. See 3d As, 2.
Tulip: Any plant of the liliaceous genus Tulipa. Many varieties are cultivated for their beautiful, often variegated flowers.
Tetter-totter: A certain game of children; seesaw; -- called also titter-totter, and titter-cum-totter.
Tracheobranchia: One of the gill-like breathing organs of certain aquatic insect larvæ. They contain tracheal tubes somewhat similar to those of other insects.
Trailing edge: A following edge. See Advancing edge, above.
Trihedral: Having three sides or faces; thus, a trihedral angle is a solid angle bounded by three plane angles.
Tincal: Crude native borax, formerly imported from Thibet. It was once the chief source of boric compounds.  Cf. Borax.
