Tmesis: The separation of the parts of a compound word by the intervention of one or more words; as, in what place soever, for whatsoever place.
Thermophone: A portable form of telethermometer, using a telephone in connection with a differential thermometer.
Trevat: A weaver's cutting instrument; for severing the loops of the pile threads of velvet.
Transanimation: The conveyance of a soul from one body to another.
Tardigrada: A tribe of edentates comprising the sloths. They are noted for the slowness of their movements when on the ground. See Sloth, 3.
Trisection: The division of a thing into three parts, Specifically: (Geom.) the division of an angle into three equal parts.
Tardation: The act of retarding, or delaying; retardation.
Threshold: The plank, stone, or piece of timber, which lies under a door, especially of a dwelling house, church, temple, or the like; the doorsill; hence, entrance; gate; door.
Townhouse: A building devoted to the public used of a town; a townhall.
Total: To bring to a total; also, to reach as a total; to amount to.
Turgidity: The quality or state of being turgid.
Top-rope: A rope used for hoisting and lowering a topmast, and for other purposes.
Top-shaped: Having the shape of a top;
Teemer: One who teems, or brings forth.
Tetrastich: A stanza, epigram, or poem, consisting of four verses or lines.
Theosophistical: Of or pertaining to theosophy; theosophical.
Twelfth-cake: An ornamented cake distributed among friends or visitors on the festival of Twelfth-night.
Theocrat: One who lives under a theocratic form of government; one who in civil affairs conforms to divine law.
Tilth: The state of being tilled, or prepared for a crop; culture; as, land is good tilth.
Tonsillectomy: The operation of removing the tonsils; -- formerly also called tonsilotomy.
Turkism: A Turkish idiom or expression; also, in general, a Turkish mode or custom.  Same as Turcism.
Tramp: A foot journey or excursion; as, to go on a tramp; a long tramp.
Tailor-made: Made by a tailor or according to a tailor's fashion; -- said specif. of women's garments made with certain closeness of fit, simplicity of ornament, etc.
Tympanites: A flatulent distention of the belly; tympany.
Tastable: Capable of worthy of being tasted; savory; relishing.
Tangun: A piebald variety of the horse, native of Thibet.
Tractor screw: A propeller screw placed in front of the supporting planes of an airplane instead of behind them, so that it exerts a pull instead of a push. Hence, Tractor monoplane, Tractor biplane, etc.  This is the most common arrangement for propellers on modern airplanes.
Thirdings: The third part of the corn or grain growing on the ground at the tenant's death, due to the lord for a heriot, as within the manor of Turfat in Herefordshire.
Toluyl: Any one of the three hypothetical radicals corresponding to the three toluic acids.
Tolsester: A toll or tribute of a sextary of ale, paid to the lords of some manors by their tenants, for liberty to brew and sell ale.
Tetramera: A division of Coleoptera having, apparently, only four tarsal joints, one joint being rudimentary.
Timekeeper: A clock, watch, or other chronometer; a timepiece.
Trench-plow: To plow with deep furrows, for the purpose of loosening the land to a greater depth than usual.
Trimethyl: A prefix or combining form (also used adjectively) indicating the presence of three methyl groups.
Tun-bellied: Having a large, protuberant belly, or one shaped like a tun; pot-bellied.
Tablespoon: A spoon of the largest size commonly used at the table; -- distinguished from teaspoon, dessert spoon, etc.
Tractable: Capable of being easily led, taught, or managed; docile; manageable; governable; as, tractable children; a tractable learner.
Tubman: One of the two most experienced barristers in the Court of Exchequer.  Cf. Postman, 2.
Tamarisk: Any shrub or tree of the genus Tamarix, the species of which are European and Asiatic.  They have minute scalelike leaves, and small flowers in spikes.  An Arabian species (Tamarix mannifera) is the source of one kind of manna.
Their: The possessive case of the personal pronoun they; as, their houses; their country.
Tepefy: To make or become tepid, or moderately warm.
Tack: To change the direction of a vessel by shifting the position of the helm and sails; also (as said of a vessel), to have her direction changed through the shifting of the helm and sails. See Tack, v. t., 4.
Tetrazole: A crystalline acid substance, CH2N4, which may be regarded as pyrrol in which nitrogen atoms replace three CH groups; also, any of various derivatives of the same.
Townspeople: The inhabitants of a town or city, especially in distinction from country people; townsfolk.
Taqua-nut: A Central American name for the ivory nut.
Tacking: A union of securities given at different times, all of which must be redeemed before an intermediate purchaser can interpose his claim.
Tice: A ball bowled to strike the ground about a bat's length in front of the wicket.
Thrown: a. & p. p. from Throw, v.
Tomaley: The liver of the lobster, which becomes green when boiled; -- called also tomalline.
Tipula: Any one of many species of long-legged dipterous insects belonging to Tipula and allied genera. They have long and slender bodies. See Crane fly, under Crane.
Tusche: A lithographic drawing or painting material of the same nature as lithographic ink. It is also used as a resistant in the biting-in process.
Tench: A European fresh-water fish (Tinca tinca, or Tinca vulgaris) allied to the carp. It is noted for its tenacity of life.
Torques: A cervical ring of hair or feathers, distinguished by its color or structure; a collar.
T: the twentieth letter of the English alphabet, is a nonvocal consonant. With the letter h it forms the digraph th, which has two distinct sounds, as in thin, then. See Guide to Pronunciation, §§262-264, and also §§153, 156, 169, 172, 176, 178-180.
Toxicology: The science which treats of poisons, their effects, antidotes, and recognition; also, a discourse or treatise on the science.
Tarso-: A combining form used in anatomy to indicate connection with, or relation to, the tarsus; as, tarsometatarsus.
Transience: The quality of being transient; transientness.
Temporizingly: In a temporizing or yielding manner.
Tabefaction: A wasting away; a gradual losing of flesh by disease.
Telegrammic: Pertaining to, or resembling, a telegram; laconic; concise; brief.
Toxoid: An altered form of a toxin, possessing little or no toxic power.
Tamarack: The American larch; also, the larch of Oregon and British Columbia (Larix occidentalis). See Hackmatack, and Larch.
Trireme: An ancient galley or vessel with tree banks, or tiers, of oars.
Tetradactylous: Having, or characterized by, four digits to the foot or hand.
Timocracy: A state in which the love of honor is the ruling motive.
Tortility: The quality or state of being tortile, twisted, or wreathed.
Thiosulphate: A salt of thiosulphuric acid; -- formerly called hyposulphite.
Thysanopterous: Of or pertaining to the Thysanoptera.
Thud: To make, or strike so as to make, a dull sound, or thud.
Telephotographic: Designating, or pertaining to, the process of telephotography.
Trag\u00e9dienne: A woman who plays in tragedy.
Tanghinia: The ordeal tree. See under Ordeal.
Thuja: A genus of evergreen trees, thickly branched, remarkable for the distichous arrangement of their branches, and having scalelike, closely imbricated, or compressed leaves.
Testable: Capable of being tested or proved.
Tomtate: A Florida and West Indian grunt (Bathystoma rimator or Hæmulon rimator); also, any of various allied species.
Tapetum: An area in the pigmented layer of the choroid coat of the eye in many animals, which has an iridescent or metallic luster and helps to make the eye visible in the dark. Sometimes applied to the whole layer of pigmented epithelium of the choroid.
Terrorist: One who governs by terrorism or intimidation; specifically, an agent or partisan of the revolutionary tribunal during the Reign of Terror in France.
Tinsel: To adorn with tinsel; to deck out with cheap but showy ornaments; to make gaudy.
Teachable: Capable of being taught; apt to learn; also, willing to receive instruction; docile.
Transgressor: One who transgresses; one who breaks a law, or violates a command; one who violates any known rule or principle of rectitude; a sinner.
Tarnish: The quality or state of being tarnished; stain; soil; blemish.
Terminative: Tending or serving to terminate; terminating; determining; definitive.
Turnery: The art of fashioning solid bodies into cylindrical or other forms by means of a lathe.
Twining: The act of one who, or that which, twines; (Bot.) the act of climbing spirally.
Trundletail: A round or curled-up tail; also, a dog with such a tail.
Thermodynamics: The science which treats of the mechanical action or relations of heat.
Tempestuous: Of or pertaining to a tempest; involving or resembling a tempest; turbulent; violent; stormy; as, tempestuous weather; a tempestuous night; a tempestuous debate.
Telotrochal: Having both a preoral and a posterior band of cilla; -- applied to the larvæ of certain annelids.
Terrorism: The act of terrorizing, or state of being terrorized; a mode of government by terror or intimidation.
Tetraptote: A noun that has four cases only.
Trinervate: Having three ribs or nerves extending unbranched from the base to the apex; -- said of a leaf.
Thundershower: A shower accompanied with lightning and thunder.
Tenderfoot: A delicate person; one not inured to the hardship and rudeness of pioneer life.
Turn-out: The act of coming forth; a leaving of houses, shops, etc.; esp., a quitting of employment for the purpose of forcing increase of wages; a strike; -- opposed to lockout.
Tabor: To make (a sound) with a tabor.
Trustless: That may not be trusted; not worthy of trust; unfaithful.
Tellureted: Combined or impregnated with tellurium; tellurized.
Tribble: A frame on which paper is dried.
Treadmill: A mill worked by persons treading upon steps on the periphery of a wide wheel having a horizontal axis. It is used principally as a means of prison discipline. Also, a mill worked by horses, dogs, etc., treading an endless belt.
Tawniness: The quality or state of being tawny.
Tumult: To make a tumult; to be in great commotion.
Tranquilize: To render tranquil; to allay when agitated; to compose; to make calm and peaceful; as, to tranquilize a state disturbed by factions or civil commotions; to tranquilize the mind.
Taborer: One who plays on the tabor.
Tided: Affected by the tide; having a tide.
Transpadane: Lying or being on the further side of the river Po with reference to Rome, that is, on the north side; -- opposed to cispadane.
Taphouse: A house where liquors are retailed.
Tenthredinides: A group of Hymneoptera comprising the sawflies.
Tabaret: A stout silk having satin stripes, -- used for furniture.
Tumbrel: A cucking stool for the punishment of scolds.
Tapering: Becoming gradually smaller toward one end.
Trying: Adapted to try, or put to severe trial; severe; afflictive; as, a trying occasion or position.
Tergeminal: Thrice twin; having three pairs of leaflets.
Trammel wheel: A circular plate or a cross, with two or more cross grooves intersecting at the center, used on the end of a shaft to transmit motion to another shaft not in line with the first.
Tour: To make a tourm; as, to tour throught a country.
Trollopee: A kind of loose dress for women.
Trawlerman: A fisherman who used unlawful arts and engines to catch fish.
Truage: A pledge of truth or peace made on payment of a tax.
Thermovoltaic: Of or relating to heat and electricity; especially, relating to thermal effects produced by voltaic action.
Throwster: One who throws or twists silk; a thrower.
Toilet: A covering of linen, silk, or tapestry, spread over a table in a chamber or a dressing room.
Tumular: Consisting in a heap; formed or being in a heap or hillock.
Tertiate: To do or perform for the third time.
Tertiary: A member of the Third Order in any monastic system; as, the Franciscan tertiaries; the Dominican tertiaries; the Carmelite tertiaries. See Third Order, under Third.
Thummim: A mysterious part or decoration of the breastplate of the Jewish high priest. See the note under Urim.
Toiler: One who toils, or labors painfully.
Tracheotomy: The operation of making an opening into the windpipe.
Tien an men: a large plaza in Beijing, China.
Thysanurous: Of or pertaining to the Thysanura.
Talon: The claw of a predaceous bird or animal, especially the claw of a bird of prey.
Tilter: One who tilts, or jousts; hence, one who fights.
Tangential: Of or pertaining to a tangent; in the direction of a tangent.
Tiliaceous: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, a natural family of plants (Tiliaceæ) of which the linden (Tilia) is the type. The family includes many plants which furnish a valuable fiber, as the jute.
Toady: To fawn upon with mean sycophancy.
Take-up: That which takes up or tightens; specifically, a device in a sewing machine for drawing up the slack thread as the needle rises, in completing a stitch.
Teraconic: Pertaining to, or designating, an acid obtained by the distillation of terebic acid, and homologous with citraconic acid.
Tele-iconograph: An instrument essentially the same as the telemetrograph.
Theanthropism: A state of being God and man.
Thrashel: An instrument to thrash with; a flail.
Tropidine: An alkaloid, C8H13N, obtained by the chemical dehydration of tropine, as an oily liquid having a coninelike odor.
Trogonoid: Like or pertaining to the trogons.
Tetrad: The number four; a collection of four things; a quaternion.
Tobie: A kind of inferior cigar of a long slender shape, tapered at one end.
Turret lathe: a lathe fitted with a turrethead.
Trojan: Of or pertaining to ancient Troy or its inhabitants.
Tetravalence: The quality or state of being tetravalent; quadrivalence.
Tabbinet: A fabric like poplin, with a watered surface.
Tweed: A soft and flexible fabric for men's wear, made wholly of wool except in some inferior kinds, the wool being dyed, usually in two colors, before weaving.
Transmigration: The act of passing from one country to another; migration.
Transfusion: The act of transfusing, or pouring, as liquor, out of one vessel into another.
Tredille: A game at cards for three.
Transcriptive: Done as from a copy; having the style or appearance of a transcription.
Tautegorical: Expressing the same thing with different words; -- opposed to allegorical.
Thurible: A censer of metal, for burning incense, having various forms, held in the hand or suspended by chains; -- used especially at mass, vespers, and other solemn services.
Tentmaker: One whose occupation it is to make tents.
Tartralic: Pertaining to, or designating, an acid obtained as a white amorphous deliquescent substance, C8H10O11; -- called also ditartaric, tartrilic, or tartrylic acid.
Trapdoor: A lifting or sliding door covering an opening in a roof or floor.
Thermochrosy: The property possessed by heat of being composed, like light, of rays of different degrees of refrangibility, which are unequal in rate or degree of transmission through diathermic substances.
Thuringian: Of or pertaining to Thuringia, a country in Germany, or its people.
Talent: Among the ancient Greeks, a weight and a denomination of money equal to 60 minæ or 6,000 drachmæ. The Attic talent, as a weight, was about 57 lbs. avoirdupois; as a denomination of silver money, its value was £243 15s. sterling, or about $1,180.
Transpalatine: Situated beyond or outside the palatine bone; -- said of a bone in the skull of some reptiles.
Tearer: One who tears or rends anything; also, one who rages or raves with violence.
Termatarium: Any nest or dwelling of termes, or white ants.
Trichophore: The special cell in red algæ which produces or bears a trichogyne. See Illust. of Trichogyne.
Tetra-: A combining form or prefix signifying four, as in tetrabasic, tetrapetalous.
Transmeable: Capable of being passed over or traversed; passable.
Triceps: A muscle having three heads; specif., the great extensor of the forearm, arising by three heads and inserted into the olecranon at the elbow.
thaneship: The state or dignity of a thane; thanehood; also, the seignioralty of a thane.
Toothshell: Any species of Dentalium and allied genera having a tooth-shaped shell. See Dentalium.
Toxicity: The quality or state of being toxic or poisonous; poisonousness.
Toastmaster: A person who presides at a public dinner or banquet, and announces the toasts.
Trochili: A division of birds comprising the humming birds.
Topophone: A double ear trumpet for estimating the direction from which sounds proceed, esp. for the use of navigators.
Triger process: A method of sinking through water-bearing ground, in which the shaft is lined with tubbing and provided with an air lock, work being proceeded with under air pressure.
Telescope: Capable of being extended or compacted, like a telescope, by the sliding of joints or parts one within the other; telescopic; as, a telescope bag; telescope table, etc.; -- now more commonly replaced by the term telescoping.
Ten: The number greater by one than nine; the sum of five and five; ten units of objects.
Transversal: A straight line which traverses or intersects any system of other lines, as a line intersecting the three sides of a triangle or the sides produced.
Tussal: Pertaining to, or manifested by, cough.
Ted: To spread, or turn from the swath, and scatter for drying, as new-mowed grass; -- chiefly used in the past participle.
Tee: To place (the ball) on a tee; also called to tee up.
Tussah: An undomesticated East Indian silkworn (Antheræa mylitta), that feeds on the leaves of the oak and other plants.
Teg: A sheep in its second year; also, a doe in its second year.
Twist: The act of twisting; a contortion; a flexure; a convolution; a bending.
Tormentry: Anything producing torment, annoyance, or pain.
Tabularization: The act of tabularizing, or the state of being tabularized; formation into tables; tabulation.
Telescopy: The art or practice of using or making telescopes.
Topology: The art of, or method for, assisting the memory by associating the thing or subject to be remembered with some place.
Tew: A rope or chain for towing a boat; also, a cord; a string.
Truckman: One who does business in the way of barter or exchange.
Thanksgive: To give or dedicate in token of thanks.
Trichomatose: Affected with a disease which causes agglutination and matting together; -- said of the hair when affected with plica. See Plica, 1.
Thranite: One of the rowers on the topmost of the three benches in a trireme.
Tersanctus: An ancient ascription of praise (containing the word “Holy” -- in its Latin form, “Sanctus” -- thrice repeated), used in the Mass of the Roman Catholic Church and before the prayer of consecration in the communion service of the Church of England and the Protestant Episcopal Church.  Cf. Trisagion.
Ty-all: Something serving to tie or secure.
Thermotension: A process of increasing the strength of wrought iron by heating it to a determinate temperature, and giving to it, while in that state, a mechanical strain or tension in the direction in which the strength is afterward to be exerted.
Teakettle: A kettle in which water is boiled for making tea, coffee, etc.
Transcolation: Act of transcolating, or state of being transcolated.
Tetany: A morbid condition resembling tetanus, but distinguished from it by being less severe and having intermittent spasms.
Tyrannic: Of or pertaining to a tyrant; suiting a tyrant; unjustly severe in government; absolute; imperious; despotic; cruel; arbitrary; as, a tyrannical prince; a tyrannical master; tyrannical government.
Trousers: A garment worn by men and boys, extending from the waist to the knee or to the ankle, and covering each leg separately.
Testudinarious: Of or pertaining to the shell of a tortoise; resembling a tortoise shell; having the color or markings of a tortoise shell.
Therefor: For that, or this; for it.
Towardliness: The quality or state of being towardly; docility; tractableness.
Thallic: Of or pertaining to thallium; derived from, or containing, thallium; specifically, designating those compounds in which the element has a higher valence as contrasted with the thallous compounds; as, thallic oxide.
Tenderling: One made tender by too much kindness; a fondling.
Toadeater: A fawning, obsequious parasite; a mean sycophant; a flatterer; a toady.
Temporary: Lasting for a time only; existing or continuing for a limited time; not permanent; as, the patient has obtained temporary relief.
Trisplanchnic: Of or pertaining to the three great splanchnic cavities, namely, that of the head, the chest, and the abdomen; -- applied to the sympathetic nervous system.
Trumpetwood: A tropical American tree (Cecropia peltata) of the Breadfruit family, having hollow stems, which are used for wind instruments; -- called also snakewood, and trumpet tree.
Testicond: Having the testicles naturally concealed, as in the case of the cetaceans.
Tempo: The rate or degree of movement in time.
Thermosiphon: An arrangement of siphon tubes for assisting circulation in a liquid.
Tchick: A slight sound such as that made by pressing the tongue against the roof of the mouth and explosively sucking out the air at one side, as in urging on a horse.
Treatable: Manageable; tractable; hence, moderate; not violent.
Thysanoptera: A division of insects, considered by some writers a distinct order, but regarded by others as belonging to the Hemiptera. They are all of small size, and have narrow, broadly fringed wings with rudimentary nervures. Most of the species feed upon the juices of plants, and some, as those which attack grain, are very injurious to crops. Called also Physopoda.  See Thrips.
Theistic: Of or pertaining to theism, or a theist; according to the doctrine of theists.
Thecaphore: A surface or organ bearing a theca, or covered with thecæ.
Tempt: To put to trial; to prove; to test; to try.
Tinamides: A division of struthious birds, including the tinamous.
Tick: To check off by means of a tick or any small mark; to score.
Tempering: The process of giving the requisite degree of hardness or softness to a substance, as iron and steel; especially, the process of giving to steel the degree of hardness required for various purposes, consisting usually in first plunging the article, when heated to redness, in cold water or other liquid, to give an excess of hardness, and then reheating it gradually until the hardness is reduced or drawn down to the degree required, as indicated by the color produced on a polished portion, or by the burning of oil.
Trichroism: The quality possessed by some crystals of presenting different colors in three different directions.
Turntable: A large revolving platform, for turning railroad cars, locomotives, etc., in a different direction; -- called also turnplate.
Trunkful: As much as a trunk will hold; enough to fill a trunk.
Trickster: One who tricks; a deceiver; a tricker; a cheat.
Trilling: One of tree children born at the same birth.
Tophet: A place lying east or southeast of Jerusalem, in the valley of Hinnom.
touch up: To make minor improvements in, especially in the appearance.
Triploblastic: Of, pertaining to, or designating, that condition of the ovum in which there are three primary germinal layers, or in which the blastoderm splits into three layers.
Tapered: Lighted with a taper or tapers; as, a tapered choir.
Tautology:
A repetition of the same meaning in different words; needless repetition of an idea in different words or phrases; a representation of anything as the cause, condition, or consequence of itself, as in the following lines: --

The dawn is overcast, the morning lowers,
And heavily in clouds brings on the day. Addison.
Tuz: A lock or tuft of hair.
Thug: One of an association of robbers and murderers in India who practiced murder by stealthy approaches, and from religious motives. They have been nearly exterminated by the British government.
Trinitrocellulose: Gun cotton; -- so called because regarded as containing three nitro groups.
Traumatic: Of or pertaining to wounds; applied to wounds.
Transvolation: The act of flying beyond or across.
Testament: A solemn, authentic instrument in writing, by which a person declares his will as to disposal of his estate and effects after his death.
Thalassinian: Any species of Thalassinidæ, a family of burrowing macrurous Crustacea, having a long and soft abdomen.
Theorization: The act or product of theorizing; the formation of a theory or theories; speculation.
Tinning: The act, art, or process of covering or coating anything with melted tin, or with tin foil, as kitchen utensils, locks, and the like.
Transgress: To offend against the law; to sin.
Tachhydrite: A hydrous chloride of calcium and magnesium occurring in yellowish masses which rapidly deliquesce upon exposure.  It is found in the salt mines at Stassfurt.
Thooid: Of or pertaining to a group of carnivores, including the wovels and the dogs.
Theoretics: The speculative part of a science; speculation.
Transpierce: To pierce through; to penetrate; to permeate; to pass through.
Tweedledum and Tweedledee: Two things practically alike; -- a phrase coined by John Byrom (1692-1793) in his satire “On the Feuds between Handel and Bononcini.”
Thus: In this or that manner; on this wise.
Talebearer: One who officiously tells tales; one who impertinently or maliciously communicates intelligence, scandal, etc., and makes mischief.
Thaumatrope: An optical instrument or toy for showing the persistence of an impression upon the eyes after the luminous object is withdrawn.
Telephoto: of or relating to photography with a telephoto lens.
Technicals: Those things which pertain to the practical part of an art, science, or profession; technical terms; technics.
Thicket: A wood or a collection of trees, shrubs, etc., closely set; as, a ram caught in a thicket.
Teleostei: A subclass of fishes including all the ordinary bony fishes as distinguished from the ganoids.
Telephote: A telelectric apparatus for producing images of visible objects at a distance.
